description: The CompTIA IT Fundamentals Certification is an entry level certification designed to introduce users to basic computer principles. It covers basic IT literacy and ensures one understands the different terminology and the various concepts involved In the IT industry. It also serves as a great starting point if you are just getting started in computers and is designed to be the first step on your way to pursuing the CompTIA A+ certification or others similar. Topics covered include hardware basics, troubleshooting, software installation, security and also networking.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.647
[SOUND] In this video we're gonna

2
00:00:02.647 --> 00:00:07.539
take a look at the CompTIA IT Fundamentals
certification.

3
00:00:07.539 --> 00:00:09.036
Now if you haven't heard of it,

4
00:00:09.036 --> 00:00:13.240
the IT Fundamentals certification is one
of many certifications from CompTIA.

5
00:00:13.240 --> 00:00:16.590
And it's designed for
people who want to get into IT but

6
00:00:16.590 --> 00:00:19.340
have little or even no experience.

7
00:00:19.340 --> 00:00:22.640
A lot of people wonder hey if I'm
gonna get into IT where do I start?

8
00:00:22.640 --> 00:00:25.020
This is literally the starting point.

9
00:00:25.020 --> 00:00:28.820
If you have zero experience you've never
really worked with computers much at all

10
00:00:28.820 --> 00:00:31.900
and you wanna get into IT,
this is it, this is the beginning.

11
00:00:31.900 --> 00:00:35.530
Now ComTIA publishes a roadmap to help
us figure out where to get started and

12
00:00:35.530 --> 00:00:37.310
obviously IT fundamentals is
gonna be at the beginning.

13
00:00:37.310 --> 00:00:40.530
Well let's take a look at that roadmap and
I'll show you how it fits in.

14
00:00:40.530 --> 00:00:43.060
Now ComTIA likes to break things
up based on your job role or

15
00:00:43.060 --> 00:00:45.870
what type of job you're looking to pursue.

16
00:00:45.870 --> 00:00:48.630
And so we've got things like
information security, network and

17
00:00:48.630 --> 00:00:52.650
cloud technologies, hardware services and
infrastructure, IT management and

18
00:00:52.650 --> 00:00:57.000
strategy, storage data, web and mobile,
software development, and even training,

19
00:00:57.000 --> 00:00:58.610
if you wanna become an instructor.

20
00:00:58.610 --> 00:01:00.920
And all of these have
a very common element.

21
00:01:00.920 --> 00:01:03.950
If you look at the very beginning,
where they tell you to get started.

22
00:01:03.950 --> 00:01:08.580
You'll see CompTIA IT Fundamentals right
there at the beginning for each and

23
00:01:08.580 --> 00:01:10.130
every one of them.

24
00:01:10.130 --> 00:01:12.570
The idea being that,
if you're going to get into IT,

25
00:01:12.570 --> 00:01:16.530
there's some basic knowledge that
you need to have to get started.

26
00:01:17.600 --> 00:01:20.670
So now we know what
the IT Fundamental Certification is,

27
00:01:20.670 --> 00:01:22.530
what do we need to know to pass the exam?

28
00:01:22.530 --> 00:01:25.400
Well, let's take a look at the exam
objectives, see what it covers.

29
00:01:25.400 --> 00:01:28.240
CompTIA publishes the exam objectives
that you know what to study and

30
00:01:28.240 --> 00:01:30.850
you make sure that you
prepared to get that exam.

31
00:01:30.850 --> 00:01:34.940
And the way it works, is it basically
breaks down all the information

32
00:01:34.940 --> 00:01:39.730
you need to know into five domains,
five different areas of knowledge.

33
00:01:39.730 --> 00:01:42.260
And each one makes up
a portion of the exam.

34
00:01:42.260 --> 00:01:43.840
You'll see some are more
important than others.

35
00:01:43.840 --> 00:01:46.810
For example, we've got basic IT literacy.

36
00:01:46.810 --> 00:01:51.360
In other words, just understanding the
terminology and jargon that we use in IT,

37
00:01:51.360 --> 00:01:54.910
that's 24% of the exam,
it's almost a quarter of the exam.

38
00:01:54.910 --> 00:01:58.420
Versus networking for
example which is only 16% of the exam,

39
00:01:58.420 --> 00:02:00.920
it's a smaller portion of that exam.

40
00:02:00.920 --> 00:02:02.890
It's important knowledge to know but

41
00:02:02.890 --> 00:02:05.840
not everyone gets involved in
networking every single day.

42
00:02:05.840 --> 00:02:07.780
CompTIA has arranged these so

43
00:02:07.780 --> 00:02:10.920
they're weighted based on their
importance out there in the real world.

44
00:02:10.920 --> 00:02:14.980
And IT fundamentals is a pretty
generalized certification.

45
00:02:14.980 --> 00:02:18.270
In other words once you get certified in
this you get the fundamental knowledge,

46
00:02:18.270 --> 00:02:22.100
you then start kind of narrowing
your focus into the particular

47
00:02:22.100 --> 00:02:23.960
field that you want to move into, right?

48
00:02:23.960 --> 00:02:26.430
So this is gonna be a little
bit on the general side.

49
00:02:26.430 --> 00:02:29.920
Now each one of these domains is made up
of a number of different topics, so for

50
00:02:29.920 --> 00:02:32.600
example software, right, 1.0 software.

51
00:02:32.600 --> 00:02:36.980
If we take a look at that one it's divided
up into a number of different things.

52
00:02:36.980 --> 00:02:41.351
Mobile operating systems, desktop
workstations, software compatibility,

53
00:02:41.351 --> 00:02:43.542
awareness of hardware compatibility.

54
00:02:43.542 --> 00:02:47.022
All of these are things we need to
know to keep our software running and

55
00:02:47.022 --> 00:02:49.362
operational and
to be able to troubleshoot and

56
00:02:49.362 --> 00:02:52.690
fix it when it's not working
the way that it's supposed to.

57
00:02:52.690 --> 00:02:54.630
These are all topics that we need to know.

58
00:02:54.630 --> 00:02:58.430
So you'll see these divisions
Inside each of the domains,

59
00:02:58.430 --> 00:03:01.140
as they kind of tailor to
the topics that you wanna cover.

60
00:03:01.140 --> 00:03:03.260
But just at a high level, software.

61
00:03:03.260 --> 00:03:05.220
Those are the programs that
we run on our computer, and

62
00:03:05.220 --> 00:03:07.950
they're the things that we
interact with on a daily basis.

63
00:03:07.950 --> 00:03:12.540
For most of us, when we use a computer
we don't necessarily care what hardware

64
00:03:12.540 --> 00:03:14.620
it has, it's the software that we use.

65
00:03:14.620 --> 00:03:16.976
That's what we interact with,
that's what important to us and so

66
00:03:16.976 --> 00:03:18.890
we need to understand how that works.

67
00:03:18.890 --> 00:03:20.210
Second is hardware.

68
00:03:20.210 --> 00:03:22.900
Hardware is what actually powers
everything behind the scenes.

69
00:03:22.900 --> 00:03:26.960
The hard drive, memory, CPU,
all of those components.

70
00:03:26.960 --> 00:03:29.720
And we don't think about them
a lot until they break and

71
00:03:29.720 --> 00:03:33.060
they malfunction or our system is
running slow and we wanna upgrade.

72
00:03:33.060 --> 00:03:36.610
All of a sudden understanding what
that hardware is, is really important.

73
00:03:36.610 --> 00:03:41.300
When you're looking at a sale and
advertisement in the newspaper and you see

74
00:03:41.300 --> 00:03:45.790
two different computers and they're
four or $500 difference, why is that?

75
00:03:45.790 --> 00:03:48.530
What are the components that make
one worth more than the other?

76
00:03:48.530 --> 00:03:50.970
Understanding hardware is what's going
to help you to answer that question.

77
00:03:50.970 --> 00:03:53.200
All right, then we've got security.

78
00:03:53.200 --> 00:03:55.490
Security is really important.

79
00:03:55.490 --> 00:03:56.710
You'll see it's 21% of the exam.

80
00:03:56.710 --> 00:04:00.170
It's another one that's a fairly
large category on the exam.

81
00:04:00.170 --> 00:04:03.530
And that's because you
see every single week

82
00:04:03.530 --> 00:04:06.010
articles that are being posted about
companies that have been compromised.

83
00:04:06.010 --> 00:04:08.110
Where data has been leaked
onto the Internet or

84
00:04:08.110 --> 00:04:11.140
hackers have broken into a system and
stolen credit card data.

85
00:04:11.140 --> 00:04:12.340
That's not good and

86
00:04:12.340 --> 00:04:16.850
a lot of it is easily avoidable if we
take the proper security precautions.

87
00:04:16.850 --> 00:04:19.810
So in the CompTIA IT Fundamentals
Certification you get

88
00:04:19.810 --> 00:04:21.380
an introduction to security.

89
00:04:21.380 --> 00:04:25.280
That needs to be a fundamental, it needs
to be a part of everything you do in

90
00:04:25.280 --> 00:04:30.080
IT regardless of your actual job role,
IT security is always important.

91
00:04:30.080 --> 00:04:32.060
In 4.0 we've got networking,

92
00:04:32.060 --> 00:04:36.750
it's rare these days to have a computer
that is just standing alone by itself.

93
00:04:36.750 --> 00:04:39.880
We almost always have it connect
to a network like the Internet.

94
00:04:39.880 --> 00:04:41.020
So how do we do that?

95
00:04:41.020 --> 00:04:42.180
How do we get connected to the Internet?

96
00:04:42.180 --> 00:04:43.850
How do we talk between two computers?

97
00:04:43.850 --> 00:04:47.090
How do we share a printer so
we don't have to buy multiple printers?

98
00:04:47.090 --> 00:04:50.060
We could have more than one computer
all using the same printer.

99
00:04:50.060 --> 00:04:53.110
That's all the basic
fundamentals of networking.

100
00:04:53.110 --> 00:04:54.690
And then lastly, IT literacy,

101
00:04:54.690 --> 00:04:58.250
I kind of mentioned already,
which is understanding the jargon.

102
00:04:58.250 --> 00:05:01.110
IT man it is acronym soup.

103
00:05:01.110 --> 00:05:04.870
You have tons and
tons of letters being thrown around and

104
00:05:04.870 --> 00:05:08.220
sometimes they're said like letters,
sometimes they're said like fake words.

105
00:05:08.220 --> 00:05:13.470
You've got scuzzy and PCI, CPU, RAM.

106
00:05:13.470 --> 00:05:14.790
What do all these mean?

107
00:05:14.790 --> 00:05:17.620
We need to make sure we understand
that jargon, otherwise you just get

108
00:05:17.620 --> 00:05:20.180
really confused when you move
into the more advanced topics.

109
00:05:20.180 --> 00:05:23.590
So these are the things that make
up the IT fundamentals exam and

110
00:05:23.590 --> 00:05:26.940
you'll see each one is very important
regardless of whether your goal

111
00:05:26.940 --> 00:05:30.250
is to go into systems administration,
network administration,

112
00:05:30.250 --> 00:05:33.940
if you wanna be an IT security officer,
going into management.

113
00:05:33.940 --> 00:05:38.520
These are topics that every one of
us should know and be aware of.

114
00:05:38.520 --> 00:05:40.320
All right,
now when you're ready to take the exam,

115
00:05:40.320 --> 00:05:43.210
let's talk a little bit about
the actual exam itself, all right?

116
00:05:43.210 --> 00:05:47.210
The exam is a multiple choice
exam that's computer based.

117
00:05:47.210 --> 00:05:49.510
You'll actually go to
a VUE testing center,

118
00:05:49.510 --> 00:05:52.780
Pearson VUE is a company that has
testing centers all over the world.

119
00:05:52.780 --> 00:05:55.180
You'll go to one of their centers,
you'll sit down at a computer, and

120
00:05:55.180 --> 00:05:56.890
you'll take a multiple choice exam.

121
00:05:56.890 --> 00:05:59.770
On a positive note, that means
you'll get your results right away,

122
00:05:59.770 --> 00:06:00.535
which is exciting.

123
00:06:00.535 --> 00:06:03.710
So you can go and take the test and
get the certification all on the same day

124
00:06:03.710 --> 00:06:05.910
have something great right
there on your resume.

125
00:06:05.910 --> 00:06:09.320
The exam is 75 questions, so
it's not too terribly large.

126
00:06:09.320 --> 00:06:13.420
But you do only have 60 minutes,
which means you don't wanna mess around.

127
00:06:13.420 --> 00:06:18.400
If you spend 1 minute per question, well,
you're gonna run out of time on the exam

128
00:06:18.400 --> 00:06:20.920
and you're not gonna get
to the last 15 questions.

129
00:06:20.920 --> 00:06:22.290
So you need to know your content.

130
00:06:22.290 --> 00:06:24.640
Get in there,
answer the questions, and move on.

131
00:06:24.640 --> 00:06:27.300
They are just multiple choice,
that does make it a little bit easier.

132
00:06:27.300 --> 00:06:30.495
You shouldn't have any problems completing
it in the time you have allotted,

133
00:06:30.495 --> 00:06:31.140
all right?

134
00:06:31.140 --> 00:06:33.560
Now it is scored out of 1,000,
you need 650 to pass, so

135
00:06:33.560 --> 00:06:39.330
that's a pretty good passing mark and
the exam itself is $112 United States.

136
00:06:39.330 --> 00:06:41.330
At least if you're in another country,

137
00:06:41.330 --> 00:06:45.000
you'll need to switch to the other pricing
to see what that is gonna be like for you.

138
00:06:45.000 --> 00:06:49.180
Now when you take the exam,
you do need to go to a VUE testing center.

139
00:06:49.180 --> 00:06:51.400
And if you don't know about VUE,

140
00:06:51.400 --> 00:06:54.850
if you haven't dealt with them before,
you're gonna deal with them a lot.

141
00:06:54.850 --> 00:06:56.940
Because CompTIA, Microsoft,

142
00:06:56.940 --> 00:07:01.430
CISCO, all of the big computer vendors out
there use Pearson VUE for their testing.

143
00:07:01.430 --> 00:07:07.790
So to find a center near you, you just go
to their website VUE's website is vue.com.

144
00:07:07.790 --> 00:07:09.500
So if you fire up your
favorite web browser and

145
00:07:09.500 --> 00:07:13.800
go to veu.com, it'll take you to the
webpage that I'm looking at right here.

146
00:07:13.800 --> 00:07:16.900
And there's a link up in the top
that says for test takers.

147
00:07:16.900 --> 00:07:19.850
And so
you can go to the test taker homepage and

148
00:07:19.850 --> 00:07:23.380
they'll have where you can find
the nearest testing center to you.

149
00:07:23.380 --> 00:07:25.050
So it's gonna ask me
what program I'm doing.

150
00:07:25.050 --> 00:07:29.540
I'm gonna type in CompTIA, and so there
we go, we've got CompTIA certifications.

151
00:07:29.540 --> 00:07:33.640
And so I can see some basic information
here, and then we can create an account,

152
00:07:33.640 --> 00:07:37.350
which you will want an account to
track all of your certifications and

153
00:07:37.350 --> 00:07:39.020
then we can find a test center.

154
00:07:39.020 --> 00:07:42.320
So I'm gonna hit that link to
find a test center near me and

155
00:07:42.320 --> 00:07:44.190
we'll see where we can go and take a test.

156
00:07:44.190 --> 00:07:48.460
So you just put in what city you happen to
be in, maybe I'll say that I'm in Orlando,

157
00:07:48.460 --> 00:07:52.230
Florida and we'll do a search and
it's gonna search.

158
00:07:52.230 --> 00:07:56.530
And I'm in the United States, if you're
in Europe, if you're in Asia, Australia,

159
00:07:56.530 --> 00:07:58.330
there's VUE testing centers there too,
right?

160
00:07:58.330 --> 00:08:00.820
So just punch in your country,
it'll find them.

161
00:08:00.820 --> 00:08:01.770
And you can register and

162
00:08:01.770 --> 00:08:04.540
take the exam right there at
the one that's closest to you.

163
00:08:04.540 --> 00:08:07.370
If one is closed or doesn't have
a seat during the time that you want,

164
00:08:07.370 --> 00:08:10.910
you can pick another one, jump over
there and take it there too, all right?

165
00:08:10.910 --> 00:08:13.390
The nice thing here,
you go to a local testing center,

166
00:08:13.390 --> 00:08:17.180
you take the exam, it tells you
immediately whether you pass or fail.

167
00:08:17.180 --> 00:08:20.580
When you pass, you have the certification,
you put it on your resume and now you're

168
00:08:20.580 --> 00:08:24.780
ready to launch that IT career and that's
really what IT fundamentals is all about.

169
00:08:24.780 --> 00:08:26.330
All right, so what's next?

170
00:08:26.330 --> 00:08:30.860
Well if this certification sounds like the
right thing for you then jump out there,

171
00:08:30.860 --> 00:08:33.210
get some training, and
go and take the exam.

172
00:08:33.210 --> 00:08:36.250
CompTIA IT Fundamentals training
from ITProTV is actually available

173
00:08:36.250 --> 00:08:37.020
free of charge.

174
00:08:37.020 --> 00:08:43.910
You can jump over to the itpro.tv
website at http://itpro.tv.

175
00:08:43.910 --> 00:08:46.472
Go in there, sign up for
a free account and

176
00:08:46.472 --> 00:08:51.340
CompTIA IT Fundamental video training
all free of charge go and take the exam,

177
00:08:51.340 --> 00:08:54.610
the only thing you have to pay for
is the exam and you get the certification.

178
00:08:54.610 --> 00:08:58.060
Now if you're knowledge level is already
beyond the topics that are here,

179
00:08:58.060 --> 00:09:01.000
some of you might be a hobbyist
you've been working or helping other

180
00:09:01.000 --> 00:09:05.000
people with computers for a long time,
you might wanna skip over IT fundamentals.

181
00:09:05.000 --> 00:09:08.720
The next one in line though is gonna
vary based on what you wanna do.

182
00:09:08.720 --> 00:09:10.570
If you're looking to do desktop support,

183
00:09:10.570 --> 00:09:13.410
the CompTIA A+ would be
the next certification for you.

184
00:09:13.410 --> 00:09:15.025
If you're looking to do
network administration,

185
00:09:15.025 --> 00:09:17.870
Network+ will be the next
certification for you.

186
00:09:17.870 --> 00:09:21.010
If you're looking to do systems
administrator you might jump over to some

187
00:09:21.010 --> 00:09:23.600
of the Microsoft MTA for
the Windows Operating System or

188
00:09:23.600 --> 00:09:25.200
Windows Server Operating Systems.

189
00:09:25.200 --> 00:09:27.910
Or CompTIA Linux+ if you're
looking to do Linux.

190
00:09:27.910 --> 00:09:30.740
So you start planning for
a focus after this.

191
00:09:30.740 --> 00:09:34.330
But at a general level, just getting
started, this is the right place for you.

192
00:09:34.330 --> 00:09:38.765
The IT fundamentals, jump in, take that
certification and start your IT career.

193
00:09:38.765 --> 00:09:42.984

episodes.title: Software Overview
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:01,114 --> 00:00:07,963
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,963 --> 00:00:13,682
The first domain for
CompTIA IT Fundamentals is 1.0 software.

3
00:00:13,682 --> 00:00:16,650
And in this domain we cover all sorts
of different things that deal with

4
00:00:16,650 --> 00:00:19,480
the interface that a human has with the,
the computer.

5
00:00:19,480 --> 00:00:23,610
Right, the, the programs that we use
to perform the jobs on our system.

6
00:00:23,610 --> 00:00:25,340
Each of these are really important and

7
00:00:25,340 --> 00:00:29,220
this is the most common element
that people deal with on a system.

8
00:00:29,220 --> 00:00:33,031
It also accounts for 21% of the exam, so
we kind of want to know this one and, and

9
00:00:33,031 --> 00:00:34,680
have our good basics there.

10
00:00:34,680 --> 00:00:37,140
But it is definitely
a high-traffic area for us.

11
00:00:37,140 --> 00:00:39,200
If you go to work in the IT profession,

12
00:00:39,200 --> 00:00:41,530
you're gonna be dealing
with software constantly.

13
00:00:42,872 --> 00:00:45,200
All right, so let's take a look
at the objectives inside of that.

14
00:00:45,200 --> 00:00:47,750
Right, so inside of software we're gonna
take a look at several different things

15
00:00:47,750 --> 00:00:51,420
starting with compare and
contrast common operating systems and

16
00:00:51,420 --> 00:00:54,010
their functions and features.

17
00:00:54,010 --> 00:00:56,600
It's pretty rare to find somebody
who doesn't have a computer at

18
00:00:56,600 --> 00:00:57,860
home these days.

19
00:00:57,860 --> 00:01:01,300
But that computer probably runs
one particular operating system,

20
00:01:01,300 --> 00:01:05,400
most commonly Microsoft Windows right,
that's, that's the main operating system

21
00:01:05,400 --> 00:01:09,050
out there in the workplace and it's
still the main operating system at home.

22
00:01:09,050 --> 00:01:12,220
But that's not the only operating
system that's out there.

23
00:01:12,220 --> 00:01:14,390
So we need to be familiar

And see how they list, what's compatible?

1511
01:11:52,091 --> 01:11:56,403
So, if you wanna run the newest
OS X You need to have

1512
01:11:56,403 --> 01:11:59,495
an iMac from mid 2007 or newer.

1513
01:11:59,495 --> 01:12:03,980
So they're really saying that just about
any system they've sold since 2007 can run

1514
01:12:03,980 --> 01:12:05,090
this latest OS.

1515
01:12:05,090 --> 01:12:08,490
But if you have an older one,
something from before there,

1516
01:12:08,490 --> 01:12:10,500
then you're not gonna be able to upgrade,
right?

1517
01:12:10,500 --> 01:12:13,280
So they list it this way just
because they control the hardware.

1518
01:12:13,280 --> 01:12:14,931
They don't have to say the processor and
all that stuff.

1519
01:12:14,931 --> 01:12:17,870
They already know it.

1520
01:12:17,870 --> 01:12:18,730
>> Oh, general requirements.

1521
01:12:18,730 --> 01:12:20,330
There you go.
>> There you go.

1522
01:12:20,330 --> 01:12:23,235
Two gigs of memory,
eight gigs of available storage.

1523
01:12:23,235 --> 01:12:26,596
So a little bit higher on
the memory demands there.

1524
01:12:26,596 --> 01:12:30,840
They do have that minimum of OS 10.6 and
this is now 10.10.

1525
01:12:30,840 --> 01:12:34,240
So they don't support a direct
upgrade from an earlier version.

1526
01:12:35,250 --> 01:12:35,970
Those are basically it.

1527
01:12:35,970 --> 01:12:36,530
So.

1528
01:12:36,530 --> 01:12:37,940
Every operating system has that.

1529
01:12:37,940 --> 01:12:39,700
Every operating system
has minimum requirements.

1530
01:12:39,700 --> 01:12:41,300
You just need to make sure you meet them.

1531
01:12:41,300 --> 01:12:43,940
If you don't,
your user experience will be very poor.

1532
01:12:43,940 --> 01:12:46,210
And there's nothing more
frustrating than a slow computer.

1533
01:12:47,380 --> 01:12:49,970
That'll really get on my nerves, I know.

1534
01:12:49,970 --> 01:12:52,240
[LAUGH]
>> Mine too.

1535
01:12:52,240 --> 01:12:52,960
All right, Ronnie.

1536
01:12:52,960 --> 01:12:55,060
So so let, let's recap this.

1537
01:12:55,060 --> 01:12:55,624
All right?
I,

1538
01:12:55,624 --> 01:12:59,084
in this segment we got a chance to
take a look at operating systems.

1539
01:12:59,084 --> 01:13:00,750
And we discussed several different ones,
right?

1540
01:13:00,750 --> 01:13:02,970
I think we did about eight different
operating systems out there.

1541
01:13:02,970 --> 01:13:05,570
But there are literally
hundreds of OS's out there.

1542
01:13:05,570 --> 01:13:08,346
We just covered the big names,
in, in computing.

1543
01:13:08,346 --> 01:13:11,800
So, wh-, you know,
what's such a big deal about

1544
01:13:11,800 --> 01:13:16,260
these operating systems is that they, they
handle how we interact with the computer.

1545
01:13:16,260 --> 01:13:19,110
They are what most of us think
of our computer, you know.

1546
01:13:19,110 --> 01:13:20,770
And depending on the operating
system you're using,

1547
01:13:20,770 --> 01:13:23,940
you can have a very different
experience from someone else,

1548
01:13:23,940 --> 01:13:26,890
just based on the user interfaces
being provided to you.

1549
01:13:26,890 --> 01:13:27,520
>> Right.

1550
01:13:27,520 --> 01:13:29,431
The operating system, remember,

1551
01:13:29,431 --> 01:13:33,454
really does handle the interaction that
we have as humans to the hardware.

1552
01:13:33,454 --> 01:13:37,590
As well as to the applications
that we want to run.

1553
01:13:37,590 --> 01:13:39,010
Well, if we don't have
an operating system,

1554
01:13:39,010 --> 01:13:42,050
there's no place to run
those applications.

1555
01:13:42,050 --> 01:13:46,574
And of course, we also have to realize
that even if we have different hardware

1556
01:13:46,574 --> 01:13:48,160
attached to that computer.

1557
01:13:48,160 --> 01:13:51,959
They won't be able to interact if we don't
have an operating system that can help us

1558
01:13:51,959 --> 01:13:54,730
to, to be able to use
those different devices.

1559
01:13:54,730 --> 01:14:00,340
So by far, this is the most important
piece of software that we're going to run.

1560
01:14:00,340 --> 01:14:03,300
And depending on the device, whether
we're going to use the mobile OS or

1561
01:14:03,300 --> 01:14:07,890
a work station type of operating system,
is what we're to have to choose.

1562
01:14:07,890 --> 01:14:11,270
And you'll actually see all these
that we mentioned somewhere out there

1563
01:14:11,270 --> 01:14:12,480
as you are doing support.

1564
01:14:13,680 --> 01:14:16,500
>> So, some of the other things
that operating systems do,

1565
01:14:16,500 --> 01:14:20,210
when you hook up external hardware,
things like printers and scanners.

1566
01:14:20,210 --> 01:14:21,970
They're the ones that handle
the communication with that.

1567
01:14:21,970 --> 01:14:24,060
So any special software needed for
that equipment,

1568
01:14:24,060 --> 01:14:27,510
it's the operating system that deals
with that so that you don't have to.

1569
01:14:27,510 --> 01:14:29,550
Other things are file structures,

1570
01:14:29,550 --> 01:14:33,420
how we store our files on a hard drive,
the operating system is managing that.

1571
01:14:33,420 --> 01:14:34,700
Different OS's store files,

1572
01:14:34,700 --> 01:14:37,485
different ways, but
all of them are kind of the same.

1573
01:14:37,485 --> 01:14:39,600
In that they, they store your
files on the drive, and then,

1574
01:14:39,600 --> 01:14:41,650
they retrieve the files
when you want them.

1575
01:14:41,650 --> 01:14:44,660
These are important things things
a lot of us take for granted.

1576
01:14:44,660 --> 01:14:47,610
We, we don't even consider throughout the,
the business of the day,

1577
01:14:47,610 --> 01:14:49,830
but your operating system
is specializing in that.

1578
01:14:49,830 --> 01:14:54,060
So that is obviously a critical
piece of your computing experience.

1579
01:14:55,132 --> 01:14:58,050
All right, I think we've covered
this one pretty well in depth, so

1580
01:14:58,050 --> 01:14:59,660
we'll probably wrap it up here.

1581
01:14:59,660 --> 01:15:00,640
Let me just remind you guys,

1582
01:15:00,640 --> 01:15:04,760
if you have any questions on any of this,
feel free to ask.

1583
01:15:04,760 --> 01:15:06,820
Live during the show,
you can go to itpro.tv/live and

1584
01:15:06,820 --> 01:15:09,569
you'll see the chat box beneath the video.

1585
01:15:09,569 --> 01:15:13,090
You can post your questions there and
we monitor and answer during the show.

1586
01:15:13,090 --> 01:15:17,170
If you have any questions after the show,
use our Q & A forums.

1587
01:15:17,170 --> 01:15:19,970
At the top of every page

1588
01:15:19,970 --> 01:15:22,740
you'll see a link that says" Q & A",
click on it.

1589
01:15:22,740 --> 01:15:23,850
Post your questions in there.

1590
01:15:23,850 --> 01:15:26,590
We monitor and
answer in there after the show.

1591
01:15:26,590 --> 01:15:29,220
So if we're not live, you know,
that's a great resource to use.

1592
01:15:30,340 --> 01:15:32,650
All right, well ladies and
gentlemen I hope you enjoyed the show.

1593
01:15:32,650 --> 01:15:36,000
Signing off for ITproTV, I'm Don Pezet
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

01:15:36,000 --> 01:15:37,613
>> And we will see you next time.

4
00:00:33,627 --> 00:00:37,550
All right, good morning, good afternoon
and good evening and welcome back!

5
00:00:37,550 --> 00:00:41,610
To another episode of IT ProTV, I'm your
host Don Pezet back with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:41,610 --> 00:00:42,330
How's it going Ronnie.

7
00:00:42,330 --> 00:00:44,839
>> It is going well today we are,
are ready for

8
00:00:44,839 --> 00:00:49,576
our second jump in to the realm of IT
fundamentals and we're looking for

9
00:00:49,576 --> 00:00:53,770
a good time in taking with
the applications and software.

10
00:00:53,770 --> 00:00:57,220
>> Now, in our first episode
we covered operating systems

11
00:00:57,220 --> 00:01:00,500
which is that basic interface between
you and your computer hardware.

12
00:01:00,500 --> 00:01:06,088
Now we're gonna take a look at software,
and software, man, is it a big, big field.

13
00:01:06,088 --> 00:01:09,240
In fact, CompTIA gives us this
nice little list that is just,

14
00:01:09,240 --> 00:01:13,330
I mean, it's massive,
this is all we're gonna be talking about.

15
00:01:13,330 --> 00:01:16,200
Of, of all the different software
you can add to your computer.

16
00:01:16,200 --> 00:01:18,070
So what, why would we do that?

17
00:01:18,070 --> 00:01:21,950
Well most modern operating systems,
while they're very powerful and

18
00:01:21,950 --> 00:01:25,890
they do a lot of things, they don't
necessarily do exactly what we want.

19
00:01:25,890 --> 00:01:28,550
Everybody uses a computer
a little bit differently.

20
00:01:28,550 --> 00:01:33,340
And so frequently, we'll need specialized
applications, programs, software, right?

21
00:01:33,340 --> 00:01:36,750
That does something specific
to what I want, all right.

22
00:01:36,750 --> 00:01:40,450
So depending on your job type or
how you use your computer at home,

23
00:01:40,450 --> 00:01:42,300
you'll have different needs for programs.

24
00:01:42,300 --> 00:01:45,440
And it's very rarely that you'll find
two people with the exact same needs, so

25
00:01:45,440 --> 00:01:48,570
people usually have this mixture
of software that they prefer.

26
00:01:48,570 --> 00:01:51,180
That all achieves some
certain kind of goal.

27
00:01:51,180 --> 00:01:55,340
So we're gonna run down that list and
look at all the different software types.

28
00:01:55,340 --> 00:01:56,310
But I shouldn't say all, right?

29
00:01:56,310 --> 00:02:00,420
We're gonna look at the, the main ones and
identify some of the different programs

30
00:02:00,420 --> 00:02:02,130
that are out there that you may or
may not use.

31
00:02:02,130 --> 00:02:02,670
All right.

32
00:02:02,670 --> 00:02:05,350
All, all just trying to familiarize you
with the different types of software

33
00:02:05,350 --> 00:02:05,890
that's available.

34
00:02:07,100 --> 00:02:11,880
Now before we get into that, understand
that programs can take a few different

35
00:02:11,880 --> 00:02:16,060
forms, and things are getting really
different today than they were ten years

36
00:02:16,060 --> 00:02:19,820
ago, and it's because of all the different
ways that we can consume our data.

37
00:02:19,820 --> 00:02:24,230
For example in, in the old days, if you
wanted to program, right, maybe, maybe you

38
00:02:24,230 --> 00:02:28,850
had a store, and you sold things, so
you needed a cash register program, right.

39
00:02:28,850 --> 00:02:31,420
Well you'd go out and buy that software,
you'd install it right here on your

40
00:02:31,420 --> 00:02:34,590
computer, and you'd run it on the
computer, and whenever you wanted to sell

41
00:02:34,590 --> 00:02:36,500
something, you'd go in that software,
and punch it in.

42
00:02:36,500 --> 00:02:37,290
Right.

43
00:02:37,290 --> 00:02:40,880
That was a standard
desktop style application.

44
00:02:40,880 --> 00:02:42,490
Right from your system.

45
00:02:42,490 --> 00:02:46,600
And, and that's what most of think
about when we think of software, right?

46
00:02:46,600 --> 00:02:48,260
But in today's world,
there's a few other types.

47
00:02:49,930 --> 00:02:52,340
For example, there's mobile applications.

48
00:02:52,340 --> 00:02:56,180
We might have a smartphone or a tablet.

49
00:02:56,180 --> 00:02:58,620
And those things come with
very few applications on it.

50
00:02:58,620 --> 00:03:02,880
They usually have a PDA, like Personal
Digital Assistant stuff, a calendar,

51
00:03:02,880 --> 00:03:05,470
a to-do list, a clock, that kind of thing.

52
00:03:05,470 --> 00:03:11,375
But you might want something else on there
a specialized web browser or for me, I,

53
00:03:11,375 --> 00:03:16,305
I read constantly and so I have a program
that I use to read e-books and I have

54
00:03:16,305 --> 00:03:20,247
another program that reads out loud to me,
so I can listen while I'm in the car.

55
00:03:20,247 --> 00:03:22,507
That doesn't mean come built
into my mobile devices.

56
00:03:22,507 --> 00:03:25,707
I had to get that application,
I had to get that software to use it.

57
00:03:25,707 --> 00:03:28,777
But that's different than the software
I might run on the desktop.

58
00:03:28,777 --> 00:03:29,797
They're not compatible,

59
00:03:29,797 --> 00:03:33,677
I have to get different applications
to do that same thing from my desktop.

60
00:03:33,677 --> 00:03:36,757
But I don't need something that can
read aloud to me on my desktop,

61
00:03:36,757 --> 00:03:38,677
because I could just look at it and
watch it.

62
00:03:38,677 --> 00:03:41,687
I need something to read aloud to me on
my phone because I use it in the car and

63
00:03:41,687 --> 00:03:44,560
I don't wanna look at my
phone while I'm driving.

64
00:03:44,560 --> 00:03:46,010
That's a great way to have a bad day.

65
00:03:47,440 --> 00:03:50,838
>> We also have what we call
web-based applications too.

66
00:03:50,838 --> 00:03:53,330
Web-based applications allow us to,

67
00:03:53,330 --> 00:03:57,200
to not have to worry about really
a lot of hardware requirements.

68
00:03:57,200 --> 00:04:00,170
All we need is the web browser
to be able to connect and

69
00:04:00,170 --> 00:04:02,080
to be able to find
information that we need.

70
00:04:02,080 --> 00:04:04,960
And to be able to have some of
the different things that we want

71
00:04:04,960 --> 00:04:08,740
without having a lot of, of hefty hardware
requirements at, at one end or, or

72
00:04:08,740 --> 00:04:10,320
at least at our end.

73
00:04:10,320 --> 00:04:13,940
So that what we do is we off load
everything back up to whatever device that

74
00:04:13,940 --> 00:04:14,590
we're connecting to.

75
00:04:14,590 --> 00:04:16,390
And this makes it very easy.

76
00:04:16,390 --> 00:04:20,940
Cause now we can control what, what our
company wants to release out there.

77
00:04:20,940 --> 00:04:23,930
And we can only give a portal for
people to access.

78
00:04:23,930 --> 00:04:26,770
>> Web based software is
really the way of the future.

79
00:04:26,770 --> 00:04:29,940
And so you're seeing many, many companies
move their software over to web based.

80
00:04:29,940 --> 00:04:31,330
It has a lot of advantages to it.

81
00:04:31,330 --> 00:04:32,020
All right.

82
00:04:32,020 --> 00:04:34,480
Let me, let me give you
an example with me and email.

83
00:04:34,480 --> 00:04:37,850
So for
years I used email software on my laptop.

84
00:04:37,850 --> 00:04:41,142
And so when I was on my laptop, I could
fire up my software, get into my email,

85
00:04:41,142 --> 00:04:42,727
do my responses, and so on, right?

86
00:04:42,727 --> 00:04:46,090
But as an IT worker I,
I jump around computers a lot.

87
00:04:47,250 --> 00:04:50,350
So I might not be at my computer,
I might be at somebody else's, and

88
00:04:50,350 --> 00:04:52,970
if I'm at their computer,
I can't get into my email.

89
00:04:52,970 --> 00:04:54,600
They might not have
the client that I have,

90
00:04:54,600 --> 00:04:56,560
they might not have that same software.

91
00:04:56,560 --> 00:04:59,730
So that's a bit of a headache is I have
to have that software available on

92
00:04:59,730 --> 00:05:01,800
any machine that I might use.

93
00:05:01,800 --> 00:05:04,720
The other thing is the data is
stored right there on my computer.

94
00:05:04,720 --> 00:05:06,740
So if my computer has
a hard drive crash and

95
00:05:06,740 --> 00:05:09,415
I loose all my data I just
lost all my old email, right?

96
00:05:09,415 --> 00:05:13,000
That's, that's a problem with software
we install on our own machine.

97
00:05:13,000 --> 00:05:16,310
So several years ago I
switched to web based email.

98
00:05:16,310 --> 00:05:19,760
So now all my email is hosted
out there in the Cloud.

99
00:05:19,760 --> 00:05:20,430
Right.

100
00:05:20,430 --> 00:05:22,000
So I use Google Apps.

101
00:05:22,000 --> 00:05:23,790
So it's all there hosted at Google.

102
00:05:23,790 --> 00:05:28,070
The cool thing here is, I can sit down
at any computer in the entire world and

103
00:05:28,070 --> 00:05:31,340
I can log in to my web based
Google Apps account and check my email,

104
00:05:31,340 --> 00:05:34,860
and it's the same experience no
matter what computer I'm on.

105
00:05:34,860 --> 00:05:36,410
And I don't care what
operating system I'm on.

106
00:05:36,410 --> 00:05:40,340
I can be on Linux, Windows, Mac,
whatever, it's the same mailbox.

107
00:05:40,340 --> 00:05:41,940
And if my computer crashes and

108
00:05:41,940 --> 00:05:46,300
I lose the hard drive, big deal my
data's up there at Google, right?

109
00:05:46,300 --> 00:05:47,850
So they're the ones that are hosting that.

110
00:05:47,850 --> 00:05:52,840
So that really does create a lot of
benefits, a lot of good things for

111
00:05:52,840 --> 00:05:53,550
you the end user.

112
00:05:53,550 --> 00:05:54,565
Now the only negative is,

113
00:05:54,565 --> 00:05:58,260
if my internet connection goes down,
I can't get to my email.

114
00:05:58,260 --> 00:05:58,890
Right?

115
00:05:58,890 --> 00:06:02,630
And with email maybe that's not such a big
deal but if you depend on the internet

116
00:06:02,630 --> 00:06:05,920
access and it fails web-based
applications aren't so great.

117
00:06:05,920 --> 00:06:08,980
And so that's an area where
some people still like to have

118
00:06:08,980 --> 00:06:11,610
the local software to run
right on their machine.

119
00:06:11,610 --> 00:06:13,200
But it's really getting split 50/50 now.

120
00:06:13,200 --> 00:06:16,640
You're seeing a lot of vendors where
they're offering their software in

121
00:06:16,640 --> 00:06:18,030
more than one form.

122
00:06:18,030 --> 00:06:20,800
So as we run down this list of
the different types of software,

123
00:06:20,800 --> 00:06:24,090
just understand that it might not be
installed right there on your machine.

124
00:06:24,090 --> 00:06:25,700
It might be a web-based solution.

125
00:06:27,140 --> 00:06:29,860
>> So, every platform has
a little bit of different

126
00:06:29,860 --> 00:06:31,470
things that we have to be able to cover.

127
00:06:31,470 --> 00:06:34,510
So on my screen, I've went ahead and
created a little diagram so

128
00:06:34,510 --> 00:06:38,200
that we can review what we've
just talked about very easily.

129
00:06:38,200 --> 00:06:41,940
So remember that if you are going
to be on a mobile device.

130
00:06:41,940 --> 00:06:45,310
A lot of times, your applications
that you'll install on that device

131
00:06:45,310 --> 00:06:48,510
is gonna come from one of the stores,
whether it's the Windows store, or

132
00:06:48,510 --> 00:06:51,610
the app store, or the,
the Google Play store.

133
00:06:51,610 --> 00:06:53,450
It's gonna come from one of those stores.

134
00:06:53,450 --> 00:06:56,500
Most of us, I'm not gonna say everybody,
but most of us are probably not gonna

135
00:06:56,500 --> 00:07:00,878
download the APK or, or, or anything
like that to, to be able to do so.

136
00:07:00,878 --> 00:07:04,990
Usually, those applications are not
designed for high power usage.

137
00:07:04,990 --> 00:07:06,080
Fairly lightweight.

138
00:07:06,080 --> 00:07:08,880
It gives us the real
functionality that we want.

139
00:07:08,880 --> 00:07:12,620
But maybe not all the bells and
whistles that we might actually need.

140

01:17:04,150 --> 01:17:09,080
Tar just archives, doesn't make
your data any smaller, all right?

1544
01:17:09,080 --> 01:17:12,360
And then lastly, Zip is the most popular.

1545
01:17:12,360 --> 01:17:14,600
It's gonna get you the best compatibility.

1546
01:17:14,600 --> 01:17:16,980
It gets pretty good compression rates,
right?

1547
01:17:16,980 --> 01:17:21,850
It's not the greatest, but it's, it's good
enough and it, it's supported darn near

1548
01:17:21,850 --> 01:17:25,680
every where, so that's gonna be the main
one that you put to use, all right?

1549
01:17:25,680 --> 01:17:28,090
But if you see an exam question that says,

1550
01:17:28,090 --> 01:17:31,680
you got some data that you want to
occupy less space on the hard drive,

1551
01:17:31,680 --> 01:17:35,270
which of the following formats would
achieve that, and you see a selection.

1552
01:17:35,270 --> 01:17:37,660
You need to be able to identify
which ones compress and

1553
01:17:37,660 --> 01:17:40,010
which ones don't,
which ones meet your needs.

1554
01:17:41,640 --> 01:17:44,360
All right, so
those are our compression formats.

1555
01:17:44,360 --> 01:17:46,310
I know it's a lot to handle, so you,

1556
01:17:46,310 --> 01:17:48,520
you know might wanna review
this a few Few times.

1557
01:17:48,520 --> 01:17:49,830
And we'll post our show notes.

1558
01:17:49,830 --> 01:17:51,630
You know, Ronnie and
I have our little, like,

1559
01:17:51,630 --> 01:17:52,970
our little cheat sheet off to the side.

1560
01:17:52,970 --> 01:17:55,250
So we don't forget which ones are,
are in which category.

1561
01:17:55,250 --> 01:17:57,010
But we'll,
we'll post this with the episode, too.

1562
01:17:57,010 --> 01:17:58,540
So you'll have it kinda written out.

1563
01:17:58,540 --> 01:18:00,292
Definitely something to
review before the exam.

1564
01:18:00,292 --> 01:18:04,930
All right, all right Rickie, think of
anything that we need to add to that?

1565
01:18:04,930 --> 01:18:05,830
That was quite a bit.

1566
01:18:05,830 --> 01:18:10,190
>> No there's I didn't even know there
were that many file formats to tell you

1567
01:18:10,190 --> 01:18:11,090
the truth.

1568
01:18:11,090 --> 01:18:14,632
There's a far cry more.

1569

1570

this is probably a pretty good spot for
us to wrap up the show so let's

episodes.title: Software Management
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,883 --> 00:00:36,855
All right good morning,
good afternoon and good evening and

3
00:00:36,855 --> 00:00:39,081
welcome back to another
episode of IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:39,081 --> 00:00:41,851
I'm your host Don Pezet and
back to you, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:41,851 --> 00:00:42,660
How's it going, Ronnie?

6
00:00:42,660 --> 00:00:43,720
>> It is going well.

7
00:00:43,720 --> 00:00:47,400
Ready for another exciting episode
into the realm of IT fundamentals.

8
00:00:47,400 --> 00:00:50,918
So we are getting ready to
tackle some operating system and

9
00:00:50,918 --> 00:00:53,600
software best practices.

10
00:00:53,600 --> 00:00:56,200
>> Yeah, so objective 1.3,
that's what we're jumping into,

11
00:00:56,200 --> 00:01:01,040
the the full one is given a scenario,
use software management best practices.

12
00:01:01,040 --> 00:01:05,580
And what we're really talking about
here are some of the standard

13
00:01:05,580 --> 00:01:09,690
things we need to remember when it comes
to adding software to our computer and

14
00:01:09,690 --> 00:01:12,070
removing software from our computer.

15
00:01:12,070 --> 00:01:15,340
And there's a lot of stuff that people
kinda lose sight of when we do this.

16
00:01:15,340 --> 00:01:19,440
So, it's important to make sure that you
follow some standard best practices,

17
00:01:19,440 --> 00:01:22,135
and that's what we're
gonna take a look at.

18
00:01:22,135 --> 00:01:25,169
So, let's go with the very beginning,
which is just installing software.

19
00:01:26,190 --> 00:01:30,330
If we want to get software installed onto
our machine, it means that we want to

20
00:01:30,330 --> 00:01:33,410
get our computer to do something that
the base operating system won't do.

21
00:01:33,410 --> 00:01:36,960
So, when you got a Windows machine,
or a Mac OS machine, or

22
00:01:36,960 --> 00:01:41,378
a whatever, it can do a lot of
stuff with just what's included.

23
00:01:41,378 --> 00:01:43,870
But there's times when you need
something that's different,

24
00:01:43,870 --> 00:01:46,080
something that's beyond
what's build into it.

25
00:01:46,080 --> 00:01:48,150
And so, you've got to go in and
install software.

26
00:01:48,150 --> 00:01:53,540
Now where do we get that software from?

27
00:01:53,540 --> 00:01:57,260
>> There's multiple ways that we
can get software on our computer.

28
00:01:57,260 --> 00:01:59,870
A lot of times today most
of us will go out there and

29
00:01:59,870 --> 00:02:02,370
download the software that we want.

30
00:02:02,370 --> 00:02:05,630
And a lot of times you'll actually
just purchase it right online.

31
00:02:05,630 --> 00:02:08,470
You'll download the software and
they'll also send you what we normally

32
00:02:08,470 --> 00:02:13,580
call a product key, or some type of
licensing that you'll also have to have.

33
00:02:13,580 --> 00:02:17,130
So that's usually the way
we see it most often today.

34
00:02:17,130 --> 00:02:20,770
But it used to be, where well Don and
I might have to head out to one

35
00:02:20,770 --> 00:02:25,590
of those brick and mortar stores like Best
Buy or, or some other location like that,

36
00:02:25,590 --> 00:02:28,530
RadioShack or, or
whoever was selling software.

37
00:02:28,530 --> 00:02:31,300
And then you'd purchase it'd and come in
this nice big box that would have one disc

38
00:02:31,300 --> 00:02:35,550
in it, and you'd go ahead and
install it from the media there, too.

39
00:02:35,550 --> 00:02:38,530
>> And now one of the challenges we
have with our modern model which is you

40
00:02:38,530 --> 00:02:41,490
go out to a company's website,
you find the software and you install it.

41
00:02:41,490 --> 00:02:44,959
Is that, this might be new software
that you just found that you don't know

42
00:02:44,959 --> 00:02:45,577
a lot about.

43
00:02:45,577 --> 00:02:49,072
And when you go to that website, how do
you know that it's a trustworthy source?

44
00:02:49,072 --> 00:02:50,980
And that's a real challenge.

45
00:02:50,980 --> 00:02:53,840
Because when you do a search for
things out on Google or wherever.

46
00:02:53,840 --> 00:02:57,140
If you come up with an idea for some kinda
software that you need, and you go and

47
00:02:57,140 --> 00:02:58,440
do a search.

48
00:02:58,440 --> 00:03:02,050
You get search results, but how do you
know which companies are reputable and

49
00:03:02,050 --> 00:03:02,730
which ones aren't?

50
00:03:02,730 --> 00:03:06,451
And there are sites that kinda prey
on this specifically, sites like,

51
00:03:06,451 --> 00:03:08,460
what's the one that always comes in?

52
00:03:08,460 --> 00:03:09,670
Softonic, or something.

53
00:03:09,670 --> 00:03:11,120
>> Yeah.
>> Here, let's do an example.

54
00:03:11,120 --> 00:03:14,560
Here, I'm gonna,
I'm gonna fire up a web browser, and,

55
00:03:14,560 --> 00:03:17,540
let's say that I need software that can

56
00:03:19,750 --> 00:03:24,280
maybe I've got a bunch of audio files,
and I want to convert wav files into mp3.

57
00:03:25,720 --> 00:03:28,716
So I want some software that can do that,
so

58
00:03:28,716 --> 00:03:32,141
I might do a search that
says convert wav to mp3.

59
00:03:32,141 --> 00:03:34,372
And I'm going to start
getting some responses back,

60
00:03:34,372 --> 00:03:36,140
and the very first one here is medio.io.

61
00:03:36,140 --> 00:03:38,095
They've got an online audio converter.

62
00:03:38,095 --> 00:03:40,689
We got audioformat.com.

63
00:03:40,689 --> 00:03:44,730
I've never heard of any of these
companies, zamzar.com, and so on.

64
00:03:44,730 --> 00:03:48,410
Now, those might be perfectly
legitimate companies.

65
00:03:48,410 --> 00:03:49,300
I dunno.

66
00:03:49,300 --> 00:03:52,787
You might go to those companies though and
they might not be on the up and up.

67
00:03:52,787 --> 00:03:56,150
And when you install that software
it might be carrying a lot of other

68
00:03:56,150 --> 00:03:57,260
things with it.

69
00:03:57,260 --> 00:04:02,540
We call that, not necessarily malware,
but normally spyware or adware.

70
00:04:02,540 --> 00:04:05,240
Where it'll add a toolbar
to your web browser,

71
00:04:05,240 --> 00:04:07,210
display advertisements on your computer.

72
00:04:07,210 --> 00:04:10,360
Any time you see free software
on the internet you need to be

73
00:04:10,360 --> 00:04:11,020
careful about that.

74
00:04:11,020 --> 00:04:13,577
Because often it's going to
lead to that kinda thing.

75
00:04:13,577 --> 00:04:16,550
That you will get advertisements and
stuff.

76
00:04:16,550 --> 00:04:22,340
There's also companies like CNET,
which aggregates software.

77
00:04:22,340 --> 00:04:25,010
So, the software might be
written by a developer and

78
00:04:25,010 --> 00:04:26,961
it might be hosted on their site even.

79
00:04:26,961 --> 00:04:28,957
But it's also copied over to CNET.

80
00:04:28,957 --> 00:04:31,133
And the problem with sites like that is,

81
00:04:31,133 --> 00:04:35,360
first off, you don't know if it's
the newest version of the software or not.

82
00:04:35,360 --> 00:04:38,420
It might be outdated from what
the vendor is actually deploying.

83
00:04:38,420 --> 00:04:42,060
And secondly,
a lot of these file aggregation sites

84
00:04:42,060 --> 00:04:45,400
add stuff to the software to pay for
the bandwidth that they use.

85
00:04:45,400 --> 00:04:47,410
And so, you're not necessarily
getting a clean download.

86
00:04:47,410 --> 00:04:49,020
So rule number one for

87
00:04:49,020 --> 00:04:54,310
installing software is you need to
get it from a trustworthy source.

88
00:04:54,310 --> 00:04:58,170
If this is the first time you've heard
of that web page don't just download and

89
00:04:58,170 --> 00:04:59,360
install whatever they offer you.

90
00:04:59,360 --> 00:05:01,354
You don't know what's gonna happen.

91
00:05:01,354 --> 00:05:03,524
And beware.

92
00:05:03,524 --> 00:05:05,703
Any time you deal with sites like CNET,

93
00:05:05,703 --> 00:05:11,490
SourceForge there's another one I'm sure
it'll be here in the top links somewhere.

94
00:05:11,490 --> 00:05:13,750
There's one,
it's called like Softonic, and

95
00:05:13,750 --> 00:05:17,215
there's one that's like
Software Encyclopedia or something.

96
00:05:17,215 --> 00:05:21,965
And I always come across them
when I search for programs.

97
00:05:21,965 --> 00:05:23,895
And of course you know now
that I do it live on the show,

98
00:05:23,895 --> 00:05:25,693
I'm not gonna get a single result on em.

99
00:05:25,693 --> 00:05:27,475
>> Softonic sounds right, though.

100
00:05:27,475 --> 00:05:29,095
>> Yeah it's oh there
>> There it is.

101
00:05:29,095 --> 00:05:30,570
>> Softonic that is one of them.

102
00:05:30,570 --> 00:05:32,580
And so here,
I'm starting to get these links, and

103
00:05:32,580 --> 00:05:35,150
see how it's; full version, free software.

104
00:05:35,150 --> 00:05:37,210
I'm like; wow, it's free and
you get the whole thing.

105
00:05:37,210 --> 00:05:41,010
Well, that's great, but they've normally
modified it to add stuff onto it.

106
00:05:41,010 --> 00:05:43,160
So, you have to be careful with those.

107
00:05:43,160 --> 00:05:45,720
Always get your software
from a trustworthy source.

108
00:05:45,720 --> 00:05:47,170
That's rule number one.

109
00:05:47,170 --> 00:05:50,920
If you bought the software and
they sent you a CD, then it's pretty safe.

110
00:05:50,920 --> 00:05:54,360
If you're downloading it from a website
make sure you're getting it from that

111
00:05:54,360 --> 00:05:56,870
original vendor.

112
00:05:56,870 --> 00:05:59,860
And it pains me to say sites
like SourceForge, cuz for

113
00:05:59,860 --> 00:06:03,820
the longest time SourceForge used to be
like the safe place to go and get stuff.

114
00:06:03,820 --> 00:06:06,956
But they've really been doing
some bad things the last year.

115
00:06:06,956 --> 00:06:10,810
So even some of the trustworthy sites
become untrustworthy over time.

116
00:06:10,810 --> 00:06:12,230
We have got to watch out.

117
00:06:12,230 --> 00:06:15,240
>> And there's a lot of us that
sit there and go; look, its free.

118
00:06:15,240 --> 00:06:19,120
We'll deal with some of this stuff that
they end up putting on the computers.

119
00:06:19,120 --> 00:06:21,970
But the problem is,
we tend to click through the install so

120
00:06:21,970 --> 00:06:25,780
fast we don't see what they add in in
the installer that they've put in.

121
00:06:25,780 --> 00:06:29,230
And so, all of a sudden, you have more
than you realize on a computer, and

122
00:06:29,230 --> 00:06:32,150
it takes a lot longer for
you to figure out what they've done.

123
00:06:32,150 --> 00:06:33,910
Rather than for
you to build a used product.

124
00:06:33,910 --> 00:06:35,560
And that's where the work
becomes a little bit more,

125
00:06:36,820 --> 00:06:38,980
on the side in which you're like,
are you joking,

126
00:06:38,980 --> 00:06:42,790
have to do all this everything I launch
the program, before I can use it?

127
00:06:42,790 --> 00:06:43,560
Yes, you do.

128
00:06:43,560 --> 00:06:46,172
>> Yeah, and some of the vendors
are trying to fix this,

129
00:06:46,172 --> 00:06:48,855
some of the operating systems
by offering app stores.

130
00:06:48,855 --> 00:06:52,690
So for example if you’re on Mac OS you
can fire up the Mac OS App Store and

131
00:06:52,690 --> 00:06:56,830
you can view a curated list that Apple
has gone through and cleaned up.

132
00:06:56,830 --> 00:06:59,180
To make sure that there is no
malicious software in there or

133
00:06:59,180 --> 00:07:01,640
software that is doing
things it shouldn’t.

134
00:07:01,640 --> 00:07:05,010
So that’s good in a way, you've got
this kinda safe zone that you can go and

135
00:07:05,010 --> 00:07:06,240
get software from.

136
00:07:06,240 --> 00:07:09,490
But it’s bad in a way in that not every
developer lists their software there.

137
00:07:09,490 --> 00:07:12,820
So you might want something
like Adobe Photoshop and,

138
00:07:12,820 --> 00:07:14,950
it's not in the Mac OS App Store.

139
00:07:14,950 --> 00:07:17,510
So you have to go and
get that from Adobe directly.

140
00:07:17,510 --> 00:07:19,600
Microsoft's doing the same
thing with the Windows,

141
00:07:19,600 --> 00:07:22,370
they don't call it the Windows app store,
it's just the Windows store.

142
00:07:22,370 --> 00:07:24,840
And you can go in, and
purchase apps there.

143
00:07:24,840 --> 00:07:27,330
But again,
not every developer is listed in there, so

144
00:07:27,330 --> 00:07:30,180
the stores aren't quite where
they need to be just yet.

145
00:07:30,180 --> 00:07:31,590
In the future we'll see that change.

146
00:07:32,750 --> 00:07:35,880
Now when you go and
download a file to install.

147
00:07:35,880 --> 00:07:37,250
You're installing that operating system,

148
00:07:37,250 --> 00:07:40,890
and if we're getting it from the orignal
vendor, then it's usually pretty safe.

149
00:07:40,890 --> 00:07:43,060
As long as it's a vendor we trust,
somebody we've heard of,

150
00:07:43,060 --> 00:07:46,260
not somebody we just found
randomly on a Google search.

151
00:07:46,260 --> 00:07:48,250
If it's random,
you just need to do your research.

152
00:07:48,250 --> 00:07:49,573
Is that a legitimate developer?

153
00:07:49,573 --> 00:07:51,733
Is it somebody that other
people have worked with before?

154
00:07:51,733 --> 00:07:53,869
Is it someone you can trust?

155
00:07:53,869 --> 00:07:57,589
When it comes to doing the install
>> There are some technologies there

156
00:07:57,589 --> 00:07:58,281
that can help.

157
00:07:58,281 --> 00:08:01,851
A lot of vendors have started doing what's
called digitally signed installers.

158
00:08:01,851 --> 00:08:05,738
And that's where they have the installer
for their software, the file you download

159
00:08:05,738 --> 00:08:08,765
to install and they've digitally
signed it with a certificate.

160
00:08:08,765 --> 00:08:14,715
And the nice part about that is if
another company like SourceForge.

161
00:08:14,715 --> 00:08:19,430
If they tacking on their software on top
of it, the certificate is no longer valid.

162
00:08:19,430 --> 00:08:22,054
And so when you go to to install,
you'll get a warning about that.

163
00:08:22,054 --> 00:08:22,570
Right?

164
00:08:22,570 --> 00:08:25,350
So now you have kind of
a visual queue that let's you

165
00:08:25,350 --> 00:08:27,873
know that this software is no longer safe,
but

166
00:08:27,873 --> 00:08:31,636
the problem with the digital signing
piece is not everybody does it.

167
00:08:31,636 --> 00:08:34,692
Everything they update their software,
they need to resign it with that

168
00:08:34,692 --> 00:08:37,113
certificate and some vendors do,
some vendors don't.

169
00:08:37,113 --> 00:08:39,516
So you can't always rely on that.

170
00:08:39,516 --> 00:08:41,478
That really makes things
challenging to it.

171
00:08:41,478 --> 00:08:44,073
All right.

172
00:08:44,073 --> 00:08:45,553
So when we go to download and install,

173
00:08:45,553 --> 00:08:48,025
the installation process itself
is pretty straightforward.

174
00:08:48,025 --> 00:08:51,276
It is different though on
different operating systems.

175
00:08:51,276 --> 00:08:55,308
So we wanna show you some examples on
a Windows machine, as well as on a Mac.

176
00:08:55,308 --> 00:08:56,637
You wanna go first?

177
00:08:56,637 --> 00:08:57,588
>> Sure.
>> You wanna start with Windows?

178
00:08:57,588 --> 00:09:00,925
>> Yeah, so I've got a Windows 7
machine launched up and ready to go.

>> Yeah,
Dell makes bad choices on that one.

00:47:41,520 --> 00:47:43,320
But it is more intuitive
doing it on the screen.

981
00:47:43,320 --> 00:47:44,360
>> Oh yeah, right there.

982
00:47:44,360 --> 00:47:45,360
>> Because it's like your pinching in and

983
00:47:45,360 --> 00:47:48,890

984
00:47:48,890 --> 00:47:51,740
On a tablet or
phone you'd be doing it on that device.

985
00:47:51,740 --> 00:47:53,885
The other one they call out is kinetics.

986
00:47:53,885 --> 00:47:55,579
And kinetics I think are really cool and

987
00:47:55,579 --> 00:47:58,978
we are starting to see some of this evolve
mostly in the video gaming industry.

988
00:47:58,978 --> 00:48:01,989
Not so much in the regular
business computing yet.

989
00:48:01,989 --> 00:48:05,900
With Kinetics, you're doing gestures, but
without touching the computer, all right.

990
00:48:06,920 --> 00:48:10,590
It's where you have physical gestures that
you do, and they can be very complex or

991
00:48:10,590 --> 00:48:11,940
they can be very simple.

992
00:48:11,940 --> 00:48:15,280
For example, maybe you're watching
a video on your computer.

993
00:48:15,280 --> 00:48:19,750
Your computer can be tracking your video
move, your body movements, and if you get

994
00:48:19,750 --> 00:48:23,640
up and walk away to go to the restroom,
it can see that and pause the video.

995
00:48:23,640 --> 00:48:24,640
That's Kinetics.

996
00:48:24,640 --> 00:48:28,010
You didn't touch the computer to do it,
it knew to do it because you walked away.

997
00:48:28,010 --> 00:48:33,460
One of the best examples of
that is the Microsoft Kinect,

998
00:48:33,460 --> 00:48:35,238
and let me just pull up their website.

999
00:48:35,238 --> 00:48:39,416
Microsoft Kinect, which they originally
released for the Xbox 360, for

1000
00:48:39,416 --> 00:48:40,193
video games.

1001
00:48:40,193 --> 00:48:42,695
And the idea was that you would
hook it up to your Xbox, and

1002
00:48:42,695 --> 00:48:45,719
if you played a game where you're on
a boat, you would stand there and

1003
00:48:45,719 --> 00:48:48,847
pretend like you were paddling and
it would watch you and say, oh look,

1004
00:48:48,847 --> 00:48:51,120
he's making the hand gestures,
he's paddling.

1005
00:48:52,310 --> 00:48:55,510
And it was this big sensor bar,
it's got a camera and a sensor, and

1006
00:48:55,510 --> 00:48:57,810
it would sit on top of your computer, and

1007
00:48:57,810 --> 00:49:02,210
it would basically just track your
movements and take actions based on that.

1008
00:49:02,210 --> 00:49:02,930
So that's what it did.

1009
00:49:02,930 --> 00:49:07,930
Well, it's made the jump,
from video gaming over to computers, and

1010
00:49:07,930 --> 00:49:12,019
so now, they make it where you can hook it
up to a Windows machine, to your desktop,

1011
00:49:12,019 --> 00:49:15,307
and developers can use
the software development kit,

1012
00:49:15,307 --> 00:49:19,250
SDK, to create physical motion
gestures for their software.

1013
00:49:19,250 --> 00:49:22,000
And so now we're seeing things like,
instead of doing a three

1014
00:49:22,000 --> 00:49:26,540
finger swipe to change my screen, I can
actually just go like this in the air.

1015
00:49:26,540 --> 00:49:27,550
You go like this in the air, and

1016
00:49:27,550 --> 00:49:30,770
it sees you make that motion and
it knows to move the screen over.

1017
00:49:30,770 --> 00:49:32,700
Or if you want to make something bigger or
smaller,

1018
00:49:32,700 --> 00:49:35,760
you go like this with your hands and
it sees you do that.

1019
00:49:35,760 --> 00:49:39,300
It's like that movie Minority Report
with terrible Tom Cruise, and

1020
00:49:39,300 --> 00:49:42,320
he's doing all this stuff in the air,
that's what Kinect does.

1021
00:49:42,320 --> 00:49:46,490
You don't touch the computer, you're doing
physical motions and there's pros and

1022
00:49:46,490 --> 00:49:47,130
cons of that.

1023
00:49:47,130 --> 00:49:50,950
The movements are usually far less
efficient cuz they're bigger motions.

1024
00:49:50,950 --> 00:49:54,200
You have to have certain lighting present
for it to work, if it's a dim room,

1025
00:49:54,200 --> 00:49:55,660
it doesn't work very well.

1026
00:49:55,660 --> 00:50:00,000
But on a positive side, you're doing
physical motion, which really helps out

1027
00:50:00,000 --> 00:50:05,360
with a lot of the problems that we
develop by sitting in an office chair for

1028
00:50:05,360 --> 00:50:08,300
hours on end every day,
it shortens your lifespan.

1029
00:50:08,300 --> 00:50:11,680
So, this helps to get you a little more
mobile, and a little more healthy.

1030
00:50:11,680 --> 00:50:14,700
So definitely some side benefits there.

1031
00:50:14,700 --> 00:50:16,360
But this stuff is really cool.

1032
00:50:16,360 --> 00:50:21,754
Kinetics can take other forms too,
like there are projected keyboards,

1033
00:50:21,754 --> 00:50:26,974
let me see if I can find one of those,
where if you're using a computer,

1034
00:50:26,974 --> 00:50:31,585
that doesn't have a big keyboard

1035
00:50:31,585 --> 00:50:35,067
here they're showing
this little cell phone.

1036
00:50:35,067 --> 00:50:39,306
And you want to type a message, they make
these devices that'll actually protect,

1037
00:50:39,306 --> 00:50:42,469
project a picture of a keyboard,
and you start typing just like

1038
00:50:42,469 --> 00:50:47,162
you're using a real keyboard, and it's
sensing where your fingers are going down.

1039
00:50:47,162 --> 00:50:51,280
That's kinetics, you're not actually
touching the device, you're doing motions.

1040
00:50:51,280 --> 00:50:54,290
The projection here is just so
you know where to put your fingers, and

1041
00:50:54,290 --> 00:50:56,980
then it's able to go and type that, so.

1042
00:50:56,980 --> 00:50:58,380
Do we have a bigger picture?

1043
00:51:00,400 --> 00:51:03,170
I guess that's about as big as it's gonna
get, but this is the projector, and

1044
00:51:03,170 --> 00:51:06,240
they've got it tied to their iPhone there,
so they're typing on a table.

1045
00:51:06,240 --> 00:51:10,250
This kind of stuff is neat,
it's not terribly expensive.

1046
00:51:10,250 --> 00:51:12,000
That I think was $100,
is that what it said?

1047
00:51:12,000 --> 00:51:13,060
>> Yeah I think 99.

1048
00:51:13,060 --> 00:51:13,800
>> Yep.

1049
00:51:13,800 --> 00:51:17,000
And the prices are coming down on
this stuff, so we'll see more and

1050
00:51:17,000 --> 00:51:20,220
more of this introduced in
equipment as time progresses.

1051
00:51:20,220 --> 00:51:22,920
But for right now, this is very
much an alternative technology.

1052
00:51:22,920 --> 00:51:27,050
Most people do not have kinetic

1053

Amazon did it with their cellphone, right?

1054

That, what was it called,

What was their phone called?

>> I know it's only for

>> Yeah.
Here, let me show you guys this thing,

the Amazon Fire Phone.

It's got a camera right here,

1065

And what it does if you tilt your phone,

1067
00:52:04,320 --> 00:52:08,740

1068
00:52:08,740 --> 00:52:13,580
So even if you're looking at it at
an angle, it'll look properly aligned.

1069
00:52:13,580 --> 00:52:15,225
>> Nice.
>> So you get better visibility out of it.

1070
00:52:15,225 --> 00:52:18,910
It's a neat idea,
it is as gimmicky as all hell.

1071

It's sorta a marketing thing, but like

>> The reviews aren't great.

>> ON contract, so

You can expect this.

Early adopters always get
a rough experience, but

1078

you'll probably see more of

1079

Samsung, they had some interesting stuff,

I think on my phone,

1094

1095

And it will take a while,
to evolve for general use.

1096

1097
00:53:17,530 --> 00:53:20,520
That doesn't mean a keyboard is the best
way to get text into your computer.

1098
00:53:20,520 --> 00:53:22,180

1099
00:53:22,180 --> 00:53:26,583
And so when something better comes along,
like speech detect or something like that,

1100
00:53:26,583 --> 00:53:28,531
it takes a little while to be adopted.

1101
00:53:28,531 --> 00:53:33,135
So these are flagged as alternative
technologies until they become standard

1102

components in an average computer
that you buy off the shelf.

1103

All right, so Ronnie,

>> I don't think so, I think all
these alternative technologies now,

we're going to see in the next couple of
years are probably going to become so

1107

gonna consider them again.

1108

>> And these were all pretty safe ones.

1109

There are some that, that just come and
go, things like the Segway scooter.

That was an alternative technology

the Nintendo Power Glove

1112

sometimes people come up with ideas,

And so they go away, and

1114

So, that's definitely something that

technologies that come out.

1116

You just kind of have to wait and

>> Now this is gonna be a fun episode

computers.

And moving to mobile devices.

15
00:00:58.140 --> 00:01:01.845
And what we're really looking at our, our
CompTIA brands as a, a wireless device.

16
00:01:01.845 --> 00:01:06.350
So we're talking about cell phones and
iPads that don't have a home.

17
00:01:06.350 --> 00:01:11.450
That you, you're constantly taking various
places and they a, a little bit of a,

00:01:11.450 --> 00:01:16.130
a different, set of characteristics
than we would with a normal PC.

19
00:01:16.130 --> 00:01:17.090
All right.

20
00:01:17.090 --> 00:01:20.770
One of the big areas that we need to talk
about is security, and when you think

21
00:01:20.770 --> 00:01:25.960
about like a, a desktop PC, so if I
had a desktop PC sitting in a desk and

22
00:01:25.960 --> 00:01:30.810
in my office, I really don't have
to worry so much about losing it.

23
00:01:30.810 --> 00:01:31.850
I'm not gonna misplace it.

24
00:01:31.850 --> 00:01:35.670
It sits right on my desk and that's
where it is and that's the end of it.

25
00:01:35.670 --> 00:01:38.880
But if somebody broke in, they could,
in theory, you know, steal it and

26
00:01:38.880 --> 00:01:41.200
it would go, but it's pretty unlikely,
so for the most part,

27
00:01:41.200 --> 00:01:43.680
I'm always gonna know
where that desktop is.

28
00:01:43.680 --> 00:01:46.770
With a laptop,
sometimes I might travel with it.

29
00:01:46.770 --> 00:01:47.620
Sometimes I might not.

30
00:01:47.620 --> 00:01:50.640
And, and so when I'm traveling, yeah,

31
00:01:50.640 --> 00:01:53.800
there's a chance that I could lose
the device, but it's pretty big.

32
00:01:53.800 --> 00:01:57.140
It's pretty obvious when you
don't have your laptop with you.

33
00:01:57.140 --> 00:02:00.200
But when you talk about cell phones,
they're very small.

34
00:02:00.200 --> 00:02:02.960
We always carry them with us,

35
00:02:02.960 --> 00:02:06.920
the odds of us losing a cell phone
becomes much, much higher, all right?

36
00:02:06.920 --> 00:02:09.240
If you were to ask around
the people you know and say, hey,

37
00:02:09.240 --> 00:02:10.540
have you ever lost a laptop?

38
00:02:10.540 --> 00:02:12.320
Just forgotten where it was?

39
00:02:12.320 --> 00:02:13.825
Most people will say no, but

40
00:02:13.825 --> 00:02:16.584
if you ask for
people who have lost a cell phone that,

41
00:02:16.584 --> 00:02:20.634
that happens a lot, you know, [CROSSTALK]
enough that they sell insurance.

42
00:02:20.634 --> 00:02:22.597
>> Yeah, it's amazing where, when you,

00:02:22.597 --> 00:02:25.950
you go down to places like
Universal Studios or Disney World.

44
00:02:25.950 --> 00:02:30.175
These amusement parks, and how many of
these devices end up in lost and found.

45
00:02:30.175 --> 00:02:31.460
>> Mm-hm.
>> And that's because people will

46
00:02:31.460 --> 00:02:34.480
go on these high G-force rides and
actually put them in their pocket or

47
00:02:34.480 --> 00:02:35.060
their shirt pocket.

48
00:02:35.060 --> 00:02:35.600
>> Yeah.

49
00:02:35.600 --> 00:02:38.560
>> It just flies out and then, you know
they have to go and get it at some point.

50
00:02:38.560 --> 00:02:40.710
But it's amazing how many of
those devices do get lost.

51
00:02:40.710 --> 00:02:43.870
>> Yeah, you leave it on a bus, you leave
it in the back of a taxi cab or whatever,

52
00:02:43.870 --> 00:02:46.060
and, and
these are the things that can happen.

53
00:02:46.060 --> 00:02:49.110
Well, the problem is not so
much losing the device right that, that,

54
00:02:49.110 --> 00:02:50.000
that, that sucks.

55
00:02:50.000 --> 00:02:51.570
Nobody wants to lose their device.

56
00:02:51.570 --> 00:02:54.600
But what if you have sensitive
information on that device?

57
00:02:54.600 --> 00:02:57.440
These smartphones and
these tablets are very powerful.

58
00:02:57.440 --> 00:03:00.920
And they typically have access to
the same data as your computer at home or

59
00:03:00.920 --> 00:03:01.870
at your office.

60
00:03:01.870 --> 00:03:03.960
So you might have personal documents.

61
00:03:03.960 --> 00:03:05.950
You might have access to your work email.

62
00:03:05.950 --> 00:03:10.700
You might have a, a VPN tunnel set up
on there to connect to your work office

63
00:03:10.700 --> 00:03:12.390
on this device that you just lost.

64
00:03:12.390 --> 00:03:16.570
And if somebody gets a hold of that,
they could now have access to all of that.

65
00:03:16.570 --> 00:03:20.270
So there's various things we
need to do to secure the device.

66
00:03:20.270 --> 00:03:23.570
Now and I do think it's kind of funny
that, that CompTIA combines unlocking and
