991
00:47:35,590 --> 00:47:38,290
And if you attach your
phone to the computer,

992
00:47:38,290 --> 00:47:41,450
you can copy data to the phone or
from the phone.

993
00:47:41,450 --> 00:47:44,570
It'll show up as, well, like a USB key.

994
00:47:44,570 --> 00:47:45,160
Right?

995
00:47:45,160 --> 00:47:46,140
Well, a lot of them.

996
00:47:46,140 --> 00:47:47,630
The Android ones will
show us as a USB key.

997
00:47:47,630 --> 00:47:49,835
You can just copy data,
and it's no big deal.

998
00:47:49,835 --> 00:47:53,208
The iPhones, for those you've gotta use,
like, iTunes, or whatever.

999
00:47:53,208 --> 00:47:55,833
But you can copy data to them and
get data back off.

1000
00:47:55,833 --> 00:47:59,417
>> So those can be used for storage too,
but they all work the same way.

1001
00:47:59,417 --> 00:48:03,460
It's just media, we can copy
data to it and get it back out.

1002
00:48:03,460 --> 00:48:09,670
Now the very last entry that they have for
us here is a touchscreen display.

1003
00:48:09,670 --> 00:48:13,313
We've talked a little bit about
touchscreen displays in some of our other

1004
00:48:13,313 --> 00:48:17,554
segments, but a display, a monitor,
we've already said that's output, right?

1005
00:48:17,554 --> 00:48:21,340
We're getting video output, so we can
see what's going on in the computer.

1006
00:48:21,340 --> 00:48:26,445
But when we make it a touchscreen, now
we're touching it and we're sending input.

1007
00:48:26,445 --> 00:48:30,830
We're sending our signals into the device
to make it receive our signal and

1008
00:48:30,830 --> 00:48:32,509
start to do things, right?

1009
00:48:32,509 --> 00:48:35,486
So that is the,
the blurring of the lines and

1010
00:48:35,486 --> 00:48:41,080
you'll see a lot of computers these days
are starting to come with touchscreens.

1011
00:48:41,080 --> 00:48:44,230
If you buy a laptop,
it's usually an option, you know,

1012
00:48:44,230 --> 00:48:49,022
you can't replace the monitor on a laptop
or at least not in any reasonable form.

1013
00:48:49,022 --> 00:48:54,261
But but on a desktop, it's as simple
as going out and buying a new monitor.

1014
00:48:54,261 --> 00:48:58,160
So here is a 23 inch Acer monitor for
$350, it's got a touchscreen.

1015
00:48:59,180 --> 00:49:02,400
And the touchscreen really is just
a type of mouse, you know, i, i,

1016
00:49:02,400 --> 00:49:05,810
it's taking your finger and moving
the mouse cursor wherever your finger is.

1017
00:49:05,810 --> 00:49:08,950
So when you hook this up,
you'll have your regular monitor cable and

1018
00:49:08,950 --> 00:49:12,630
you'll usually have a USB cable also,
which is how interprets the touch and

1019
00:49:12,630 --> 00:49:15,140
brings it in and that's what I
did with my computer at home.

1020
00:49:15,140 --> 00:49:18,451
I just went and bought a monitor that
actually had touch support in it and

1021
00:49:18,451 --> 00:49:19,013
I got that.

1022
00:49:19,013 --> 00:49:20,994
And now, I don't use it, so
it was kind of a waste of money.

1023
00:49:20,994 --> 00:49:22,909
But if, if you like that, right?

1024
00:49:22,909 --> 00:49:26,291
You can, you're in business, but

1025
00:49:26,291 --> 00:49:30,930
that makes it both an input and
an output device.

1026
00:49:30,930 --> 00:49:31,603
All right.

1027
00:49:31,603 --> 00:49:34,735
And I was surprised they didn't
mention multifunction printers.

1028
00:49:34,735 --> 00:49:38,511
The multifunction printers are ones
where you've got a printer that also has

1029
00:49:38,511 --> 00:49:41,430
a scanner and copier on it and
those are input output.

1030
00:49:41,430 --> 00:49:44,264
They're input, cuz they have the scanner,
you can feed data in.

1031
00:49:44,264 --> 00:49:47,405
And their output, cuz they can print,
you get data out and

1032
00:49:47,405 --> 00:49:49,560
those are very common too.

1033
00:49:49,560 --> 00:49:51,005
I know a lot of people
aren't big fans of them,

1034
00:49:51,005 --> 00:49:54,330
cuz if one piece breaks the,
the whole thing kinda breaks, but but

1035
00:49:54,330 --> 00:49:56,630
they are fairly popular and
inexpensive these days.

1036
00:49:56,630 --> 00:49:59,426
>> Yeah, and that's the key is
the inexpensive part with so

1037
00:49:59,426 --> 00:50:03,166
many different functions, doesn't
take up as much desk, desktop space.

1038
00:50:03,166 --> 00:50:06,909
So, if you're not really into
needing it heavily all the time, but

1039
00:50:06,909 --> 00:50:10,193
just the occasional use for
copying and, and even faxing,

1040
00:50:10,193 --> 00:50:14,150
then you have all the devices right
there and you, they're on demand.

1041
00:50:15,890 --> 00:50:18,252
>> All right.
Well, I doubt we've covered any input and

1042
00:50:18,252 --> 00:50:20,550
output devices that were shocking and
new to you.

1043
00:50:20,550 --> 00:50:21,939
Right?
Most of these are pretty,

1044
00:50:21,939 --> 00:50:25,646
pretty run of the mill average things, but
these are the ones that are going to show

1045
00:50:25,646 --> 00:50:28,544
up on the exam, so we need to be
familiar with them and kind of know

1046
00:50:28,544 --> 00:50:32,500
the differences, so that we understand
when one is appropriate versus another.

1047
00:50:32,500 --> 00:50:35,785
So just keep that in mind as
you prepare to take the exam.

1048
00:50:35,785 --> 00:50:37,558
All right.
Well that's a pretty good spot for

1049
00:50:37,558 --> 00:50:39,560
us to wrap up, wrap up this objective.

1050
00:50:39,560 --> 00:50:42,911
Let me remind you guys, if you have
any questions, just let us know.

1051
00:50:42,911 --> 00:50:45,717
Live during the show,
you can go to itpro.tv/live and

1052
00:50:45,717 --> 00:50:47,936
you'll see the chat box beneath the video.

1053
00:50:47,936 --> 00:50:51,590
Post your questions there,
we monitor and answer during the show.

1054
00:50:51,590 --> 00:50:55,585
If you have questions after the show,
well, you can go to our Q and A forums.

1055
00:50:55,585 --> 00:50:58,485
At the top of every page
on the itpro.tv website,

1056
00:50:58,485 --> 00:51:00,585
you'll see a link that says, Q and A.

1057
00:51:00,585 --> 00:51:02,125
Click on it, it'll take you to the forums.

1058
00:51:02,125 --> 00:51:05,265
Post your questions there and
we monitor and answer after the show.

1059
00:51:06,285 --> 00:51:07,747
All right.
We wanna make sure you guys have all

1060
00:51:07,747 --> 00:51:10,525
the information you need to be successful,
so take advantage of that.

1061
00:51:10,525 --> 00:51:12,358
It is there for you.

1062
00:51:12,358 --> 00:51:13,938
Well, I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1063
00:51:13,938 --> 00:51:16,238
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

1064
00:51:16,238 --> 00:51:17,032
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1065
00:51:17,032 --> 00:51:18,886
>> And we will see you next time.

1066
00:51:18,886 --> 00:51:28,886
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Connector Types
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,424 --> 00:00:36,327
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening and

3
00:00:36,327 --> 00:00:38,425
welcome back to another
episode of IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:38,425 --> 00:00:40,885
I'm your host Don Pezent,
back with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:40,885 --> 00:00:41,570
How's it going, Ronnie?

6
00:00:41,570 --> 00:00:43,020
>> It is going well today.

7
00:00:43,020 --> 00:00:46,370
Today is Thursday, so
that must mean it's throwback Thursday.

8
00:00:46,370 --> 00:00:47,330
>> Throwback Thursday.

9
00:00:47,330 --> 00:00:53,010
>> And so we are going old school and
we're talking about cables and connectors,

10
00:00:53,010 --> 00:00:57,580
and everything that an IT pro needs
to know about cables and connectors.

11
00:00:57,580 --> 00:01:02,230
So we're gonna take a dive into that realm
and see some of the most common ones.

12
00:01:02,230 --> 00:01:05,250
>> Yeah, remember, one of the objectives
on the exam that we're gonna hit later,

13
00:01:05,250 --> 00:01:07,960
the last domain, IT literacy.

14
00:01:07,960 --> 00:01:10,780
One of the things they expect you to know
is how to take a computer out of the box

15
00:01:10,780 --> 00:01:12,430
and hook up all the cables.

16
00:01:12,430 --> 00:01:15,040
So we probably need to
be able to recognize

17
00:01:15,040 --> 00:01:17,620
what cables belong to what
type of a connection.

18
00:01:17,620 --> 00:01:21,450
And that's exactly what
Exam Objective 2.2 is all about.

19
00:01:21,450 --> 00:01:27,710
The official objective is compare and
contrast common computer connector types.

20
00:01:27,710 --> 00:01:28,270
All right.

21
00:01:28,270 --> 00:01:32,040
Now, there are a lot of connectors,
and I guess it depends.

22
00:01:32,040 --> 00:01:35,580
If you look at a laptop, you might
only have one thing connected to it,

23
00:01:35,580 --> 00:01:37,720
just the power cable and that's it.

24
00:01:37,720 --> 00:01:41,890
But when you look at the back of
a desktop, you may have a ton of cabling.

25
00:01:41,890 --> 00:01:44,800
My computer at home is
a nightmare of cables behind it.

26
00:01:44,800 --> 00:01:48,460
So what are all those cables and
what are they connecting us to?

27
00:01:48,460 --> 00:01:51,110
>> At one time when we built
our own computers way back,

28
00:01:51,110 --> 00:01:54,360
I'll use the term that we always
use around here, back in the day,

29
00:01:54,360 --> 00:01:58,220
we had relatively few cables
that we really dealt with.

30
00:01:58,220 --> 00:02:01,970
Power, and then a connector to the monitor
and maybe a mouse and a keyboard.

31
00:02:01,970 --> 00:02:06,734
But now that we've advanced into
the end of the first decade or

32
00:02:06,734 --> 00:02:12,139
of the 21st century, it's amazing
about how many different cables

33
00:02:12,139 --> 00:02:17,010
are actually out there for
really connecting the same things.

34
00:02:17,010 --> 00:02:19,564
Because we're actually moving in so
many different types and

35
00:02:19,564 --> 00:02:21,723
this is something we've got
to be able to identify,

36
00:02:21,723 --> 00:02:25,170
and you're gonna be working with
them more often than you realize.

37
00:02:25,170 --> 00:02:29,317
>> Yeah so, CompTIA lists about
11 different types of cables.

38
00:02:29,317 --> 00:02:34,890
But for video, for
the display connector, they actually

39
00:02:34,890 --> 00:02:39,990
branch that out into sub categories, and
they have seven different cables for that.

40
00:02:39,990 --> 00:02:45,130
And I guess I should have brought up
the actual exam objective here to show us.

41
00:02:45,130 --> 00:02:48,590
But they break that one out because video
is where it's really gotten complex.

42
00:02:48,590 --> 00:02:52,570
There are so many different types
of video cables that are available.

43
00:02:52,570 --> 00:02:54,520
So, we're gonna show you each of them.

44
00:02:54,520 --> 00:02:55,910
Well, almost all of them.

45
00:02:55,910 --> 00:02:59,700
CompTIA does call out some really old ones
that we'll just have to show a picture of.

46
00:02:59,700 --> 00:03:02,270
But let me just jump down
here to exam objective 2.2.

47
00:03:02,270 --> 00:03:03,730
There it is.

48
00:03:03,730 --> 00:03:06,090
And so you'll se we've got video, and

49
00:03:06,090 --> 00:03:10,880
here's seven different types of video
cable that you might have on your system.

50
00:03:10,880 --> 00:03:14,790
And then after that, we've got a couple
other normal data type cables and

51
00:03:14,790 --> 00:03:18,160
those that are kind of
listed beyond there.

52
00:03:18,160 --> 00:03:20,500
But video has become really complex.

53
00:03:20,500 --> 00:03:21,820
So let's start there, Ronnie.

54
00:03:21,820 --> 00:03:25,280
We'll just take these video connectors and
we'll kind of break down each one and

55
00:03:25,280 --> 00:03:28,620
show what they do and what they're for.

56
00:03:28,620 --> 00:03:34,150
And that very first one,
VGA, up until maybe five or

57
00:03:34,150 --> 00:03:36,960
six years ago,
this was the de facto standard.

58
00:03:36,960 --> 00:03:42,210
So when you were attaching a monitor to
a computer, a VGA cable is what you'd use.

59
00:03:43,280 --> 00:03:47,790
In today's world, there's newer cables
that are better, do higher resolution,

60
00:03:47,790 --> 00:03:51,510
sharper video, but
because VGA was so common,

61
00:03:51,510 --> 00:03:55,660
you still see it all over the place,
you still see it in a lot of systems.

62
00:03:55,660 --> 00:04:00,460
And it's rare to find a computer that
doesn't at least have a VGA connector.

63
00:04:00,460 --> 00:04:02,150
It's kind of the one you can count on,

64
00:04:02,150 --> 00:04:05,980
that almost every system Is going
to have that VGA connector.

65
00:04:05,980 --> 00:04:07,140
So Ronnie, let's take a look at that.

66
00:04:07,140 --> 00:04:09,020
What does that VGA connector look like?

67
00:04:09,020 --> 00:04:12,676
>> A VGA connector,
as we go to our famous Sky Cam here,

68
00:04:12,676 --> 00:04:17,664
we end up having a fairly short cable,
usually about 18 inches or so,

69
00:04:17,664 --> 00:04:20,380
but you end up seeing that there-
>> It's 18 inches?

70
00:04:20,380 --> 00:04:22,888
>> Or is it-
>> That's like a foot and a half, Ronnie,

71
00:04:22,888 --> 00:04:23,950
you have video cables a foot and a half?

72
00:04:23,950 --> 00:04:25,000
>> I'm lying to you.

73
00:04:25,000 --> 00:04:25,945
Yeah, maybe longer.

74
00:04:25,945 --> 00:04:28,100
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don't what I was thinking I

75
00:04:28,100 --> 00:04:28,783
had 18 inches in.

76
00:04:28,783 --> 00:04:30,670
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, I'm wrong on that one.

77
00:04:30,670 --> 00:04:31,620
>> I don't wanna know
what you were thinking.

78
00:04:31,620 --> 00:04:32,800
>> Yeah.
So, they're fairly long.

79
00:04:32,800 --> 00:04:35,590
>> They'll normally be pretty long, cuz
your computer might be under the table,

80
00:04:35,590 --> 00:04:37,080
and the monitor up above, so

81
00:04:37,080 --> 00:04:39,480
it could be a six-foot cable,
it could be a three-foot cable.

82
00:04:39,480 --> 00:04:41,532
18 inches would be impressive.

83
00:04:41,532 --> 00:04:42,200
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

84
00:04:42,200 --> 00:04:44,230
>> I don't know what I was thinking.

85
00:04:44,230 --> 00:04:46,180
>> That's what I'm here for,
Ronnie, keeping you honest.

86
00:04:46,180 --> 00:04:48,310
>> I think I was thinking of SATA or
something.

87
00:04:48,310 --> 00:04:48,850
I don't know.

88
00:04:48,850 --> 00:04:49,630
Who knows?

89
00:04:49,630 --> 00:04:51,890
So usually they're 15 pin connectors.

90
00:04:51,890 --> 00:04:54,650
And a lot of times, just a default,
they're colored blue.

91
00:04:54,650 --> 00:04:58,408
It doesn't mean that they have to be,
but most people have accepted that.

92
00:04:58,408 --> 00:05:01,620
And when they make cables, you tend
to find that these connectors, and

93
00:05:01,620 --> 00:05:07,490
they also have these nice little
screw in types that allow the cable

94
00:05:07,490 --> 00:05:11,750
itself to be plugged in and anchored in so
they don't wiggle themselves out.

95
00:05:11,750 --> 00:05:14,960
So usually we put a couple of turns
on them to make sure as people

96
00:05:14,960 --> 00:05:17,690
move the computer around or
the monitor around, it doesn't end

97
00:05:17,690 --> 00:05:22,250
up wiggling out of it's position and
so usually, that's what we see.

98
00:05:22,250 --> 00:05:25,720
>> And you've really got to have that
because if you think of a power outlet,

99
00:05:25,720 --> 00:05:27,760
you just have two pins that you stick in.

100
00:05:27,760 --> 00:05:31,330
I guess, actually maybe a three,
that go into the wall outlet and

101
00:05:31,330 --> 00:05:32,880
that kind of holds it in place.

102
00:05:32,880 --> 00:05:37,850
But on these, you've got 15 pins in there,
all those little tiny pins.

103
00:05:37,850 --> 00:05:39,540
I know it's kind of hard to see.

104
00:05:39,540 --> 00:05:42,350
But they're all in these little copper,
brass pins.

105
00:05:42,350 --> 00:05:44,410
I think they're all copper.

106
00:05:44,410 --> 00:05:47,970
And each one has to be seated properly or
your display will mess up.

107
00:05:47,970 --> 00:05:50,600
You'll lose a color or
it just won't work at all.

108
00:05:50,600 --> 00:05:53,130
So those thumb screws tighten it in place,
and

109
00:05:53,130 --> 00:05:55,950
this thing isn't coming out as
long as those screws are in place.

110
00:05:55,950 --> 00:05:56,830
>> Yeah.

111
00:05:56,830 --> 00:05:59,060
Nice thing to remember is you don't
have to actually tighten them down so

112
00:05:59,060 --> 00:06:00,685
tight that you'll never get them loose.

113
00:06:00,685 --> 00:06:02,100
>> [LAUGH]
>> The goal of course is

114
00:06:02,100 --> 00:06:03,660
just to snug them down.

115
00:06:03,660 --> 00:06:06,170
Make them tight but don't make them so
tight that when you go and

116
00:06:06,170 --> 00:06:09,300
try to reach for them,
you need a pair of pliers to unscrew them.

117
00:06:09,300 --> 00:06:12,050
>> Does this cable have it running
where the other end of the thumb

118
00:06:12,050 --> 00:06:14,510
screw actually has a gouge
in it like a channel?

119
00:06:14,510 --> 00:06:15,100
>> Sure does.

120
00:06:15,100 --> 00:06:16,800
>> Yeah, a lot of times they'll
put a channel in there and

121
00:06:16,800 --> 00:06:20,090
it looks like a screwdriver, like
a Phillips head or a flathead screwdriver.

122
00:06:20,090 --> 00:06:21,490
>> That doesn't mean you should use one,
right?

123
00:06:21,490 --> 00:06:23,330
You should just do them finger-tight,
right?

124
00:06:23,330 --> 00:06:24,460
Tighten them with your hand.

125
00:06:24,460 --> 00:06:27,490
But if you ever go to undo one that's
been screwed in place for years,

126
00:06:27,490 --> 00:06:30,310
it can be really hard, and so
they put those grooves in there so

127
00:06:30,310 --> 00:06:33,190
that you can use a coin or
a screwdriver to loosen them up.

128
00:06:33,190 --> 00:06:37,090
But they are just plastic, so if you put
too much torque on there, you'll strip it

129
00:06:37,090 --> 00:06:40,890
out real easy, so it's not intended
to be used like that very frequently.

130
00:06:40,890 --> 00:06:43,640
Now this is the cable end
of the connector, and

131
00:06:43,640 --> 00:06:47,330
this is considered a male cable
because you've got the pins.

132
00:06:47,330 --> 00:06:51,860
The other side of this is going to be
the connector that's the female connector.

133
00:06:51,860 --> 00:06:54,850
And so instead of pins, it's gonna
have grooves these pins fit into.

134
00:06:56,040 --> 00:07:01,050
This cable is almost always
colored blue on the ends.

135
00:07:01,050 --> 00:07:05,530
And they follow that same idea
on the other end of the cable.

136
00:07:05,530 --> 00:07:09,590
If we take a, well you know what, mine's,
I'm about to show one that's not blue.

137
00:07:09,590 --> 00:07:13,822
On the other end of the cable,
on your computer where this plugs into,

138
00:07:13,822 --> 00:07:18,890
you can spot those VGA connectors real
quickly because they're blue too.

139
00:07:18,890 --> 00:07:20,610
So the blue cable goes in the blue port,

140
00:07:20,610 --> 00:07:24,790
but the color is not something we can
count on, especially not on the exam.

141
00:07:24,790 --> 00:07:28,120
In real life, that cable could be
any of a number of colors, and

142
00:07:28,120 --> 00:07:30,600
to kind of reinforce that,
I've got a little VGA

143
00:07:30,600 --> 00:07:34,850
adapter here that I use all the time
on my laptop, and it's gray.

144
00:07:34,850 --> 00:07:38,460
So what you really need to be able

when you plug into a wall jack,

1699
01:27:25,790 --> 01:27:28,610
which I guess, we had them up here,
but we're using them.

1700
01:27:28,610 --> 01:27:32,680
So that big jack, when you plug into
a wall jack, that's what that's doing,

1701
01:27:32,680 --> 01:27:37,140
is it's taking the alternating current and
converting it to direct current.

1702
01:27:37,140 --> 01:27:39,480
But when you're on battery,
a battery gives you direct current, so

1703
01:27:39,480 --> 01:27:40,810
you get exactly what you want.

1704
01:27:40,810 --> 01:27:42,100
Oh, thank you, Ronnie.

1705
01:27:42,100 --> 01:27:47,520
Ronnie just brought his up, so he's got
that little Dell box, this box right here.

1706
01:27:47,520 --> 01:27:52,510
So, when you plug a laptop in, you need

1707
01:27:52,510 --> 01:27:56,030
Some laptops might have that internally,
but it makes the laptops big, so

1708
01:27:56,030 --> 01:27:59,690
a lot of people put it outside so

1709
01:27:59,690 --> 01:28:02,819
And they can make your laptop smaller.

1710
01:28:02,819 --> 01:28:06,089
But if you've got a desktop, it just plugs
right into the wall, and that's because

1711
01:28:06,089 --> 01:28:09,423

it can deal with just alternating current.

1712
01:28:09,423 --> 01:28:11,659
Two different types of power,

1713
01:28:11,659 --> 01:28:16,390
and so that's the difference
between those cables, all right?

1714
01:28:16,390 --> 01:28:19,070
Also, the tiny circular plug they
put on laptops is nice and small,

1715
01:28:19,070 --> 01:28:21,600
versus this D plug which is kinda giant.

1716
01:28:21,600 --> 01:28:24,795
Laptops these days aren't normally
even as thick as those D plugs, but

1717
01:28:24,795 --> 01:28:27,425
pretty thin as fat plugs
wouldn't work out.

1718
01:28:27,425 --> 01:28:30,705
>> Yeah, and your plug's actually a little
bit different on yours, isn't it?

1719
01:28:30,705 --> 01:28:32,147
It's not an actual direct plugin.

1720
01:28:32,147 --> 01:28:33,945
>> Yeah.
>> It's a kind of magnetic kind of thing.

1721
01:28:33,945 --> 01:28:35,745
Let me see if I can show that.

1722
01:28:35,745 --> 01:28:41,195
Some vendors have started switching to
these because they're a little bit safer.

1723
01:28:41,195 --> 01:28:44,785
Here, let me disconnect my screen share

because I don't need to
share my screen anymore.

1725
01:28:47,060 --> 01:28:51,280
So I can move my laptop,
into the limelight here.

1726

So let me.

1727
01:28:51,981 --> 01:28:55,970
[LAUGH] Give me just a second while I do
that, and I'll show you what I've got.

1728
01:28:55,970 --> 01:28:59,910
It's just a little magnetic connector,
and the laptop vendors and stuff.

1729
01:28:59,910 --> 01:29:03,130
They can choose to use whatever
type of connector they want.

1730
01:29:03,130 --> 01:29:04,290
It's up to them.

1731
01:29:04,290 --> 01:29:07,516
But they typically follow the standards,
if they can.

1732
01:29:07,516 --> 01:29:12,630

1733
01:29:12,630 --> 01:29:17,390

1734
01:29:17,390 --> 01:29:21,410
But so here's, so it's now unplugged,

1735
01:29:21,410 --> 01:29:23,650

and

1736

a giant recessed thing.

1737

It's just four little copper
pins that are right there.

1738
01:29:29,800 --> 01:29:30,940
There are five.

1739
01:29:30,940 --> 01:29:36,070
And what I've got is my
Power cable looks like this.

1740
01:29:36,070 --> 01:29:36,870
It's flat.

1741
01:29:36,870 --> 01:29:38,410
It's weird, right?

1742

And they just made it where it's magnetic,
so

1743

that it'll stick on and
the magnet holds it in place.

1744
01:29:43,760 --> 01:29:45,520
>> That's cool.
>> And the reason they did that

1745
01:29:45,520 --> 01:29:46,120
>> Is people

1746

1747

And that port, on most laptops, is
soldered to the mother board inside of it,

1748
01:29:52,380 --> 01:29:53,990
and the solder can break.

1749
01:29:53,990 --> 01:29:56,150
When that port gets loose,
it can start to spark.

1750
01:29:56,150 --> 01:29:58,440
And eventually your laptop
will stop charging.

1751
01:29:58,440 --> 01:30:00,650
And a lot of people say oh,
my battery doesn't work anymore.

1752

My laptop won't charge.

1753

>> And
it's not the laptop that's the problem, or

1754
01:30:03,870 --> 01:30:06,560
the battery that's the problem,
it's just the port.

1755
01:30:06,560 --> 01:30:08,060
But since it's attached
to the motherboard,

1756
01:30:08,060 --> 01:30:11,230
it can be a pretty expensive repair unless
you're handy with a soldering iron.

1757
01:30:11,230 --> 01:30:16,030
I can't even count how many of

1758
01:30:16,030 --> 01:30:19,310
But you'll see these

1759

It doesn't have to be blue.

1765

I know that's USB 3 because

1767

that's the standard 3.5 millimeter jack.

1768

On my other side I've
got HDMI right there and

1769
01:30:51,430 --> 01:30:55,430
I've got USB right there I've got my

1770
01:30:55,430 --> 01:31:00,540
So those are all kind of ports that we'll
see on laptops as we work with those.

1771
01:31:00,540 --> 01:31:02,102
Cause you know laptops
have different needs.

1772
01:31:02,102 --> 01:31:07,830
All right, well Ronnie look I'm looking
at my notes here and I think that

1773

that CompTIA calls out for the exam.

1774
01:31:11,050 --> 01:31:11,550
>> It does.

1775
01:31:12,890 --> 01:31:16,100
>> All right, so keep in mind guys,
that these are just the most common ones,

1776
01:31:16,100 --> 01:31:17,680

1777

It doesn't hurt to know them.

1778

1779

You just need to know which

5

Good morning, good afternoon and
good evening, and

6

welcome back to another
episode of ITPRO TV.

7
00:00:38,851 --> 00:00:41,700
I'm your host Don Posset,
back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:41,700 --> 00:00:42,650
How's it going Ronnie?

9
00:00:42,650 --> 00:00:43,790

10

We are in the middle taking
a look at IT fundamentals and

12

stuff inside the case.

13
00:00:54,120 --> 00:00:56,740
>> That's right, if you are following

14

15
00:00:59,030 --> 00:01:03,410
Identify the purpose of
internal computer components.

16
00:01:03,410 --> 00:01:07,320
In previous episodes, we've talked about
all the stuff we hook up to the outside.

17
00:01:07,320 --> 00:01:09,230
What about all the stuff on the inside?

18
00:01:09,230 --> 00:01:11,590
Your average computer user is
never gonna worry about that.

19
00:01:11,590 --> 00:01:15,230
They're never gonna open up their case but
If you're gonna get into an IT career,

20
00:01:15,230 --> 00:01:17,490
this is where troubleshooting
will lend you.

21
00:01:17,490 --> 00:01:20,670
Not just troubleshooting, but also you
might choose to upgrade a computer.

22
00:01:20,670 --> 00:01:23,530
So, we need to know what each of
the components are inside of it and

23
00:01:23,530 --> 00:01:24,820
what they do.

24
00:01:24,820 --> 00:01:29,000
Well, the best way to do that is to
take a look inside of a computer.

25
00:01:29,000 --> 00:01:32,300
So, right here on our podium,
we actually have a guest host with us,

26
00:01:32,300 --> 00:01:36,630
which is a Dell computer, a Dell,
what is this, an OptiPlex 980 or-

27
00:01:36,630 --> 00:01:38,470
>> It is a 960.

28
00:01:38,470 --> 00:01:40,000
>> OptiPlex nine something.

29
00:01:40,000 --> 00:01:43,950
So it's a [LAUGH], it's a Dell computer
and it's pretty representative of your

30
00:01:43,950 --> 00:01:47,560
average tower-based computer,
like what you have at a desk.

31
00:01:47,560 --> 00:01:49,340
Laptops are gonna be far different and

32
00:01:49,340 --> 00:01:52,830
laptops are usually very specialized
because of how small they are.

33
00:01:52,830 --> 00:01:55,380
But desktops are typically
arranged the same and

34
00:01:55,380 --> 00:01:58,050
this one's a really good
kind of general model.

35
00:01:58,050 --> 00:01:59,800
So, we're gonna rip this thing open and

36
00:01:59,800 --> 00:02:02,610
take a look at the components inside and
highlight their purpose.

37
00:02:02,610 --> 00:02:05,130
So, Ronnie,
why don't you get this guy opened.

38
00:02:05,130 --> 00:02:05,770
>> All right.

39
00:02:05,770 --> 00:02:06,900
>> And we'll start to take a look inside.

40
00:02:06,900 --> 00:02:10,740
And while you're doing that, I'm gonna
start talking about our first component.

41
00:02:10,740 --> 00:02:15,560
The first component I wanna talk about
is the CPU, the central processing unit.

42
00:02:15,560 --> 00:02:19,320
Now, a lot of people are in the habit
of referring to this entire tower

43
00:02:19,320 --> 00:02:22,230
as the CPU and that's not really true.

44
00:02:22,230 --> 00:02:24,950
The CPU's actually a very,
very small piece of it.

45
00:02:24,950 --> 00:02:27,090
It is the brain of your computer.

46
00:02:27,090 --> 00:02:29,090
The CPU is what does the thinking.

47
00:02:29,090 --> 00:02:32,400
When there's a mathematical question,
it gets thrown to the CPU and

48
00:02:32,400 --> 00:02:35,300
the CPU finds the answer and
returns it back.

49
00:02:35,300 --> 00:02:39,460
So, everything your computer does is
really being controlled by that processor.

50
00:02:39,460 --> 00:02:43,300
So, when we open up the computer,
even though the CPU is a very,

51
00:02:43,300 --> 00:02:47,500
very small piece,
it's the most important, and here we go.

52
00:02:47,500 --> 00:02:49,550
So, Ronnie,
you got this thing ripped open.

53
00:02:49,550 --> 00:02:53,750
And the CPU that I'm talking about,
that's this guy, right here,

54
00:02:53,750 --> 00:02:56,570
this chip right here on my motherboard.

55
00:02:56,570 --> 00:02:58,920
Now, before we get too far into this,

56
00:02:58,920 --> 00:03:01,970
let's start with just a little
something not on the objectives,

57
00:03:01,970 --> 00:03:06,400
which is electrical safety when
working with computers, all right.

58
00:03:06,400 --> 00:03:09,790
If you want to do this at home,
there's two things we need to remember.

59
00:03:09,790 --> 00:03:14,610
First off, the computer should be
turned off any time you open it.

60
00:03:14,610 --> 00:03:19,080
It's an electrical device,
you could shock yourself and I've done it,

61
00:03:19,080 --> 00:03:21,010
it doesn't feel very good, so.

62
00:03:21,010 --> 00:03:22,950
Some people might be into that,
but I'm not.

63
00:03:22,950 --> 00:03:26,530
So, you don't want to shock
yourself if you don't have to.

64
00:03:26,530 --> 00:03:28,340
Secondly, whether you know it or not.

65
00:03:28,340 --> 00:03:31,420
You have static electricity
built up in your system.

66
00:03:31,420 --> 00:03:34,120
Just walking around on carpet or
even the weather.

67
00:03:34,120 --> 00:03:35,750
Certain barometric temperatures, or

68
00:03:35,750 --> 00:03:38,350
pressures can create static
electricity in the human body.

69
00:03:38,350 --> 00:03:41,720
It's just, it's there, and you really
know it, like in the winter time.

70
00:03:41,720 --> 00:03:43,810
If you rub your feet and
you walk up and you touch somebody and

71
00:03:43,810 --> 00:03:47,770
zap them or, rubber balloon in your
hair and then it will stick to the wall.

72
00:03:47,770 --> 00:03:52,720
But in a computer, it doesn't take
very much static electricity to

73
00:03:52,720 --> 00:03:54,650
damage an electrical component.

74
00:03:54,650 --> 00:03:59,180
So, when you're working on a computer like
this, you should always be grounded, and

75
00:03:59,180 --> 00:04:01,120
there's a number of ways to do that.

76
00:04:01,120 --> 00:04:05,130
There are elecro-static wristbands
that you can wear to ground yourself.

77
00:04:05,130 --> 00:04:08,260
There are metal tables and
tables that have grounding in it.

78
00:04:08,260 --> 00:04:08,780
Like ours,

79
00:04:08,780 --> 00:04:12,800
we've got this giant metal band around it
here that helps to ground out our system.

80
00:04:12,800 --> 00:04:16,670
You've also got things like ankle straps,
all sorts of different tools that

81
00:04:16,670 --> 00:04:20,030
are available, and, for those of you that
go on to work on the A+ certification,

82
00:04:20,030 --> 00:04:22,150
we cover those in much
more greater depth there.

83
00:04:23,390 --> 00:04:26,690
If you take your computer apart at home,
though, definitely be aware of that.

84
00:04:26,690 --> 00:04:29,430
You don't want to ruin a component just
because you weren't properly grounded.

85
00:04:30,690 --> 00:04:32,040
All right, so that CPU,

86
00:04:32,040 --> 00:04:36,550
that little processor right down there
on the mother board, it is a micro chip,

87
00:04:36,550 --> 00:04:39,830
and it doesn't look very micro,
it's actually kind of a decent size.

88
00:04:39,830 --> 00:04:43,430
But it's small compared to everything
else that's inside of the case.

89
00:04:43,430 --> 00:04:44,070
All right.

90
00:04:44,070 --> 00:04:46,030
Ronnie, do you wanna pop
that out of it's socket?

91
00:04:46,030 --> 00:04:47,150
>> Sure.

92
00:04:47,150 --> 00:04:49,930
>> When you look at a CPU,
if you were to flip it over,

93
00:04:49,930 --> 00:04:53,250
the top of it is actually just very
>> Flat, there's not much to it.

94
00:04:53,250 --> 00:04:56,360
When you flip it over,
there's actually hundreds of little

95
00:04:56,360 --> 00:05:00,460
pins underneath it that connect in with
the motherboard, and they're very fragile.

96
00:05:00,460 --> 00:05:01,990
So, we have to be careful with that.

97
00:05:01,990 --> 00:05:03,920
We don't want to break any of the pins.

98
00:05:03,920 --> 00:05:08,160
There is no way to repair
a broken pin on a CPU.

99
00:05:08,160 --> 00:05:10,330
If we damage it, it's just damaged, and

100
00:05:10,330 --> 00:05:13,800
that's it, so
You have to be careful with this.

101
00:05:13,800 --> 00:05:16,970
Now, in our case, we can see that CPU
is right there on the motherboard.

102
00:05:16,970 --> 00:05:19,700
We're gonna take a closer look
at it a little bit later.

103
00:05:19,700 --> 00:05:20,460
On your computer,

104
00:05:20,460 --> 00:05:23,770
when you open it up, you might not
be able to see the CPU right away.

105
00:05:23,770 --> 00:05:28,145
A lot of times they will have a metal
shroud on top of them called a heatsink,

106
00:05:28,145 --> 00:05:32,645
and possibly even a fan sitting on top,
all to dissipate heat.

107
00:05:32,645 --> 00:05:37,245
Modern CPUs generate a lot of heat, and
it's gotta be pushed out of the case,

108
00:05:37,245 --> 00:05:38,975
otherwise your system will overheat.

109
00:05:38,975 --> 00:05:43,005
We took it off before this show because
we didn't want to block the view.

110
00:05:43,005 --> 00:05:44,445
If you can't see anything
how do you learn?

111
00:05:45,830 --> 00:05:50,020
Now, the other general components inside
of the case all start to build to what

112
00:05:50,020 --> 00:05:51,210
the computer does.

113
00:05:51,210 --> 00:05:53,640
You'll notice this gigantic circuit here.

114
00:05:53,640 --> 00:05:56,440
That's our motherboard, and
we're gonna take a close look at it in

115
00:05:56,440 --> 00:05:59,680
another segment, because I wanna
get that out of the case here so

116
00:05:59,680 --> 00:06:01,550
we can take a really close look at it.

117
00:06:01,550 --> 00:06:05,400
But before we get to that, some of the
other major components that you'll notice

118
00:06:05,400 --> 00:06:07,262
we got our power supply up here.

119
00:06:07,262 --> 00:06:11,060
All right, this is what's providing
power to your entire computer.

120
00:06:12,090 --> 00:06:14,650
If it gets damage there are not

121
00:06:14,650 --> 00:06:17,180
field repairable Parts inside of this,
all right?

122
00:06:17,180 --> 00:06:19,270
There are capacitors in

00:49:22,719 --> 00:49:26,911
drive entirely, the next time you plug
it in to the network, it phones home.

1019
00:49:26,911 --> 00:49:30,790
And so they had, I think it was It was
15 laptops or so that got stolen and

1020
00:49:30,790 --> 00:49:34,606
when the guy took them back to his
condo and he started formatting them,

1021
00:49:34,606 --> 00:49:38,573
he put them on the internet to go into
Windows update and they phoned home.

1022
00:49:38,573 --> 00:49:41,683
And they all phoned home from his
apartment and law enforcement was able to

1023
00:49:41,683 --> 00:49:44,758
go right there and bust him and
he had stacks of laptops in the apartment.

1024
00:49:44,758 --> 00:49:47,498
And so that's, that's what can happen.

1025
00:49:47,498 --> 00:49:50,748
And that's a, a,
a problem with physical security.

1026
00:49:50,748 --> 00:49:54,835
He should not have been able to walk
into that building first off, right?

1027
00:49:54,835 --> 00:49:59,354
Secondly, he should not have been able
to move office to office without being

1028
00:49:59,354 --> 00:50:00,617
validated somehow.

1029
00:50:00,617 --> 00:50:05,365
And third, those laptops should not
have been sitting there unsecured.

1030
00:50:05,365 --> 00:50:10,194
There's thing we can do to stop this
type of attack at multiple places and

1031
00:50:10,194 --> 00:50:14,166
any one of them would have
stopped the attack all together.

1032
00:50:14,166 --> 00:50:15,907
>> So hardware theft fairly common.

1033
00:50:15,907 --> 00:50:20,505
The other one that you, you hear about
more often is the software theft.

1034
00:50:20,505 --> 00:50:25,106
You've probably heard it on the radio,
you've probably seen it on TV that tells

1035
00:50:25,106 --> 00:50:28,623
you that software theft today is,
is as great as it ever was and

1036
00:50:28,623 --> 00:50:33,492
the way that it happens is, is companies
will allow their their employees to

1037
00:50:33,492 --> 00:50:37,379
bring software and install it on
a computer, then make a copy of it.

1038
00:50:37,379 --> 00:50:40,816
They take it home and then install it on
their own computer system at home too.

1039
00:50:40,816 --> 00:50:44,433
And a lot of times when you start hearing
these public service announcements

1040
00:50:44,433 --> 00:50:48,006
it's always saying, hey, that's a bad
thing make sure you report this.

1041
00:50:48,006 --> 00:50:52,647
>> And you know, your company might buy a
bulk of license from Microsoft Office, so

1042
00:50:52,647 --> 00:50:55,796
they get one product key
that can be used 200 times.

1043
00:50:55,796 --> 00:50:59,252
And they start installing it and
they get through hundred computers and

1044
00:50:59,252 --> 00:51:01,217
then it tells them they're out of keys.

1045
00:51:01,217 --> 00:51:02,009
And they only used half.

1046
00:51:02,009 --> 00:51:03,075
What happened to the other half?

1047
00:51:03,075 --> 00:51:06,143
Well, an employee may have gotten
the key and shared it with friends,

1048
00:51:06,143 --> 00:51:09,471
installed it on unauthorized machines and
now you've got software theft.

1049
00:51:09,471 --> 00:51:10,193
Right?

1050
00:51:10,193 --> 00:51:13,711
You find a lot of times when you buy
software off of eBay of whatever,

1051
00:51:13,711 --> 00:51:15,273
that can be stolen software.

1052
00:51:15,273 --> 00:51:16,562
It does happen.

1053
00:51:16,562 --> 00:51:19,849
That's why we have these activation
systems you have to go though to make sure

1054
00:51:19,849 --> 00:51:21,833
that you're, you're software is genuine.

1055
00:51:21,833 --> 00:51:24,451
You know, not, no actually bootlegged or
stolen or copied.

1056
00:51:24,451 --> 00:51:29,155
Software at it's heart is really
just a bunch of ones and zeros, so

1057
00:51:29,155 --> 00:51:32,357
it is easy to duplicate and
represents that.

1058
00:51:32,357 --> 00:51:33,048
All right.

1059
00:51:33,048 --> 00:51:34,872
Shoulder surfing is another one.

1060
00:51:34,872 --> 00:51:38,194
Now, Comtec throws this one
under physical security.

1061
00:51:38,194 --> 00:51:40,798
Some of the other vendors out there
actually put this under social

1062
00:51:40,798 --> 00:51:41,421
engineering.

1063
00:51:41,421 --> 00:51:47,144
But for this exam, shoulder surfing
is a type of physical compromise.

1064
00:51:47,144 --> 00:51:51,078
When you are logging into your computer
and it asks you for your password,

1065
00:51:51,078 --> 00:51:52,102
you gotta type it.

1066
00:51:52,102 --> 00:51:54,577
You gotta take your hands,
you gotta put em on the keyboard and

1067
00:51:54,577 --> 00:51:55,632
you gotta touch the keys.

1068
00:51:55,632 --> 00:51:58,988
If somebody's standing behind you,
they can look over your shoulder,

1069
00:51:58,988 --> 00:52:01,088
that's why it's called shoulder surfing.

1070
00:52:01,088 --> 00:52:03,724
And they could see which keys
you're touching on your keyboard.

1071
00:52:03,724 --> 00:52:06,297
And now, they know your password.

1072
00:52:06,297 --> 00:52:11,269
I have a, a tablet at home and
I have a password on it.

1073
00:52:11,269 --> 00:52:13,691
You know, if you wanna unlock my tablet,
you gotta punch in a code.

1074
00:52:13,691 --> 00:52:16,863
And my son,
he likes to play games on the tablet.

1075
00:52:16,863 --> 00:52:19,817
And so whenever he wanted this,
he had to bring the tablet to me and

1076
00:52:19,817 --> 00:52:22,586
I would unlock it and
he would get in there and play the games.

1077
00:52:22,586 --> 00:52:27,436
Well, after a couple of weeks,
[LAUGH] he came to me and said, dad,

1078
00:52:27,436 --> 00:52:29,355
I can unlock your tablet.

1079
00:52:29,355 --> 00:52:31,909
And sure enough,
he'd punch the code in, log right in.

1080
00:52:31,909 --> 00:52:33,962
He had seen me do enough
that over the times,

1081
00:52:33,962 --> 00:52:36,581
he was able to tell exactly
which numbers I was hitting.

1082
00:52:36,581 --> 00:52:37,858
He was able to get in.

1083
00:52:37,858 --> 00:52:40,400
Now, I don't worry about it so
much, I'm at home.

1084
00:52:40,400 --> 00:52:44,461
But if you're on a bus in an airplane,
you got people around you and

1085
00:52:44,461 --> 00:52:47,650
you're punching in your passwords,
people can see that.

1086
00:52:47,650 --> 00:52:51,632
And so we've gotta take steps to ensure
that that doesn't happen, all right?

1087
00:52:51,632 --> 00:52:55,397
Now there's not a whole heck of a lot
of ways to prevent that when you're in

1088
00:52:55,397 --> 00:52:59,711
a crowded area other than not to type in
your password and just wait until later.

1089
00:52:59,711 --> 00:53:03,141
There are different other technologies
though a lot of people with their,

1090
00:53:03,141 --> 00:53:04,566
their laptops, for example.

1091
00:53:04,566 --> 00:53:08,386
You can get these screen protectors
almost all banks use these now.

1092
00:53:08,386 --> 00:53:12,589
There is a little screen protectors that
go on your screen and they're clear.

1093
00:53:12,589 --> 00:53:15,351
They just, they don't look any
different than the normal screen.

1094
00:53:15,351 --> 00:53:18,490
But if you look at the screen
from any kind of angle,

1095
00:53:18,490 --> 00:53:20,391
the whole screen turns black.

1096
00:53:20,391 --> 00:53:23,281
They're basically polarize, they got
these little channels inside of them.

1097
00:53:23,281 --> 00:53:27,349
And when you look at an angle, you're
seeing the edges of theses channels and so

1098
00:53:27,349 --> 00:53:29,062
it turns the whole screen black.

1099
00:53:29,062 --> 00:53:32,708
But when you're looking straight on,
it's perfectly clear like normal.

1100
00:53:32,708 --> 00:53:36,342
So that stops people in your periphery
from being able to see your laptop.

1101
00:53:36,342 --> 00:53:40,019
They don't stop somebody standing directly
behind you though, so there is that risk,

1102
00:53:40,019 --> 00:53:41,666
but it would be much more challenging.

1103
00:53:41,666 --> 00:53:43,453
Somebody would have to look
through your head, right?

1104
00:53:43,453 --> 00:53:47,306
So they'd have to, like really be on
your shoulder to see that screen.

1105
00:53:47,306 --> 00:53:49,626
But that is one technology you can use.

1106
00:53:49,626 --> 00:53:53,539
Another one is you'll see a lot of phones
now have switched to fingerprint scanners.

1107
00:53:53,539 --> 00:53:57,126
So you want to unlock your phone or
your tablet, you scan your fingerprint.

1108
00:53:57,126 --> 00:54:00,007
I don't care if they see which finger I
use, they're not gonna take my, well,

1109
00:54:00,007 --> 00:54:01,863
if they take my finger,
I've got other problems.

1110
00:54:01,863 --> 00:54:04,187
But you know, so they're not gonna see it,

1111
00:54:04,187 --> 00:54:06,321
it's not like a code they can watch and
punch in.

1112
00:54:06,321 --> 00:54:08,967
So these are ways that we
get around that problem.

1113
00:54:08,967 --> 00:54:12,469
You know, on the topic of solutions,
we talk about physical security.

1114
00:54:12,469 --> 00:54:17,152
Some of the solutions there, security
guards at the front door, sign in lists.

1115
00:54:17,152 --> 00:54:17,887
Right?

1116
00:54:17,887 --> 00:54:18,997
Visitor badges.

1117
00:54:18,997 --> 00:54:20,680
Don't let people use their own badge,

1118
00:54:20,680 --> 00:54:22,931
have your own visitor badges
that they have to wear.

1119
00:54:22,931 --> 00:54:24,824
Those are all things
that can help with that.

1120
00:54:24,824 --> 00:54:28,050
Locked offices and
even equipment locked for your machines.

1121
00:54:28,050 --> 00:54:31,640
Most computers have a what it'
called is it a tar, a TARDIS lock?

1122
00:54:31,640 --> 00:54:32,615
What, what those are called?
>> Kensington.

1123
00:54:32,615 --> 00:54:33,741
>> Kensington lock.

1124
00:54:33,741 --> 00:54:36,576
So they'll have this little notch
in the side of your laptops for

1125
00:54:36,576 --> 00:54:40,108
putting in a Kensington lock, which is
a cable that will lock down to your desk.

1126
00:54:40,108 --> 00:54:42,301
So now somebody can't
physically take the laptop.

1127
00:54:42,301 --> 00:54:46,237
These are all simple steps that we can put
in place that eliminate all these attacks.

1128
00:54:46,237 --> 00:54:49,811
Everything we've talked about on
this show has a simple solution,

1129
00:54:49,811 --> 00:54:51,577
if we educate our users about it.

1130
00:54:51,577 --> 00:54:52,715
>> Yeah.

1131
00:54:52,715 --> 00:54:56,917
Our last topic that we're gonna
cover is dumpster diving.

1132
00:54:56,917 --> 00:55:00,736
There's a lot of times when companies
are trying to get rid of older systems.

1133
00:55:00,736 --> 00:55:03,646
And what ends of happening is that,
even though they might,

1134
00:55:03,646 --> 00:55:06,730
they're supposed to go through
a particular procedure in a very

1135
00:55:06,730 --> 00:55:09,317
quick instance,
they might all end up in a dumpster.

1136
00:55:09,317 --> 00:55:12,755
Somebody could easily jump in that
dumpster and not only get these systems

1137
00:55:12,755 --> 00:55:15,748
out, but maybe other data that you
may have put in there as well,

1138
00:55:15,748 --> 00:55:19,649
which means that they could get access to
that and use that data to their advantage.

1139
00:55:19,649 --> 00:55:20,357
>> Mm-hm.

1140
00:55:20,357 --> 00:55:23,864
Yeah, when you throw a computer in the
trash or, or even if you sell it on eBay,

1141
00:55:23,864 --> 00:55:26,220
what happens to your data
that was on that computer?

1142
00:55:26,220 --> 00:55:27,845
It doesn't magically disappear.

1143
00:55:27,845 --> 00:55:28,794
It's there.

1144
00:55:28,794 --> 00:55:33,886
And even if you format the computer and
erase it, the magnetic residual signals

1145
00:55:33,886 --> 00:55:38,458
are still there on your disk and
in most cases and they can be recovered.

1146
00:55:38,458 --> 00:55:41,843
It takes Five minutes on Google,
to find a program for 20 bucks,

1147
00:55:41,843 --> 00:55:44,710
that'll scan a hard drive and
recover lost data.

1148
00:55:44,710 --> 00:55:46,020
You can spend thousands of dollars and

1149
00:55:46,020 --> 00:55:49,230
get the high end stuff too, and
recover data from the drive.

1150
00:55:49,230 --> 00:55:51,300
If you had sensitive or

1151
00:55:51,300 --> 00:55:54,530
confidential information that was
on there, somebody could get it.

1152
00:55:54,530 --> 00:55:57,690
They'd just have to dig through
the dumpster of your trash or, you know,

1153
00:55:57,690 --> 00:55:59,890
buy equipment from you on eBay or
whatever.

1154
00:55:59,890 --> 00:56:02,060
And now they'll have access
to that information.

1155
00:56:02,060 --> 00:56:07,890
So, any time you dispose of a computer
system, you need to check it for data.

1156
00:56:07,890 --> 00:56:10,900
And if you don't have a proper way to
sanitize that hard drive to ensure

1157
00:56:10,900 --> 00:56:14,900
the data's not on there,
then you need to destroy the hard drive.

1158
00:56:14,900 --> 00:56:15,600
If you go on eBay,

1159
00:56:15,600 --> 00:56:19,580
you can find a lot of computers that are
being sold with no hard drive included.

1160
00:56:19,580 --> 00:56:23,630
And that'll usually mean that it came from
some agency that was smart enough to say,

1161
00:56:23,630 --> 00:56:27,095
we can't trust that our drives are empty,
so we are just gonna destroy them.

1162
00:56:27,095 --> 00:56:29,820
And there's companies that
do hard drive shredding.

1163
00:56:29,820 --> 00:56:32,387
They have these giant commercial
shredders that will destroy them, or

1164
00:56:32,387 --> 00:56:35,010
they drill holes in them, or whatever,
there's various ways to do it.

1165
00:56:35,010 --> 00:56:37,870
The, the drilling holes thing isn't
as effective as they make it sound.

1166
00:56:37,870 --> 00:56:40,145
But, but you can just destroy them.

1167
00:56:40,145 --> 00:56:42,190
It'/s the, the really best way to be safe.

1168
00:56:42,190 --> 00:56:46,800
And, it extends beyond computers too,
all right, be careful with firewalls.

1169
00:56:46,800 --> 00:56:49,470
A lot of people will
throw a firewall away.

1170
00:56:49,470 --> 00:56:51,030
Well, what's on that firewall?

1171
00:56:51,030 --> 00:56:52,880
There's configurations.

1172
00:56:52,880 --> 00:56:56,980
And list what ports you allowed,
what VPN you had set up, and so on.

1173
00:56:56,980 --> 00:57:00,710
Well, you obviously replaced
it with a new firewall.

1174
00:57:00,710 --> 00:57:03,630
You probably follow the same
configuration on the new firewall, right.

1175
00:57:03,630 --> 00:57:04,950
It might be faster,
it might be bigger, but

1176
00:57:04,950 --> 00:57:07,240
you're probably allowing
the same ports and the same IPs.

1177
00:57:07,240 --> 00:57:10,320
Now an attacker knows what's
available on your system.

1178
00:57:10,320 --> 00:57:14,215
So, any kind of computer gear not
being disposed, not just PCs,

1179
00:57:14,215 --> 00:57:18,801
needS to be sanitized or destroyed, so
that your personal data doesn't get out.

1180
00:57:19,910 --> 00:57:23,514
Other ways to solve a problem,
if you do full drive encryption,

1181
00:57:23,514 --> 00:57:28,545
Microsoft BitLocker TrueCrypt, what was
the, what's the new name at TrueCrypt?

1182
00:57:28,545 --> 00:57:29,670
The, the guys that forked it?

1183
00:57:30,754 --> 00:57:33,647
>> I don't remember
>> I can't remember either, but yeah,

1184
00:57:33,647 --> 00:57:36,380
there, there's several different
systems out there has one,

1185
00:57:36,380 --> 00:57:39,390
where you can encrypt
your entire hard drive.

1186
00:57:39,390 --> 00:57:41,850
Now you can format it,
throw data on there, fine, and

1187
00:57:41,850 --> 00:57:46,450
if somebody tries to recover your deleted
data, they get encrypted data, and

1188
00:57:46,450 --> 00:57:48,100
so it's, it's not of any use to them.

1189
00:57:48,100 --> 00:57:51,900
Those are steps you can take to help
secure your data on your system,

1190
00:57:51,900 --> 00:57:54,730
so that it doesn't leak out.

1191
00:57:54,730 --> 00:57:56,750
But dumpster diving can go even further.

1192
00:57:56,750 --> 00:58:01,470
Maybe you've thrown away some electric
utility bills, and if somebody wants to do

1193
00:58:01,470 --> 00:58:03,580
identity theft, they're gonna
have to prove that they are you.

1194
00:58:03,580 --> 00:58:06,010
And they can say, well, here,
I've got my electric bill.

1195
00:58:06,010 --> 00:58:06,550
Right?

1196
00:58:06,550 --> 00:58:09,100
Or they can find other things
on there that have your

1197
00:58:09,100 --> 00:58:10,630
personally identifiable information.

1198
00:58:10,630 --> 00:58:15,030
Things like user names, or
account numbers, and so on.

1199
00:58:15,030 --> 00:58:17,200
I mean, that's stuff that gets
listed on a lot of paperwork that

1200
00:58:17,200 --> 00:58:18,260
might get thrown away.

1201
00:58:18,260 --> 00:58:20,240
So, you should really make
sure paperwork is shredded or

1202
00:58:20,240 --> 00:58:23,460
destroyed, if it's got
identification information on it.

1203
00:58:25,740 --> 00:58:28,860
All right, so that pretty much
covers the basic security threats.

1204

We've got more to cover
when it comes to security.

1205

We've got two little sections
that we've gotta hit.

1206

But for this episode,
that's probably a good stopping point,

1207

don't you think, Ronnie?

>> All right.

00:45:10,950 --> 00:45:12,640

00:45:18,760 --> 00:45:21,390

00:45:21,390 --> 00:45:24,460

00:45:24,460 --> 00:45:27,070

00:45:27,070 --> 00:45:32,170

00:45:32,170 --> 00:45:35,010

you'd sit down and check your email and

00:45:35,010 --> 00:45:38,940

you're doing is being logged, and,

00:45:38,940 --> 00:45:41,920
the attackers are just wait a few
weeks and they would go back and

976
00:45:41,920 --> 00:45:44,950
rent the machine for an hour and
collect the data and walk off with it.

977
00:45:44,950 --> 00:45:48,040
And so they were harvesting user names and
passwords left and right,

978
00:45:48,040 --> 00:45:53,630
all over and that's one of the big
risks with using a public computer.

00:45:53,630 --> 00:45:57,010

995

11
00:00:38,080 --> 00:00:42,290
which is small office, home office,
router, wired and wireless.

12
00:00:42,290 --> 00:00:44,150
In other words, for your house or for

13
00:00:44,150 --> 00:00:48,700
your, your small office, how we can
set up basic network connectivity.

14
00:00:48,700 --> 00:00:52,230
Wired and wireless is pretty important
because while wired networks are nice and

15
00:00:52,230 --> 00:00:56,050
stable and fast, wireless networks
are easy and quick to deploy, and so

16
00:00:56,050 --> 00:00:57,830
you see them very, very commonly.

17
00:00:57,830 --> 00:01:00,230
So we'll take a look at what's
involved in both of those scenarios.

18
00:01:01,270 --> 00:01:03,210
>> In our second objective,
we also have compare and

19
00:01:03,210 --> 00:01:07,830
contrast cellular, wireless,
and wired data connections.

20
00:01:07,830 --> 00:01:11,630
We begin by taking a look at
the basic infrastructure when we

21
00:01:11,630 --> 00:01:14,860
start connecting computers together and
what we'll need there.

22
00:01:14,860 --> 00:01:19,130
We'll also talk about adding in
the wireless access point, so that we

23
00:01:19,130 --> 00:01:23,370
can get connectivity without having to
be tethered to a single work station.

24
00:01:23,370 --> 00:01:24,900
But then we go a little bit, even,

25
00:01:24,900 --> 00:01:28,950
beyond that in which the device
itself is directly connected out

26
00:01:28,950 --> 00:01:33,380
to the internet itself without
needing another device to go through.

27
00:01:33,380 --> 00:01:37,470
So we'll make sure that, you know, when we
normally will see that and we'll also talk

28
00:01:37,470 --> 00:01:41,810
about the, the contrast of it, when we,
how we differentiate between those three.

29
00:01:43,410 --> 00:01:45,650
>> The last objective is 4.3 compare and

30
00:01:45,650 --> 00:01:49,240
contrast different methods of sharing and
storage.

31
00:01:49,240 --> 00:01:51,980
When we get our computers to communicate
with each other, we can use it for

32
00:01:51,980 --> 00:01:55,280
things like web browsing but
more commonly we're gonna use it for

33
00:01:55,280 --> 00:01:57,660
exchanging information, sharing.

34
00:01:57,660 --> 00:02:00,340
So, we'll have documents on one computer
that we want to access from another

35
00:02:00,340 --> 00:02:01,770
computer or vice versa.

36
00:02:01,770 --> 00:02:05,270
Maybe not documents, maybe media files,
music, videos whatever.

37
00:02:05,270 --> 00:02:08,870
So some of the basic ways that we can
exchange that information between them and

38
00:02:08,870 --> 00:02:11,110
handle our storage to support that.

39
00:02:11,110 --> 00:02:13,870
So very useful,
especially in an office environment,

40
00:02:13,870 --> 00:02:16,820
where you are going to have shared
storage across your machines.

41
00:02:16,820 --> 00:02:18,940
So everybody's storing their
data in the same place.

42
00:02:20,152 --> 00:02:24,540
All right, well those topics and
more are found in domain 4.0 networking.

43
00:02:24,540 --> 00:02:28,560
This is one of the smaller objectives for
the certification, but it is very

44
00:02:28,560 --> 00:02:32,150
important and you'll see as you go through
other certifications that networking

45
00:02:32,150 --> 00:02:36,820
becomes more and more significant in each
of those because of how critical it is.

46
00:02:36,820 --> 00:02:38,450
So, it's pretty cool stuff.

47
00:02:38,450 --> 00:02:41,288
We're definitely gonna be jumping
into all of that, so stay tuned.

48
00:02:41,288 --> 00:02:44,701
We've got networking episodes coming up.

49

Good morning, good afternoon,

And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:39,174 --> 00:00:41,812
I'm your host Don Pezet,
back with Mr Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:41,812 --> 00:00:43,000
How's it going, Ronnie?

7
00:00:43,000 --> 00:00:44,080
>> It is going swell.

8
00:00:44,080 --> 00:00:47,900
I too, like Taylor Swift, have removed
my entire album collection from Spotify.

9
00:00:47,900 --> 00:00:49,570
>> You know, is that why

10

>> It has.

11
00:00:50,870 --> 00:00:52,570
>> Ronnie sings the oldies.

12
00:00:54,550 --> 00:00:59,160
All right well, speaking of internet
access, I guess we really weren't,

13
00:00:59,160 --> 00:00:59,740
but anyhow.

14
00:01:00,970 --> 00:01:03,790
So we're back here with another
episode of CompTIA Fundamentals, and

15
00:01:03,790 --> 00:01:07,330
we're jumping into Objective 4.0,
which is networking.

16
00:01:07,330 --> 00:01:11,600
So, we've got a lot of networking stuff
to tackle in the next few episodes.

17
00:01:11,600 --> 00:01:16,560
In this one we're doing 4.1
another nice long Objective name.

18
00:01:16,560 --> 00:01:22,558
Given a scenario setup and configure
a basic SOHO router, wired / wireless.

19
00:01:22,558 --> 00:01:23,092
All right?

20
00:01:23,092 --> 00:01:24,415
Nice long title for us.

21
00:01:24,415 --> 00:01:28,550
In most small office,
home office environments, right?

22
00:01:28,550 --> 00:01:30,090
That's what SOHO stands for.

23
00:01:30,090 --> 00:01:32,310
Small office, being you know, a,

24
00:01:32,310 --> 00:01:35,780
a business office that might only have a
handful of employees, four or five people,

25
00:01:35,780 --> 00:01:37,710
you know, not something very large.

26
00:01:37,710 --> 00:01:41,270
A home office might be an employee
that just works from home.

27
00:01:41,270 --> 00:01:42,910
And in those environments,

28
00:01:42,910 --> 00:01:46,890
we'll typically have network gear
that a regular home might not have.

29
00:01:46,890 --> 00:01:49,390
And I know that,
that line's gotten blurred a lot as

30
00:01:49,390 --> 00:01:52,370
things like wireless routers
have become a lot cheaper.

31
00:01:52,370 --> 00:01:54,420
So or, I'm sorry, less expensive.

32
00:01:54,420 --> 00:01:57,150
You're not supposed to say cheaper,
it makes them sound cheap.

33
00:01:57,150 --> 00:01:59,590
But [LAUGH] so, so
these are pretty commonplace now.

34
00:01:59,590 --> 00:02:03,040
So we now have a basic understanding
how to whip one of those things up.

35
00:02:03,040 --> 00:02:07,900
How to get a wireless router setup in an
environment to provide internet access to

36
00:02:07,900 --> 00:02:11,910
more than one PC, laptop,
tablet, phone, whatever.

37
00:02:11,910 --> 00:02:15,415
>> Now, I, I, I think all I need to
do is buy one, take it outta the box,

38
00:02:15,415 --> 00:02:17,250
plug it in, and everything works.

39
00:02:17,250 --> 00:02:18,480
>> Sad.
>> I think that's all I need to do.

40
00:02:18,480 --> 00:02:20,300
>> Sadly, you can do that.

41
00:02:20,300 --> 00:02:21,690
>> Yeah.
>> Right, mo, mo, most of these things you

42
00:02:21,690 --> 00:02:24,580
can take right outta the box,
plug them in and they will work.

43
00:02:25,690 --> 00:02:27,850
But, there,
there's a lot of stuff wrong with that.

44
00:02:27,850 --> 00:02:28,950
>> Right.
>> Right, well what are some of the things

45
00:02:28,950 --> 00:02:29,909
that we're gonna have that are wrong?

46
00:02:30,980 --> 00:02:35,560
Typically, the wireless network
is turned on and not secured,

47
00:02:35,560 --> 00:02:37,290
no password, whatsoever.

48
00:02:37,290 --> 00:02:39,330
So anybody can jump on
your wireless network.

49
00:02:41,190 --> 00:02:43,950
What were some of the other things that
are wrong with a, a default config?

50
00:02:43,950 --> 00:02:48,240
>> Well, because it's unsecured,
they have a default configuration,

51
00:02:48,240 --> 00:02:51,030
which means that anybody that's
hacking probably already knows what

52
00:02:51,030 --> 00:02:52,750
the password is to the router itself.

53
00:02:52,750 --> 00:02:56,320
Which means they can configure it, and
even lock you out of your own router.

54
00:02:56,320 --> 00:03:00,800
>> Even if they don't know the password,
if they see that default wireless name,

55
00:03:00,800 --> 00:03:02,220
they're easy to spot.

56
00:03:02,220 --> 00:03:04,430
All you have to do is go and
pull the manual for that router.

57
00:03:04,430 --> 00:03:08,060
And a lot of companies like Netgear have
been using the same default user name

58
00:03:08,060 --> 00:03:10,790
password combination for
a long, long time.

59
00:03:10,790 --> 00:03:13,050
So they can just look it up in
the support manual for your,

60
00:03:13,050 --> 00:03:14,870
your router and access it.

61
00:03:14,870 --> 00:03:18,580
So while you can take a lot of these
out of the box, plug them in and

62
00:03:18,580 --> 00:03:21,320
just let it go, you don't want to do that.

63
00:03:21,320 --> 00:03:25,410
You'll have a unsecure wireless
network and that's, that's dangerous.

64
00:03:25,410 --> 00:03:28,390
So we need to go in and
modify that default config and

65
00:03:28,390 --> 00:03:30,790
that's what we're gonna take
a look at in this show.

66
00:03:30,790 --> 00:03:34,220
CompTIA calls out several
items here in the list.

67
00:03:34,220 --> 00:03:36,370
It's, like seven things,
I guess, or eight?

68
00:03:36,370 --> 00:03:37,630
>> Eight.
>> Eight things.

69
00:03:37,630 --> 00:03:41,530
Eight things that we need to remember to
go in and check and modify, to make our

70
00:03:41,530 --> 00:03:47,500
network more secure, more stable, and
to make it just work for us properly.

71
00:03:47,500 --> 00:03:49,190
Now, we're gonna show you on a very,

72
00:03:49,190 --> 00:03:54,330
very common router during this show, but
you may have one from a different vendor.

73
00:03:54,330 --> 00:03:57,930
The options are typically going
to be the same, but the menus and

74
00:03:57,930 --> 00:04:00,000
the screens might be
a little bit different.

75
00:04:00,000 --> 00:04:02,890
So you, you're looking for the same
things, they're just in different places.

76
00:04:02,890 --> 00:04:04,970
So what we're gonna show
you is fairly generic,

77
00:04:04,970 --> 00:04:08,910
even though we're going to use
the Linksys/Cisco router here.

78
00:04:08,910 --> 00:04:11,410
It, you could,
could be using any of a number of routers.

79
00:04:12,450 --> 00:04:16,040
All right, so when I get a brand
new wireless router, and I go and

80
00:04:16,040 --> 00:04:19,670
throw it on the network,
I want my PCs to be able to connect to it.

81
00:04:19,670 --> 00:04:22,922
And for a wired PC that's
pretty straightforward, right?

82
00:04:22,922 --> 00:04:24,269
If it was a cable, I'd plug it in.

83
00:04:24,269 --> 00:04:27,550
For a wireless we have to get
the wireless network set up.

84
00:04:27,550 --> 00:04:33,200
But, even before that we need to start
with the internet connection itself.

85
00:04:33,200 --> 00:04:34,110
All right.

86
00:04:34,110 --> 00:04:35,990
If you're putting
a wireless router at home,

87
00:04:35,990 --> 00:04:37,430
it's gotta connect to
the internet somehow.

88
00:04:37,430 --> 00:04:43,560
And there's two main ways, there's DSL and
cable high speed internet, right?

89
00:04:43,560 --> 00:04:44,800
Or cable broadband.

90
00:04:44,800 --> 00:04:46,890
So those are the two main
types of connections you have.

91
00:04:46,890 --> 00:04:48,485
There, there's other ones, right, Ronnie?

92
00:04:48,485 --> 00:04:49,190
You've got, what is your?

93
00:04:49,190 --> 00:04:49,920
>> Satellite.

94
00:04:49,920 --> 00:04:51,080
>> What's yours officially called?

95
00:04:51,080 --> 00:04:53,934
Do you know?
>> Mine is officially called Wildblue.com

96
00:04:53,934 --> 00:04:55,080
satellite.

97
00:04:55,080 --> 00:04:57,940
>> So I, I know that, that there's like
some different standards in there to,

98
00:04:57,940 --> 00:04:58,930
I don't know them myself.

99
00:04:58,930 --> 00:05:00,560
But I know they have some.

100
00:05:00,560 --> 00:05:03,600
So there are other variety of
things that are out there.

101
00:05:03,600 --> 00:05:05,930
But the most common ones are DSL and
cable.

102
00:05:05,930 --> 00:05:07,570
Which is not available in ever area.

103
00:05:07,570 --> 00:05:10,030
Which Ronnie can tell
you all too much about.

104
00:05:10,030 --> 00:05:10,620
>> Oh, yeah.

105
00:05:11,752 --> 00:05:14,360
>> [LAUGH] So when we get that right,
when we get cable or

106
00:05:14,360 --> 00:05:17,350
DSL they're gonna put
a device in called a modem.

107
00:05:17,350 --> 00:05:22,210
And the modem is basically a translator,
it's translating data coming off of

108
00:05:22,210 --> 00:05:26,320
their line into a format that is ready for
your equipment.

109
00:05:26,320 --> 00:05:29,290
And vice versa,
it's taking data from your equipment and

110
00:05:29,290 --> 00:05:32,112
translating it into a format that
will work across that DSL cable.

111
00:05:32,112 --> 00:05:33,660
All right, that's all a modem does.

112
00:05:33,660 --> 00:05:35,350
So on the modem,

113
00:05:35,350 --> 00:05:37,440
there really is no configuration
that you need to worry about.

114
00:05:37,440 --> 00:05:39,360
Your service provider takes care of that.

115
00:05:39,360 --> 00:05:43,580
So if it's DSL,
you plug a phone line into the DSL modem.

116
00:05:43,580 --> 00:05:49,360
If it's cable broadband, you screw
the cable connector onto the cable modem.

117
00:05:49,360 --> 00:05:53,730
But then, they just have a regular network
jack right on an RJ45 network jack, and

118
00:05:53,730 --> 00:05:57,660
you run regular network cable
right into your router.

119
00:05:57,660 --> 00:06:00,760
Your router will typically have
multiple interfaces on it.

120
00:06:00,760 --> 00:06:06,550
And, one of them will be designates
as a WAN port, Wide Area Network.

121
00:06:06,550 --> 00:06:07,430
All right?

122
00:06:07,430 --> 00:06:08,720
It may just say Internet on it.

123
00:06:08,720 --> 00:06:10,140
A, a lot of them do that.

124
00:06:10,140 --> 00:06:12,300
But, some of them still say WAN W-A-N,

125
00:06:12,300 --> 00:06:17,950
and that's to identify that this is
the one that points to the outside world.

126
00:06:17,950 --> 00:06:20,950
All of the other ports you have, and
you might only have one other one, but

127
00:06:20,950 --> 00:06:22,720
you might have five other ones.

128
00:06:22,720 --> 00:06:26,720
All of the other ports will
be inside ports or LAN,

129
00:06:26,720 --> 00:06:30,590
Local Area Network ports, that are
designed for your computers to plug in to.

130
00:06:30,590 --> 00:06:31,210
All right.

131
00:06:31,210 --> 00:06:34,020
So we need to plug our cable modem or
our DSL modem

132
00:06:34,020 --> 00:06:39,000
into that WAN port on the router, and
we need to verify that it's working.

133
00:06:39,000 --> 00:06:42,210
Now the easiest way to verify basic
connectivity, is that when you

134
00:06:42,210 --> 00:06:46,040
plug a network cable in there's a little
light on it called a link light and

135
00:06:46,040 --> 00:06:47,830
it should light up, all right?

136
00:06:47,830 --> 00:06:50,010
If it doesn't light up,
then the cable is not working.

137
00:06:50,010 --> 00:06:52,590
Then it might be the wrong type of
cable or there might be a problem,

138
00:06:52,590 --> 00:06:54,930
the cable modem or
DSM modem might not be working.

139
00:06:54,930 --> 00:06:56,850
There's all sorts of issues
that can pop up there.

140
00:06:56,850 --> 00:06:59,557
We just need to verify that we see that
link light, that's step one, right?

141
00:07:01,270 --> 00:07:05,870
Step two is to see whether your
router is able to use it, and

142
00:07:05,870 --> 00:07:09,640
that's usually done right on
the main screen of your router.

143
00:07:09,640 --> 00:07:11,910
When you log in to your
router's interface,

144
00:07:11,910 --> 00:07:15,020
it'll usually tell you whether that
internet connection is working.

145
00:07:15,020 --> 00:07:16,278
And that's the first
thing CompTIA calls out.

146
00:07:16,278 --> 00:07:21,340
Verify wired connection if applicable and
your internet connection normally will be.

147
00:07:22,390 --> 00:07:26,090
So let me bring up a router interface
here, so I've got one pulled up.

148
00:07:27,160 --> 00:07:34,210
This is a Linksys WRT54G version 2 and
it's a very, very popular access point.

149
00:07:34,210 --> 00:07:36,540
A lot of people use this one.

150
00:07:36,540 --> 00:07:38,290
There was a predecessor to it,

151
00:07:38,290 --> 00:07:43,894
the WRT54G, it was like the defacto
home router for a, a long time.

152
00:07:43,894 --> 00:07:46,136
So, there, there's several of
these products that are out there.

153
00:07:46,136 --> 00:07:48,049
On this one, when I log in,

154
00:07:48,049 --> 00:07:52,307
my main page is actually not as
useful as it is on some of them.

155
00:07:52,307 --> 00:07:55,686
Some of them, when you log in,
they take you to a status page.

156
00:07:55,686 --> 00:07:58,672
And you can s,
see whether things are working or not.

157
00:07:58,672 --> 00:08:00,627
And, and in my case, I look at it and

158
00:08:00,627 --> 00:08:04,600
it's not giving me a status,
this is a configuration page.

159
00:08:04,600 --> 00:08:08,970
And status for me is way over here,
and so I'm gonna go into status.

160
00:08:08,970 --> 00:08:12,620
And here's where I can take a look
at it and find out whether or

161
00:08:12,620 --> 00:08:16,370
not my Internet connection is working,
all right.

162
00:08:16,370 --> 00:08:19,540
When I look at mine I see my
login type is set to DHCP,

163
00:08:19,540 --> 00:08:23,110
that stands for
dynamic host configuration protocol.

164
00:08:23,110 --> 00:08:26,220
I should be getting an IP address and

165
00:08:26,220 --> 00:08:28,840
other information from
my service provider.

166
00:08:28,840 --> 00:08:30,390
I should see numbers.

167
00:08:30,390 --> 00:08:32,450
Right in here, where I just see zeros.

168
00:08:32,450 --> 00:08:36,560
Okay, that's a pretty good indicator right
there that my connection is not working,

169
00:08:36,560 --> 00:08:39,870
I'm not connecting to the Internet,
all right.

170
00:08:39,870 --> 00:08:45,020
So, I've got a problem, and I either
need to call the service provider and,

171
00:08:45,020 --> 00:08:48,170
and work with their tech support to
solve it, or, you know, we could try and

172
00:08:48,170 --> 00:08:51,430
do some troubleshooting on our own,
replace the cable and, and so on.

173
00:08:51,430 --> 00:08:55,070
We could try and get a new DHCP address,
but I can see I'm not getting one.

174
00:08:55,070 --> 00:08:57,350
So I got a problem.

175
00:08:57,350 --> 00:09:00,630
If I were to hook up all my PCs to this
router, they'd be able to see each other,

176
00:09:00,630 --> 00:09:02,260
but they wouldn't be able
to get out to the Internet.

177
00:09:02,260 --> 00:09:03,870
So this is something we
definitely need to overcome.

178
00:09:03,870 --> 00:09:06,450
So this is like step one of
setting up one of these routers

179
00:09:06,450 --> 00:09:09,180
is to verify your Internet
connection is working.

180
00:09:09,180 --> 00:09:10,518
>> I just thought of something.

181
00:09:10,518 --> 00:09:15,260
You said to get access to the router
itself and it to bring this up.

182
00:09:15,260 --> 00:09:17,350
How I actually get to doing that?

183
00:09:17,350 --> 00:09:19,110
Do I have to get some special software?,

184
00:09:19,110 --> 00:09:20,890
But I see you're doing
it through a browser.

185
00:09:20,890 --> 00:09:22,870
>> It depends, right, and
that's why they don't test on it,

186
00:09:22,870 --> 00:09:26,720
that is not one of our objectives because
it is different for every router.

187
00:09:26,720 --> 00:09:29,400
Some routers will have a web
page just like this one.

188
00:09:29,400 --> 00:09:32,570

there it is.

00:23:45,880 --> 00:23:47,537

00:24:16,150 --> 00:24:19,200

00:24:19,200 --> 00:24:22,309

00:24:40,960 --> 00:24:44,240

00:24:44,240 --> 00:24:45,260
So it doesn't matter.

00:24:45,260 --> 00:24:47,770
You don't always have to

00:24:47,770 --> 00:24:51,560
There's always a little bit of risk when

00:24:51,560 --> 00:24:55,450

518
00:24:55,450 --> 00:24:58,750

519
00:24:58,750 --> 00:25:00,240

520
00:25:00,240 --> 00:25:04,150
So, don't apply a firmware update unless
it's actually doing something you need,

521
00:25:04,150 --> 00:25:06,540
