00:22:54,560 --> 00:22:56,690
and the network can start
to get bogged down.

472
00:22:56,690 --> 00:23:00,360
Usually somewhere in the area
of about 300 machines, right?

473
00:23:00,360 --> 00:23:04,110
So when you have about 300 PCs or devices
on your network, you start to get a little

474
00:23:04,110 --> 00:23:07,700
performance degragate, degradation and
you need to divide up your network.

475
00:23:07,700 --> 00:23:10,070
But for small offices and home offices
that's not really gonna happen.

476
00:23:10,070 --> 00:23:14,090
So, concurrent connections is not
something we really worry about

477
00:23:14,090 --> 00:23:16,280
when it comes to physical connections.

478
00:23:16,280 --> 00:23:17,700
But it's different on wireless, isn't it?

479
00:23:17,700 --> 00:23:18,450
>> Yeah.

480
00:23:18,450 --> 00:23:22,130
You know remember because everybody's
actually connecting one antenna, and

481
00:23:22,130 --> 00:23:25,210
only one person can
connect at any one time,

482
00:23:25,210 --> 00:23:29,340
well that actually does limit
us to a little bit more.

483
00:23:29,340 --> 00:23:33,808
So if you have wireless antenna
that may be 54 megabits per second,

484
00:23:33,808 --> 00:23:37,958
you keep dividing that up cuz everybody
is trying to jam that at one time.

485
00:23:37,958 --> 00:23:38,625
>> Mm-hm.

486
00:23:38,625 --> 00:23:40,708
>> All of a sudden,
the bandwidth goes away.

487
00:23:40,708 --> 00:23:43,275
It, it becomes less than
1 kilobit per second and

488
00:23:43,275 --> 00:23:45,792
it may even get less than
that to the point where.

489
00:23:45,792 --> 00:23:48,084
Half the people are not
going to be able to connect.

490
00:23:48,084 --> 00:23:50,977
>> So, when you buy a wireless access
point they'll normally advertise, well,

491
00:23:50,977 --> 00:23:51,810
they usually don't.

492
00:23:51,810 --> 00:23:52,460
>> No.
>> Advertise in

493
00:23:52,460 --> 00:23:55,350
really big letters in the front of the
box, but it'll be in the manual somewhere,

494
00:23:55,350 --> 00:23:58,680
where it will say the maximum
number of simultaneous connections.

495
00:23:58,680 --> 00:24:02,200
And your home routers are usually
only rated for like ten devices.

496
00:24:02,200 --> 00:24:06,910
Right, not a lot, you can get enterprise
ones that can do 26 or 50 connections.

497
00:24:06,910 --> 00:24:10,900
Right, a lot of the Cisco ones, or really
nice Cisco ones, can do 50 connections.

498
00:24:10,900 --> 00:24:13,390
But, even there it, it's just 50.

499
00:24:13,390 --> 00:24:15,460
So, if you're providing wireless for

500
00:24:15,460 --> 00:24:19,370
a company with thousands of employees,
you're gonna have to have many access

501
00:24:19,370 --> 00:24:23,640
points spread out through your building
to service all the various people, right?

502
00:24:23,640 --> 00:24:27,690
So, you do have a limit to the amount
of concurrent connections you can have.

503
00:24:27,690 --> 00:24:32,330
Cellular networks, they can handle tons
of connections right far beyond it, so

504
00:24:32,330 --> 00:24:35,220
really just the wireless access
points that we use they are the ones

505
00:24:35,220 --> 00:24:36,620
that truly create a bottleneck on this.

506
00:24:36,620 --> 00:24:40,430
So, just be aware of it the more antennas
your access point has the more connections

507
00:24:40,430 --> 00:24:45,060
it will be able to support, but most of
them usually only have about two antennas.

508
00:24:45,060 --> 00:24:48,720
And ones used as a send antenna,
and ones used as a receive antenna.

509
00:24:48,720 --> 00:24:53,810
And so it's really just a single antenna's
amount of concurrent users that you get.

510
00:24:53,810 --> 00:24:55,070
That's where that limit comes in.

511
00:24:56,910 --> 00:24:58,730
All right, what is our last point here?

512
00:24:58,730 --> 00:25:00,105
>> Levels of security.

513
00:25:00,105 --> 00:25:00,780
>> Yeah,

514
00:25:00,780 --> 00:25:05,790
each of these connection types gives us
a different level of security, right?

515
00:25:05,790 --> 00:25:07,340
The one I like is wired.

516
00:25:07,340 --> 00:25:10,250
With wired you have a pretty
high degree of security.

517
00:25:10,250 --> 00:25:16,730
If somebody wants to intercept my traffic
on my wired network, they're gonna

518
00:25:16,730 --> 00:25:21,710
come get in between my laptop and the
network somehow, to intercept my signals.

519
00:25:21,710 --> 00:25:23,500
That means they'd have to
be in the building with me.

520
00:25:23,500 --> 00:25:24,890
I'd probably see them do it.

521
00:25:24,890 --> 00:25:27,940
So, you have a high
degree of security there,

522
00:25:27,940 --> 00:25:30,269
just because the nature of
the being of a physical connection.

523
00:25:31,590 --> 00:25:36,660
>> When the wireless not as secure,
the reason why is the single

524
00:25:36,660 --> 00:25:40,750
goes out in every single direction and the
person that may be trying to get access to

525
00:25:40,750 --> 00:25:43,590
that single doesn't have to
be in the same room with you.

526
00:25:43,590 --> 00:25:46,850
Because, the signal is actually emanating
in all different directions, so

527
00:25:46,850 --> 00:25:51,530
that is less secure even with all the
additional security protocols we can add.

528
00:25:51,530 --> 00:25:54,730
Is still less secure than having
a physical wired connection.

529
00:25:54,730 --> 00:25:57,800
>> Yeah, I mean, you know our access point
is mounted on that back wall which is

530
00:25:57,800 --> 00:26:02,300
an exterior wall, it goes out a good
100 feet out into the parking lot.

531
00:26:02,300 --> 00:26:04,860
So, somebody could be out in
the parking lot right now and,

532
00:26:04,860 --> 00:26:06,600
it is encrypted, so there's that.

533
00:26:06,600 --> 00:26:10,610
But, they can be sitting there just
working away on it, capturing data,

534
00:26:10,610 --> 00:26:12,430
trying to decipher,
trying to figure out what that is.

535
00:26:12,430 --> 00:26:15,130
I wouldn't even know they're there,
there's no window on that wall,

536
00:26:15,130 --> 00:26:18,270
I can't, can't see, so
that's the problem with wireless.

537
00:26:18,270 --> 00:26:20,160
And so we've got to be aware of that.

538
00:26:20,160 --> 00:26:22,110
That it does weaken our security.

539
00:26:22,110 --> 00:26:22,950
At least a little bit.

540
00:26:22,950 --> 00:26:25,490
So, that's why it's so
important to encrypt that data.

541
00:26:25,490 --> 00:26:27,760
Now what about cellular, right?

542
00:26:27,760 --> 00:26:30,610
Cellular, it is not impossible, but

543
00:26:30,610 --> 00:26:33,430
it is difficult to intercept
cellular signals, right?

544
00:26:33,430 --> 00:26:37,223
It's done at frequencies that regular
consumer grade equipment isn't allowed to

545
00:26:37,223 --> 00:26:42,380
talk on, so an attack, first off,
is gonna have very specialized equipment.

546
00:26:42,380 --> 00:26:46,130
For a regular wireless network, anybody
can do that, but to intercept cellular,

547
00:26:46,130 --> 00:26:49,620
cellular transmissions require
specialized equipment, so

548
00:26:49,620 --> 00:26:53,120
that's your first obstacle in
intercepting that traffic.

549
00:26:53,120 --> 00:26:56,320
The second obstacle, is just the sheer
amount of cellular traffic that's out

550
00:26:56,320 --> 00:27:00,230
there, so being able to identify traffic
from one person is more challenging.

551
00:27:00,230 --> 00:27:03,450
So, there's a few little factors
that come into play there.

552
00:27:03,450 --> 00:27:06,840
But, the biggest weakness,
the biggest security issue we

553
00:27:06,840 --> 00:27:10,200
really have with cellular is
It's not your network, right?

554
00:27:10,200 --> 00:27:11,360
It's somebody else's network.

555
00:27:11,360 --> 00:27:15,840
It's AT&T or Verizon or whoever.

556
00:27:15,840 --> 00:27:19,490
Whoever it is you've bought your internet
access or your cellular access through,

557
00:27:19,490 --> 00:27:23,500
and so you're trusting them to
provide you that secure communication.

558
00:27:23,500 --> 00:27:27,750
On a wired network, for local traffic,
it's your network, but for

559
00:27:27,750 --> 00:27:30,220
internet you're still trusting
somebody else anyway.

560
00:27:30,220 --> 00:27:33,390
So on the cellular network it's
not that far of a leap, but

561
00:27:33,390 --> 00:27:36,850
we just have to be aware that these
signals are traveling miles potentially,

562
00:27:36,850 --> 00:27:40,820
and there's a lot of room for
somebody to try and try and intercept.

563
00:27:40,820 --> 00:27:43,530
But, of them really just
traditional wireless.

564
00:27:43,530 --> 00:27:46,410
That's the weakest of the three, and
the one we have to worry about the most.

565
00:27:47,738 --> 00:27:52,690
All right, so,
when it comes to comparing cellular,

566
00:27:52,690 --> 00:27:56,040
wireless, and wired,
they've each got their advantages.

567
00:27:56,040 --> 00:27:57,660
They've all got pros and cons, and

568
00:27:57,660 --> 00:28:01,230
different scenarios one will be better
than the other based on your needs.

569
00:28:01,230 --> 00:28:06,190
And it's basically gonna boil down to
band within speed versus mobility or

570
00:28:06,190 --> 00:28:07,740
security versus mobility.

571
00:28:07,740 --> 00:28:12,060
Mobility is really what you get with
the wireless side of things, all right?

572
00:28:12,060 --> 00:28:14,222
So, just keep that in
mind as you compare them.

573
00:28:15,410 --> 00:28:16,945
Can you think anything else
to throw in on that one?

574
00:28:16,945 --> 00:28:21,155
>> I really can, I think we covered it
pretty well, and being able to discuss

575
00:28:21,155 --> 00:28:25,425
the mobility verses all the security, and
all the other options that talked about.

576
00:28:25,425 --> 00:28:26,865
So, I think that's good coverage.

577
00:28:26,865 --> 00:28:27,855
>> Cool.

578

All right, well ladies and
gentlemen, that's a good spot for

579

>> Yeah, we're gonna dive into the last

12
00:00:55,218 --> 00:01:00,076
Our official title for this one is 4.3,
compare and contrast different

13
00:01:00,076 --> 00:01:04,950
methods of sharing and storage, and
what the heck are they talking about?

14
00:01:04,950 --> 00:01:08,110
Well, when you have
more than one computer,

15
00:01:08,110 --> 00:01:11,260
you will often times find where you've
got a file on one computer, and

16
00:01:11,260 --> 00:01:14,040
you'd really like to have
it on the other computer.

17
00:01:14,040 --> 00:01:17,390
And sometimes the computers are right next
to each other like Ronnie and I is, and

18
00:01:17,390 --> 00:01:20,080
sometimes they're in different states or
different countries.

19
00:01:20,080 --> 00:01:23,260
And you still need to be able to get those
files, between the different systems.

20
00:01:23,260 --> 00:01:25,720
So, this is something I
bump into all the time.

21
00:01:25,720 --> 00:01:29,560
I've got a computer at home and when I'm
at my computer at home, I might write up

22
00:01:29,560 --> 00:01:33,190
show notes or whatever, and then I get
here to the office and I'm on this laptop,

23
00:01:33,190 --> 00:01:37,720
and I want access to those same files,
so how do we exchange it?

24
00:01:37,720 --> 00:01:42,140
Well, people, people go through
various stages in their IT careers.

25
00:01:42,140 --> 00:01:45,120
They learn more and
more ways to transfer files,

26
00:01:45,120 --> 00:01:49,415
and unfortunately the first phase is
the worst which is they use email.

27
00:01:49,415 --> 00:01:49,930
>> Mm-hm.

28
00:01:49,930 --> 00:01:53,410
>> Email is a terrible way to move files,
and people do it all the time.

29
00:01:54,440 --> 00:01:57,750
Problems with email are,
first off it's designed for

30
00:01:57,750 --> 00:02:00,160
email, letters, not giant files.

31
00:02:00,160 --> 00:02:02,700
This is designed for very small emails.

32
00:02:02,700 --> 00:02:06,290
The larger your file, the more
damaging it is to the email servers.

33
00:02:06,290 --> 00:02:11,230
So they usually limit you to 10 megabit,
or 10 megabytes of data.

34
00:02:11,230 --> 00:02:15,640
So you're kinda held to a small amount
of data, that you can transmit that way.

35
00:02:15,640 --> 00:02:20,930
The second problem is,
well not just that but it's unencrypted.

36
00:02:20,930 --> 00:02:24,280
Emails don't encrypt their data so
if anybody intercepts that email,

37
00:02:24,280 --> 00:02:25,480
they get your file.

38
00:02:25,480 --> 00:02:29,160
The third problem is, if you change the
file after you've sent it, well too bad.

39
00:02:29,160 --> 00:02:30,270
You've already sent it, right?

40
00:02:30,270 --> 00:02:33,810
So, now it's out there, and
now you got multiple versions of a file.

41
00:02:33,810 --> 00:02:36,120
There's all sorts of
problems with that method.

42
00:02:36,120 --> 00:02:41,241
So, if you're one of those people that
sends files by email, stop it, right now.

43
00:02:41,241 --> 00:02:43,970
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's, not the best way to do things.

44
00:02:43,970 --> 00:02:47,445
So, there are tons of other methods
we can use that are much better.

45
00:02:47,445 --> 00:02:50,945
That don't suffer from the problems
of sending files via email.

46
00:02:50,945 --> 00:02:53,935
And that's what CompT is
really calling out here is,

47
00:02:53,935 --> 00:02:55,965
what are some of the ways that
we can do to exchange that data?

48
00:02:57,657 --> 00:03:02,140
All right, so the first thing they
mention are web based file transfers.

49
00:03:03,170 --> 00:03:06,130
Many websites out there makes files
available for you to download.

50
00:03:06,130 --> 00:03:10,310
We do it right off of our own webpage
at ITProTV for our annual members.

51
00:03:10,310 --> 00:03:13,530
They can go and
download episodes right from the site.

52
00:03:13,530 --> 00:03:17,970
And, you don't need a special program,
or special protocol to do that.

53
00:03:17,970 --> 00:03:23,200
It's done just via regular,
HTTP, or HTTPS, right?

54
00:03:23,200 --> 00:03:27,320
Now, when we download a file from the web,
if it's, not a sensitive file,

55
00:03:27,320 --> 00:03:30,130
if it's something like one of our
episodes, we don't bother encrypting that,

56
00:03:30,130 --> 00:03:31,600
we just send it using HTTP.

57
00:03:31,600 --> 00:03:34,350
But, if you're downloading
sensitive documents or

58
00:03:34,350 --> 00:03:37,210
files from a website,
you'll want that HTTPS.

59
00:03:37,210 --> 00:03:39,690
You'll want that secure,
encrypted connection.

60
00:03:39,690 --> 00:03:42,360
So, it does vary based on
what you're accessing.

61
00:03:42,360 --> 00:03:43,070
But if it's just,

62
00:03:43,070 --> 00:03:47,330
like downloading some new software,
I doubt you'll see that HTTPS connection.

Let me just show an example,
right, so Ronnie,

64

what's a, a software package that we
might want to install on a machine?

65

>> Usually for, for me,
it's something like PuTTY.

66

>> PuTTY's a great example.

So this is our network show, right?

And as a network person you might
need a Telnet or SSH client, or

69

that's available for download.

70

Let me just go and pull up their website.

And, so
I'm gonna fire up my web browser, and

1150
01:12:42,450 --> 01:12:47,630
Now, when we take a look at that,
those permissions are not assigned by me.

1151
01:12:47,630 --> 01:12:51,860
The operating system has
assigned them at a higher level.

1152
01:12:51,860 --> 01:12:54,960
So that now,
anything that Sachi would end this folder,

1153
01:12:54,960 --> 01:13:00,120
folder one, you'll probably
also see that system Ronnie and

1154
01:13:00,120 --> 01:13:03,620
the administrators will end up
getting the same level permissions.

1155
01:13:05,010 --> 01:13:10,129
So remember that I had that
file called Test1 in here.

1156
01:13:10,129 --> 01:13:14,930
If I right-click and
I go to Properties here, and

1157
01:13:14,930 --> 01:13:20,510
I select the Security tab,
notice system, Ronnie,

1158
01:13:20,510 --> 01:13:24,730
and administrators, they will also
have those same permissions, too.

1159
01:13:26,430 --> 01:13:29,680
It's a very good thing, because it
means that all of the permissions that

1160
01:13:29,680 --> 01:13:32,825
are assigned to a folder, those files and

1161
01:13:32,825 --> 01:13:37,030
sub-folders within that folder will
also inherit those same permissions.

1162
01:13:37,030 --> 01:13:40,330
It means that you and I don't have
to go around and explicitly assign

1163
01:13:40,330 --> 01:13:45,540
every single permission, so that users
can gain access to those folders.

1164
01:13:45,540 --> 01:13:49,570
It also means that you and
I can control that if we need to.

1165
01:13:49,570 --> 01:13:53,718
For those of you that are going on towards
your A+ and your Network+ certification,

1166
01:13:53,718 --> 01:13:56,367
and your Windows 7 or, or
Windows 8 certification,

1167
01:13:56,367 --> 01:13:59,760
you'll learn more about file and
folder permissions.

1168
01:13:59,760 --> 01:14:03,200
It allows us to take a single resource,
such as a folder,

1169
01:14:03,200 --> 01:14:08,070
be able to assign different permissions to
different people on that same resource.

1170
01:14:08,070 --> 01:14:10,410
So maybe where you have full control, and

1171
01:14:10,410 --> 01:14:13,490
I only have read-only
access to that folder.

1172
01:14:13,490 --> 01:14:17,070
So that way, we can actually have very,
very granular control,

1173
01:14:17,070 --> 01:14:20,790
very detailed controls on who
can access that folder and

1174
01:14:20,790 --> 01:14:23,570
what level of permissions that they
have on those folders and files too.

1175
01:14:24,620 --> 01:14:26,070
So you'll deal with that more and

1176
01:14:26,070 --> 01:14:30,080
more as you go on and
continue to see that in your IT career.

1177
01:14:30,080 --> 01:14:34,080
But at this point, we're just trying
to demonstrate that they do exist.

1178
01:14:34,080 --> 01:14:38,120
Sometimes a person is not
able to gain access to

1179
01:14:38,120 --> 01:14:43,090
a resource because they don't have
the permissions that they need to be able

1180
01:14:43,090 --> 01:14:47,930
to gain access to that resource such as
a file or a printer, or even a folder.

1181
01:14:47,930 --> 01:14:51,749
But if their name is on there or if they
are part of a group that's actually on

1182
01:14:51,749 --> 01:14:55,870
that list, then they'll have those levels
of permissions to deal with, all right?

1183
01:14:57,030 --> 01:15:00,030
So in this episode,
we really did take a look

1184
01:15:00,030 --> 01:15:03,990
at some of the different ways that you and
I can navigate around an operating system.

1185
01:15:03,990 --> 01:15:05,940
We took the very basic file and

1186
01:15:05,940 --> 01:15:09,730
showed you how we can manipulate
that file by copying it.

1187
01:15:09,730 --> 01:15:12,930
By cutting it and
moving it to a different location.

1188
01:15:12,930 --> 01:15:15,670
By deleting it and even renaming it.

1189
01:15:15,670 --> 01:15:18,880
We also took a look at file and
folder permissions, and that

1190
01:15:18,880 --> 01:15:24,000
we can actually control access to those
resources by using those permissions.

1191
01:15:24,000 --> 01:15:27,110
We showed you some of the different
shortcuts that are available so

1192
01:15:27,110 --> 01:15:30,020
that we can keep our hands on
the keyboard to become more productive.

1193
01:15:31,120 --> 01:15:33,580
We also showed you some of
the information that come,

1194
01:15:33,580 --> 01:15:36,760
that you can also find
on the files themselves.

1195
01:15:36,760 --> 01:15:41,170
And, we also showed you how you can
display certain files by using filters or

1196
01:15:41,170 --> 01:15:42,420
even be able to sort and

1197
01:15:42,420 --> 01:15:45,130
display them differently
depending on what you need to do.

1198
01:15:46,250 --> 01:15:51,580
Lastly, we also took a look at being able
to navigate around using Windows Explorer.

1199
01:15:51,580 --> 01:15:55,650
These are some of the most basic things
that we have to be familiar with

1200
01:15:55,650 --> 01:15:59,820
if we are going to be helping
others in an IT career and

1201
01:15:59,820 --> 01:16:04,330
supporting them as they're using Windows
7 or even any other operating system.

1202
01:16:04,330 --> 01:16:06,600
Some of the other things that we did,
all these things,

1203
01:16:06,600 --> 01:16:08,690
we'll probably have to do regardless
of whether you're on Windows 7,

1204
01:16:08,690 --> 01:16:12,280
or whether you're actually
working in Mac OS 10, or

1205
01:16:12,280 --> 01:16:16,970
even in Linux as to be able to help out
and be able to find this this information.

1206
01:16:16,970 --> 01:16:20,770
So even though we specifically
only stuck with Windows today,

1207
01:16:20,770 --> 01:16:23,910
most of the same concepts will
actually apply even there,

1208
01:16:23,910 --> 01:16:28,800
even though it won't specifically apply on
the details in how we actually got there.

1209
01:16:28,800 --> 01:16:30,940
So remember that as you
continue on towards your study,

1210
01:16:30,940 --> 01:16:35,190
not only for your IT fundamentals, but
also as you move on towards your next step

1211
01:16:35,190 --> 01:16:39,900
in your certification goals,
too, for our A+ studies.

1212
01:16:39,900 --> 01:16:43,740
As always, if you're ali,
alive and you wanna watch you know,

1213
01:16:43,740 --> 01:16:49,770
while we're actually here alive, you can
always interact with us in our chat room.

1214
01:16:49,770 --> 01:16:51,280
By being able to post questions there,

1215
01:16:51,280 --> 01:16:54,950
we try and answer them alive
as we're actually on screen.

1216
01:16:54,950 --> 01:16:56,550
If you happen to be watching this episode,

1217
01:16:56,550 --> 01:17:01,510
and it's in a recorded format,
remember to jump on over onto our webpage.

1218
01:17:01,510 --> 01:17:06,727
On every single webpage that we have on,
on top of every single page is the Q&A,

1219
01:17:06,727 --> 01:17:09,100
and that will lead you
directly to our forums.

1220
01:17:09,100 --> 01:17:11,140
That will allow you to
post questions there.

1221
01:17:11,140 --> 01:17:13,540
We monitor and we answer there, too.

1222
01:17:13,540 --> 01:17:17,320
So take advantage of that as a resource
for you as you continue on and

1223
01:17:17,320 --> 01:17:20,590
towards your preparations for
the IT fundamentals, and

1224
01:17:20,590 --> 01:17:23,270
even towards other certification goals.

1225
01:17:23,270 --> 01:17:24,921
We hoped you enjoyed the show today.

1226
01:17:24,921 --> 01:17:29,011
And if you have, please continue to
watch for more of this coming up.

1227
01:17:29,011 --> 01:17:33,983
And, signing off for IT Pro TV my name is
Ronnie Wong and we'll see you next time.

4
00:00:32,959 --> 00:00:35,911
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

5
00:00:35,911 --> 00:00:38,210
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:38,210 --> 00:00:40,040
I'm your host Don Pezet.

7
00:00:40,040 --> 00:00:41,070
Back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:41,070 --> 00:00:42,040
How's it going Ronnie?

9
00:00:42,040 --> 00:00:43,452
>> It is going well today.

10
00:00:43,452 --> 00:00:45,010
Another beautiful day here in Florida.

11
00:00:45,010 --> 00:00:48,820
A little bit chilly, but
it's a great day for IT fundamentals.

12
00:00:48,820 --> 00:00:50,370
>> Chilly with a chance of rain.

13
00:00:50,370 --> 00:00:50,944
>> That's right.

14
00:00:50,944 --> 00:00:53,360
>> All right, well Ronnie we
are diving right back into CompT,

15
00:00:53,360 --> 00:00:54,500
IT Fundamentals today.

16
00:00:54,500 --> 00:00:57,990
And we've got basic,
well here, the full objective.

17
00:00:57,990 --> 00:00:59,800
We're doing objective 5.3.

18
00:00:59,800 --> 00:01:04,050
Given a scenario,
implement basic support concepts.

19
00:01:04,050 --> 00:01:08,300
And what this objective is all about,
is when you get a new computer,

20
00:01:08,300 --> 00:01:11,400
you take it out of the box,
right, like we did in 5.1.

21
00:01:11,400 --> 00:01:13,550
And we're getting that set up.

22
00:01:13,550 --> 00:01:14,540
What if it doesn't work?

23
00:01:14,540 --> 00:01:17,720
Well, if you, you hook up all the cables,
you hit the power button and

24
00:01:17,720 --> 00:01:21,730
nothing happens, or other types
of issues arise, what do we do?

25
00:01:21,730 --> 00:01:24,060
What are our basic support steps?

26
00:01:24,060 --> 00:01:27,030
Now, for those of you that are going
on to do, like, a A plus certification,

27
00:01:27,030 --> 00:01:29,220
you're gonna learn all
sorts of advanced things.

28
00:01:29,220 --> 00:01:33,190
But we're gonna cover here the basic
steps that really, any person who's

29
00:01:33,190 --> 00:01:36,480
buying a computer should be aware of as
they go through just the initial setup.

30
00:01:36,480 --> 00:01:37,990
You know.

31
00:01:37,990 --> 00:01:42,030
>> In supporting a, a computer setup, once
we get it set up, one of the first things

32
00:01:42,030 --> 00:01:46,880
especially if nothing's working,
is to check the physical connections.

33
00:01:46,880 --> 00:01:48,720
It's very easy to plug everything in and

34
00:01:48,720 --> 00:01:52,890
do like I do, forget to plug like,
the power cable in.

35
00:01:52,890 --> 00:01:55,810
Even though I've got it
plugged into the power supply,

36
00:01:55,810 --> 00:02:00,110
forgetting to actually connect it right to
the wall outlet or to a power strip, or

37
00:02:00,110 --> 00:02:01,400
even turning on the power strip.

38
00:02:01,400 --> 00:02:03,990
You know, that's, some,
something like that is actually very easy.

39
00:02:03,990 --> 00:02:05,580
>> Yeah, any time I buy something new and

40
00:02:05,580 --> 00:02:07,985
it doesn't work,
>> I get this moment of.

41
00:02:07,985 --> 00:02:09,450
>> [LAUGH] panic
>> not so

42
00:02:09,450 --> 00:02:12,760
much panic as much as it is like dread and
I'm like ugh,

43
00:02:12,760 --> 00:02:15,570
I'm gonna have to deal with tech support
or I'm going to have to return this.

44
00:02:15,570 --> 00:02:17,238
I'm gonna ship it back.

45
00:02:17,238 --> 00:02:20,620
It's all this burden, like when you buy
something you just expect it to work.

46
00:02:20,620 --> 00:02:26,970
So ideally you can do everything you can
to avoid having to send it back, right.

47
00:02:26,970 --> 00:02:28,380
>> Yep.
>> Having to create that delay.

48
00:02:28,380 --> 00:02:30,920
Getting this thing to work if you can,
but at the same time,

49
00:02:30,920 --> 00:02:35,420
you don't wanna keep something
that's not as it should be, right?

50
00:02:35,420 --> 00:02:37,630
You don't wanna,
to receive a broken device and say,

51
00:02:37,630 --> 00:02:38,994
well I guess I'll just keep
it cuz I'm in a hurry.

52
00:02:38,994 --> 00:02:40,920
[LAUGH] You, you know,
you paid full price for something,

53
00:02:40,920 --> 00:02:43,140
you should be able to
expect to get that product.

54
00:02:43,140 --> 00:02:45,050
And hopefully it's something simple.

55
00:02:45,050 --> 00:02:46,170
Ronnie, you hit the nail on the head.

56
00:02:46,170 --> 00:02:46,750
>> Yeah.

57
00:02:46,750 --> 00:02:51,740
>> A loose cable or connection can make
it look like the entire computer is dead,

58
00:02:51,740 --> 00:02:52,960
and we just need to tighten that up.

59
00:02:52,960 --> 00:02:57,930
So, all those cables that we hooked up in
Objective 5.1, when we plugged in the,

60
00:02:57,930 --> 00:03:00,750
the mouse, the keyboard, the monitor.

61
00:03:00,750 --> 00:03:02,090
The power cables, right?

62
00:03:02,090 --> 00:03:05,120
Power on the monitor,
power on the computer, the speakers.

63
00:03:05,120 --> 00:03:06,700
That's a lot of cables to hook up.

64
00:03:06,700 --> 00:03:07,780
Some of them can be mixed up,

65
00:03:07,780 --> 00:03:11,740
some of them might feel like they're
in but not actually be all the way in.

66
00:03:11,740 --> 00:03:13,970
PS2 ports are really bad about that.

67
00:03:13,970 --> 00:03:18,190
Sometimes PS2 ports will grab on
the circle, shielding on the outside, but

68
00:03:18,190 --> 00:03:20,110
the pins aren't actually in the slots.

69
00:03:20,110 --> 00:03:21,490
I've done that more than once.

70
00:03:21,490 --> 00:03:24,080
So it looks like the cable is all
the way in, but it actually isn't.

71
00:03:24,080 --> 00:03:27,890
So, just go through and unplug the cable,
and plug the cable back in, and

72
00:03:27,890 --> 00:03:30,180
make sure it's seated nice and firm.

73
00:03:30,180 --> 00:03:33,010
Also check the cables,
if it's, if it's a male cable,

74
00:03:33,010 --> 00:03:35,970
if it's got pins in it,
just visually inspect the pins.

75
00:03:35,970 --> 00:03:38,260
Make sure there's no bent or broken pins.

76
00:03:38,260 --> 00:03:41,500
You may simply have a bad cable, and
the rest of the equipment is just fine.

77
00:03:41,500 --> 00:03:44,290
So you just need to,
to replace that one component.

78
00:03:44,290 --> 00:03:45,180
>> Yep.
>> Right.

79
00:03:45,180 --> 00:03:48,840
But if we start examining that and
things still aren't working for us,

80
00:03:48,840 --> 00:03:50,680
there's a few other things we can check,
right?

81
00:03:50,680 --> 00:03:53,290
Like what's on the list here is, power.

82
00:03:53,290 --> 00:03:57,080
>> Well, we, we did mention power
a little bit when I, I described it, but

83
00:03:57,080 --> 00:04:00,600
not only is the AC outlet, now Don,
this happened in my house.

84
00:04:00,600 --> 00:04:05,380
I have one of those walls that has two you
know little light, light switches on and

85
00:04:05,380 --> 00:04:08,140
I didn't realize that one of those
light switches actually controls one of

86
00:04:08,140 --> 00:04:08,785
the power outlets.

87
00:04:08,785 --> 00:04:10,510
>> Mm-hm.
>> So I went to turn it off and

88
00:04:10,510 --> 00:04:12,530
then I went to plug my computer
in to charge and like,

89
00:04:12,530 --> 00:04:14,160
I don't know what's going on.

90
00:04:14,160 --> 00:04:15,940
Even simple things like that.

91
00:04:15,940 --> 00:04:19,390
But the other thing is we, we rely on so
many wireless devices today

92
00:04:19,390 --> 00:04:24,100
that it could be just the battery
itself is just not connected.

93
00:04:24,100 --> 00:04:27,160
Just recently I can't remember
what device it was but

94
00:04:27,160 --> 00:04:30,125
now they have these little plastic slips
that they put in between the batteries.

95
00:04:30,125 --> 00:04:30,800
>> Mm-hm.

96
00:04:30,800 --> 00:04:34,690
>> And a, a lot of times they have
a little a little little piece of plastic.

97
00:04:34,690 --> 00:04:35,240
>> A tab or something.

98
00:04:35,240 --> 00:04:36,590
>> that yeah that pulls it out.

99
00:04:36,590 --> 00:04:37,890
But this one didn't.

100
00:04:37,890 --> 00:04:42,430
So I had to actually undo, and actually
pull it out from the battery, so it was

101
00:04:42,430 --> 00:04:45,710
off, even though it didn't have anything,
I had to go into the instructions itself.

102
00:04:45,710 --> 00:04:48,370
It said, remove the safety,
or whatever, the,

103
00:04:48,370 --> 00:04:51,200
the plastic wrap around the battery
before that should work.

104
00:04:51,200 --> 00:04:53,591
So, sometimes Don doesn't panic, but I do.

105
00:04:53,591 --> 00:04:54,383
>> [LAUGH]
>> And, I'm like,

106
00:04:54,383 --> 00:04:57,040
I can't believe I just paid money for
this thing, now I've gotta return it.

107
00:04:57,040 --> 00:04:57,850
To, to get it done.

108
00:04:57,850 --> 00:05:00,810
So, so remember,
it's not only about the AC power,

109
00:05:00,810 --> 00:05:03,220
but also about the battery power too.

110
00:05:03,220 --> 00:05:04,747
>> Yeah, and, and
you'd see batteries if you

111
00:05:04,747 --> 00:05:05,970
had like a wireless keyboard-
>> Mm-hm.

112
00:05:05,970 --> 00:05:07,430
>> Or a wireless mouse.

113
00:05:07,430 --> 00:05:09,435
You, you have batteries in a laptop.

114
00:05:09,435 --> 00:05:10,135
>> Mm-hm.
But they normally

115
00:05:10,135 --> 00:05:10,935
don't put the little pull
>> Right.

116
00:05:10,935 --> 00:05:12,145
>> tabs in there because
they're rechargeable.

117
00:05:12,145 --> 00:05:15,305
But when you get a wireless keyboard or
mouse, they're normally just regular

118
00:05:15,305 --> 00:05:19,475
batteries and I know a lot of companies
ship them where the batteries are outside

119
00:05:19,475 --> 00:05:21,545
of the keyboard, but
if they're actually in the keyboard or

120
00:05:21,545 --> 00:05:24,335
in the mouse when you receive it, if they
didn't put that little tab in there,

121
00:05:24,335 --> 00:05:26,295
the battery would drain while
it was sitting on the shelf.

122
00:05:26,295 --> 00:05:28,775
So that's why they do that,
but it is easy to, to forget.

123
00:05:28,775 --> 00:05:31,440
>> Yeah
>> For me, when it comes to power there,

124
00:05:31,440 --> 00:05:33,710
there's a couple things
that I always mess up.

125
00:05:33,710 --> 00:05:36,640
One is when you hook up a computer,
you got a lot of power, so

126
00:05:36,640 --> 00:05:41,210
the, the devices we were hooking up in
the earlier episode, we did a speaker bar

127
00:05:41,210 --> 00:05:45,840
that had a power plug, the tower's
power supply had one and the monitor.

128
00:05:45,840 --> 00:05:49,360
So that's already three devices
right there on a standard computer.

129
00:05:49,360 --> 00:05:51,650
Your wall socket likely
only has two connectors.

130
00:05:51,650 --> 00:05:53,660
So you're probably gonna
use a power strip.

131
00:05:53,660 --> 00:05:57,490
And your power strip will usually
have an on/off switch on it.

132
00:05:57,490 --> 00:05:58,730
So that could be off.

133
00:05:58,730 --> 00:06:02,920
And it also usually has a circuit in there
as, to act as a minor surge suppressor.

134
00:06:02,920 --> 00:06:03,800
So it could be tripped.

135
00:06:03,800 --> 00:06:06,080
There's usually, like,
a reset button on those.

136
00:06:06,080 --> 00:06:09,460
You could always troubleshoot by
taking the power strip out and

137
00:06:09,460 --> 00:06:12,500
plugging directly into the wall just
to test, try a different power socket.

138
00:06:12,500 --> 00:06:15,280
Those are all different
things that we can check.

139
00:06:15,280 --> 00:06:18,160
But, it is always possible
the power supply can be damaged.

140
00:06:18,160 --> 00:06:21,960
Another thing to keep in mind on power,
some power supplies have a little switch

141
00:06:21,960 --> 00:06:26,020
on the back that lets them
move between 110 volt and

142
00:06:26,020 --> 00:06:30,350
220 volt outlets or,
sometimes they say 120 and 240.

143
00:06:30,350 --> 00:06:34,160
Here in the United States all of
our wall sockets are 110 volt but

144
00:06:34,160 --> 00:06:36,730
in other countries,

00:26:09,228 --> 00:26:12,230
>> You know, and nobody wants to get
something new and not be able to use it.

601
00:26:12,230 --> 00:26:12,980
>> Yeah.
>> Right?

602
00:26:12,980 --> 00:26:14,620
I got a new computer,
I wanna see what it can do.

603
00:26:14,620 --> 00:26:15,250
>> Yeah.
>> And

604
00:26:15,250 --> 00:26:16,620
>> Won't even work or

605
00:26:16,620 --> 00:26:19,430
it's got a cracked screen, and
that stuff's really frustrating.

606
00:26:19,430 --> 00:26:23,500
So, yeah, you definitely don't wanna
put up with that if you don't have to.

607
00:26:23,500 --> 00:26:26,160
All right, well ladies and gentlemen,
that pretty much wraps up our basic

608
00:26:26,160 --> 00:26:29,450
troubleshooting steps right there, so
this is a good point for us to stop.

609
00:26:29,450 --> 00:26:34,470
We do still have a couple more topics that
we need to get to for basic IT literacy.

610

So stay turned,
we've got more content coming up.

611
00:26:37,060 --> 00:26:39,860
But for right now,
well let's wrap this turkey up.

612

615

Post your questions there,

616

If you have questions after the show,

617

>> At the top of every page,
you'll see a link that says Q&A.

618

Just click on it, take you to the forums.

619
00:26:58,390 --> 00:27:00,070
To our technical support forums.

And you can post your questions there, and

621

we'll post all sorts of crazy
stuff in response, like.

It helps with conductivity.

>> Yes.
>> And and so

625

we'll respond with all sorts

626
00:27:09,550 --> 00:27:12,210
Take advantage of that resource,
it's there for you.

627
00:27:12,210 --> 00:27:15,570
I didn't even think about it, I'm about

See this is the quality

629

All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed the show today.

630

Signing off for IT Pro TV, I'm Don Pazete.

episodes.title: Basic Backup Concepts
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,147 --> 00:00:36,837
All right, good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening, and welcome back,

3
00:00:36,837 --> 00:00:38,271
to another episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:38,271 --> 00:00:40,060
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

5
00:00:40,060 --> 00:00:41,170
Back again here with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:41,170 --> 00:00:42,140
How's it going, Ronnie?

7
00:00:42,140 --> 00:00:43,950
>> It is going well today.

8
00:00:43,950 --> 00:00:46,430
We have another beautiful
day here in Florida, and

9
00:00:46,430 --> 00:00:48,700
we are still doing IT fundamentals.

10
00:00:48,700 --> 00:00:51,974
But, I need to actually get pretty
close to, to back up my laptop,

11
00:00:51,974 --> 00:00:54,433
because it's probably been almost a year,
Don.

12
00:00:54,433 --> 00:00:55,270
>> Since you backed up your laptop?

13
00:00:55,270 --> 00:00:56,570
>> Since I backed up my laptop.

14
00:00:56,570 --> 00:00:58,870
>> Well, this is the episode for you.

15
00:00:58,870 --> 00:01:02,140
We are continuing on with
CompTIA IT fundamentals.

16
00:01:02,140 --> 00:01:05,500
Our major objective is 5.0,
basic IT literacy.

17
00:01:05,500 --> 00:01:10,350
But in this episode, we're jumping
straight to 5.4 explain basic

18
00:01:10,350 --> 00:01:14,951
backup concepts and backing up of
our data is something that a lot of

19
00:01:14,951 --> 00:01:18,337
people don't think about
until it's too late.

20
00:01:18,337 --> 00:01:21,297
Now, what are we talking about when
we talk about backing things up?

21
00:01:21,297 --> 00:01:24,210
Well, you have a lot of
information on your computer.

22
00:01:24,210 --> 00:01:28,020
You have emails that you've written,
and files that you've created,

23
00:01:28,020 --> 00:01:30,900
documents that you save,
maybe tax paperwork you filled out, or

24
00:01:30,900 --> 00:01:35,090
whatever, and all of that gets stored
on the hard drive in your computer.

25
00:01:35,090 --> 00:01:37,370
Unfortunately, hard drives
don't last forever.

26
00:01:37,370 --> 00:01:41,380
If it's a mechanical hard drive, one
that has spinning platters inside of it,

27
00:01:41,380 --> 00:01:44,250
it's probably only rated for
about three years.

28
00:01:44,250 --> 00:01:46,880
Look at the warranty of your hard
drive when you buy it or, you know,

29
00:01:46,880 --> 00:01:48,170
the warranty of your computer.

30
00:01:48,170 --> 00:01:51,660
If your hard drive only comes with a one
year warranty, that means after year one,

31
00:01:51,660 --> 00:01:55,430
the hardware manufacturer no longer
trusts that drive to survive.

32
00:01:55,430 --> 00:01:57,902
And if it comes with a three
year warranty, same thing, but

33
00:01:57,902 --> 00:01:59,320
just three years out.

34
00:01:59,320 --> 00:02:01,510
So, if you're beyond that period,

35
00:02:01,510 --> 00:02:04,410
it's pretty safe to say your
drive could fail at any moment.

36
00:02:04,410 --> 00:02:08,350
But, even if it's before,
when you have a moving piece,

37
00:02:08,350 --> 00:02:11,560
any kind of equipment that
has a moving part can fail.

38
00:02:11,560 --> 00:02:14,260
It doesn't necessarily
last the whole time.

39
00:02:14,260 --> 00:02:18,050
And, you never want to have yourself in
a position where you lose that drive.

40
00:02:18,050 --> 00:02:20,400
And you lose things that
were important to you.

41
00:02:20,400 --> 00:02:22,730
Because, there are some
things we can't recreate.

42
00:02:22,730 --> 00:02:25,780
And that is a, a real,
real, just, travesty.

43
00:02:25,780 --> 00:02:27,610
I mean it can be, it can be sickening.

44
00:02:27,610 --> 00:02:28,840
Have you ever had that, Ronnie?

45
00:02:28,840 --> 00:02:30,690
>> Oh yeah.
>> Where you lost data and?

46
00:02:30,690 --> 00:02:33,630
>> Oh yeah.
There's, even do this day, when I

47
00:02:33,630 --> 00:02:38,200
end up moving, cause I've moved from
Georgia to Tennessee to North Carolina and

48
00:02:38,200 --> 00:02:41,860
South Carolina to Florida and
back to Florida again before.

49
00:02:41,860 --> 00:02:46,490
I still have a hard drive that I swear
has data on it, that, that I can't find.

50
00:02:46,490 --> 00:02:49,260
So, there's a couple of different hard
drives that have gone missing and

51
00:02:49,260 --> 00:02:52,520
I wish I had a backup somewhere
of that information that I could

52
00:02:52,520 --> 00:02:54,970
have gotten access to when I needed,
and I don't.

53
00:02:54,970 --> 00:03:00,450
Backups are the only real way that we can
ensure that we're not going to lose data.

54
00:03:00,450 --> 00:03:04,030
Doing it like I did just once
a year is probably not enough, yup.

55
00:03:04,030 --> 00:03:06,730
>> Yeah and it,
it's when that drive fails, you know,

56
00:03:06,730 --> 00:03:08,760
when you look at it [CROSSTALK]
>> It's sickening.

57
00:03:08,760 --> 00:03:09,294
>> And you're like man, my.

58
00:03:09,294 --> 00:03:10,670
>> [LAUGH]
>> That was my family photos.

59
00:03:10,670 --> 00:03:11,230
>> Yeah.
>> Or whatever.

60
00:03:11,230 --> 00:03:12,740
You get this, this sinking feeling
>> Yeah.

61
00:03:12,740 --> 00:03:13,720
>> In your gut, it's terrible.

62
00:03:13,720 --> 00:03:15,132
You don't want that to happen.

63
00:03:15,132 --> 00:03:19,550
I, I, I started out in computers
doing warranty repairs for people.

64
00:03:19,550 --> 00:03:21,530
I replaced a lot of hard drives in my day.

65
00:03:21,530 --> 00:03:25,480
And we used to get people that were
like PhD Students, or, you know,

66
00:03:25,480 --> 00:03:27,440
doctorial students at a college.

67
00:03:27,440 --> 00:03:31,920
And, they'd have their, their dissertation
on there they'd been working on for years,

68
00:03:31,920 --> 00:03:33,210
and, and it's gone.

69
00:03:33,210 --> 00:03:35,590
And and they'd say well is there
someway you can get it off the drive,

70
00:03:35,590 --> 00:03:37,480
and usually you can't.

71
00:03:37,480 --> 00:03:39,020
>> Right.
Sometimes there's ways you can get

72
00:03:39,020 --> 00:03:41,940
the data off there, but most of the times,
you can't, the data's just gone.

73
00:03:41,940 --> 00:03:44,575
Now, if they had a good
backup with their system,

74
00:03:44,575 --> 00:03:46,440
then they wouldn't be sweating it at all.

75
00:03:46,440 --> 00:03:47,480
Hey, my drive failed.

76
00:03:47,480 --> 00:03:50,390
That sucks, but,
I got my data over here too, so I'm okay.

77
00:03:50,390 --> 00:03:51,720
I've got my information.

78
00:03:51,720 --> 00:03:52,300
Right?

79
00:03:52,300 --> 00:03:54,740
And so this is something
that we can't stress enough.

80
00:03:54,740 --> 00:03:57,700
You should never have just
one copy of your data.

81
00:03:57,700 --> 00:04:00,630
You should always have
at least two copies, so

82
00:04:00,630 --> 00:04:02,740
that you can recover in
the event of a failure.

83
00:04:02,740 --> 00:04:06,360
Do not trust your hard drive,
hard drives fail.

84
00:04:06,360 --> 00:04:08,940
Even if you have the solid state drives,
they're actually a little worse.

85
00:04:08,940 --> 00:04:10,710
They can fail before
a physical hard drive, and

86
00:04:10,710 --> 00:04:12,410
usually give you very little warning.

87
00:04:12,410 --> 00:04:15,390
So, we definitely want
to back those things up.

88
00:04:15,390 --> 00:04:19,070
Fortunately, in today's world, we have
a lot of choices that are out there, and

89
00:04:19,070 --> 00:04:21,710
we'll take a look at some of
the different methods that we can use.

90
00:04:21,710 --> 00:04:23,820
And Marvin, in the chat room,

91
00:04:23,820 --> 00:04:27,280
actually asked a question here just
a minute ago about when he does a backup.

92
00:04:27,280 --> 00:04:31,810
Making sure that he doesn't get just
what's done right now versus what he

93
00:04:31,810 --> 00:04:32,770
might have done in the past.

94
00:04:32,770 --> 00:04:34,530
Now, I'll, I'll talk about that too,
here, in just a minute.

95
00:04:34,530 --> 00:04:38,682
Some of the, some of the solutions we
have can take care of that same problem.

96
00:04:38,682 --> 00:04:42,140
All right, so, let's start with
just a couple of things, right?

97
00:04:42,140 --> 00:04:43,390
We know what a backup is.

98
00:04:43,390 --> 00:04:46,759
Backup is just a second copy of our data,
right?

99
00:04:46,759 --> 00:04:51,580
So, one of the decisions we have to
make is when to do those backups,

100
00:04:51,580 --> 00:04:54,130
how often we should do the backups.

101
00:04:54,130 --> 00:04:55,770
And then when we schedule them, right?

102
00:04:55,770 --> 00:05:00,200
So, Ronnie, what, what do you,
what's your opinion on this one?

103
00:05:00,200 --> 00:05:00,980
>> The more often,

104
00:05:00,980 --> 00:05:05,310
the better, but normally what ends
up happening is that I forget.

105
00:05:05,310 --> 00:05:11,740
So even though I have a good intention
of backing up weekly, I realize

106
00:05:11,740 --> 00:05:14,810
that after a time, it's usually been
a month before I've backed up anything.

107
00:05:14,810 --> 00:05:16,833
And then sometimes we're really busy,

108
00:05:16,833 --> 00:05:19,580
it may be two months
before I back up anything.

109
00:05:19,580 --> 00:05:22,570
And by that point,
my computer's changed so rapidly.

110
00:05:22,570 --> 00:05:23,770
Stuff I've deleted.

111
00:05:23,770 --> 00:05:25,050
Stuff that's gone.

112
00:05:25,050 --> 00:05:27,500
Stuff that have changed is now, not there.

113
00:05:27,500 --> 00:05:29,230
And so yeah, things can change rapidly.

114
00:05:29,230 --> 00:05:33,050
>> Now, the amount of time between backups
is going to vary between person to person.

115
00:05:33,050 --> 00:05:33,870
All right?

116
00:05:33,870 --> 00:05:38,240
The time between backups,
is basically a statement from you saying,

117
00:05:38,240 --> 00:05:41,740
this is the amount of data
I can afford to lose.

118
00:05:41,740 --> 00:05:43,480
Let's say that we back up once a week.

119
00:05:43,480 --> 00:05:46,310
So I'm going to back up
my computer every Sunday.

120
00:05:46,310 --> 00:05:49,040
So every Sunday,
I'm going to back up my whole computer.

121
00:05:49,040 --> 00:05:53,550
Well, If I have a failure, I can just go
get my backup from the last Sunday and

122
00:05:53,550 --> 00:05:54,460
I'm back in business, right?

123
00:05:54,460 --> 00:05:56,830
But what if today is Friday?

124
00:05:56,830 --> 00:06:00,250
If today is Friday and
I have a failure, I haven't

125
00:06:00,250 --> 00:06:04,590
backed up all the work that I did on
Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday.

126
00:06:04,590 --> 00:06:08,440
If I go back to last Sunday,
I loose everything since then, and

127
00:06:08,440 --> 00:06:10,760
so, if that was a lot of work.

128
00:06:10,760 --> 00:06:14,600
If I put a lot of effort in that,
like if I lost my show notes for

129
00:06:14,600 --> 00:06:17,620
those days, I would be so frustrated.

130
00:06:17,620 --> 00:06:21,060
I can't afford to lose
multiply days worth of work.

131
00:06:21,060 --> 00:06:25,390
If I lost one day of work, I'd be okay,
I could, I could redo that, I'd,

132
00:06:25,390 --> 00:06:29,100
I'd be able to cope with that, but
I can't lose a week's work, I, I can't,

133
00:06:29,100 --> 00:06:30,060
it's just too much.

134
00:06:30,060 --> 00:06:34,370
Right, so for me,
a weekly backup is not acceptable.

135
00:06:34,370 --> 00:06:36,196
A monthly backup is unconscionable for
me, right?

136
00:06:36,196 --> 00:06:38,160
>> [LAUGH]
>> But but a, a weekly is,

137
00:06:38,160 --> 00:06:39,110
is really not possible either.

138
00:06:39,110 --> 00:06:42,090
So for me, I need a daily backup,

139
00:06:42,090 --> 00:06:45,850
I need a backup every single daily
at a minimum if not more frequently.

140
00:06:45,850 --> 00:06:51,470
If you're something like a stock exchange,
where you're processing stock purchases.

141
00:06:51,470 --> 00:06:53,420
You can't afford to lose any data
>> Yeah.

142
00:06:53,420 --> 00:06:56,020
>> Right?
So even going a single day would be too

143
00:06:56,020 --> 00:07:00,000
crazy to try and rebuild all the financial
transactions you did in that day.

144
00:07:00,000 --> 00:07:04,010
So for companies,
they may backup very, very frequently.

145
00:07:04,010 --> 00:07:07,780
For us though, we may back our personal
stuff up much less frequently.

146
00:07:07,780 --> 00:07:10,540
And I,
I personally do a backup every single day.

147
00:07:10,540 --> 00:07:12,710
But you know,
different people have different methods.

148
00:07:12,710 --> 00:07:15,130
And, Ronnie, you mentioned like,
you forget, right?

149
00:07:15,130 --> 00:07:15,850
>> Yes.
>> So you,

150
00:07:15,850 --> 00:07:17,640
you do a manual backup on your system,
right?

151
00:07:17,640 --> 00:07:18,550
>> I do.
Yeah, and

152
00:07:18,550 --> 00:07:23,130
the reason why I do a manual backup,
I don't know why, I just like to do it.

153
00:07:23,130 --> 00:07:25,590
I like to see it start,
I like to see it finish.

154
00:07:25,590 --> 00:07:28,270
And so, normally,
when I have everything ready to go, I,

155
00:07:28,270 --> 00:07:29,340
I want to go ahead and do that.

156
00:07:29,340 --> 00:07:30,830
But there are times I forget.

157
00:07:30,830 --> 00:07:34,297
I always back up this little terabyte
hard drive that I have USB, and

158
00:07:34,297 --> 00:07:36,270
sometimes I leave
the terabyte hard drive here.

159
00:07:36,270 --> 00:07:39,740
Sometimes I leave it at home.

160
00:07:39,740 --> 00:07:41,930
Sometimes it's just not
where I need it and so

161
00:07:41,930 --> 00:07:43,960
that's why I always end up forgetting.

162
00:07:43,960 --> 00:07:47,436
>> And most of the backup solutions
that you choose do have an option,

163
00:07:47,436 --> 00:07:51,130
do an automatic backup, but they will
ask you for a schedule, typically,

164
00:07:51,130 --> 00:07:52,470
because here's the thing.

165
00:07:52,470 --> 00:07:55,459
A lot of us like to schedule the backups
in the middle of the night when we're

166
00:07:55,459 --> 00:07:56,793
not using the computer, right?

167
00:07:56,793 --> 00:07:58,950
Backing up your computer can
take a lot of resources.

168
00:07:58,950 --> 00:08:01,350
It has to read all your data and
back that up So,

169
00:08:01,350 --> 00:08:05,000
you probably don't want to do that
while you're using the computer.

170
00:08:05,000 --> 00:08:08,500
So, if we can schedule it for the middle
of the night, I'm not using the computer.

171
00:08:08,500 --> 00:08:10,832
It'll run the backup and
it'll be perfect, and it will do it so

172
00:08:10,832 --> 00:08:13,170
I don't have to worry about me forgetting.

173
00:08:13,170 --> 00:08:14,815
But what if I turn my
computer off at night?

174
00:08:14,815 --> 00:08:16,180
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now it's not so viable.

175
00:08:16,180 --> 00:08:17,120
The computer's not on.

176
00:08:17,120 --> 00:08:19,450
It can't run a backup
if you're powered off.

177
00:08:19,450 --> 00:08:22,940
So, we need to schedule the backups to
occur at a time when we know the computer

178
00:08:22,940 --> 00:08:24,170
will be on.

179
00:08:24,170 --> 00:08:27,230
And it is a good idea to do
automatic scheduling on it.

180
00:08:27,230 --> 00:08:30,570
I know that's how I have my laptop set up,
so that it'll do backups

181
00:08:30,570 --> 00:08:33,910
just when it's on and and
I actually don't have a time set on mine.

182
00:08:33,910 --> 00:08:37,430
I have mine just set to do a backup once
a day whenever it's powered on, right?

183
00:08:37,430 --> 00:08:41,510
So, it'll actually do backups while
I'm using the laptop and, and

184
00:08:41,510 --> 00:08:45,640
that's kind of a nice thing if you're
just wanting to guarantee a backup.

185
00:08:45,640 --> 00:08:48,230
I'm willing to give up a little
performance in exchange for

186
00:08:48,230 --> 00:08:49,800
knowing that my data has been duplicated.

187
00:08:49,800 --> 00:08:51,030
All right.

188
00:08:51,030 --> 00:08:54,850
So, as far as scheduling and frequency,
that will vary from person to person, but

189
00:08:54,850 --> 00:08:57,330
these are the things we need to,
to take into account.

190
00:08:58,460 --> 00:09:01,550
The other thing we need to
consider when we backup is,

191
00:09:01,550 --> 00:09:03,350
what are we backing our data up to?

192
00:09:03,350 --> 00:09:04,710
Where, where are we copying it?

193
00:09:04,710 --> 00:09:06,395
Cuz you can make some
really bad decisions.
